headline: Japan Talks By Publisher
abstract: LEAD: Owen J. Lipstein, the publisher of Smart, Psychology Today and Mother Earth News, said yesterday that he was negotiating with a Japanese company interested in a buying a 50 percent stake in his publications.

headline: New Venture Gear
abstract: LEAD: New Venture Gear Inc., the first joint manufacturing effort between leading United States auto makers, signed a four-year deal to supply parts for the British Rover Group's new diesel model. New Venture was formed earlier this year by Acustar, a division of the Chrysler Corporation, and the General Motors Corporation.

headline: Panel Backs Fraud Funds
abstract: LEAD: Legislation that would triple Federal spending to pursue savings and loan fraud won unanimous endorsement today from members of a House banking panel.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   The Pope and Prague
abstract: LEAD: The Vatican and Czechoslovakia restored diplomatic relations today in a step that expands the Roman Catholic Church's influence in the former Communist-governed countries of Eastern Europe.

headline: Citicorp Rates Up for 3d Week
abstract: LEAD: Interest rates rose yesterday for the third consecutive week at Citicorp's auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper, following the general rise in rates for most debt securities in the same period.

headline: A Singer Wins Frito-Lay Suit
abstract: LEAD: Frito-Lay Inc. must pay the singer Tom Waits almost $2.5 million for imitating his gravelly style in a radio commercial for corn chips, a Federal court jury decided on Tuesday.

headline: Allegheny Opposed On Reorganization
abstract: LEAD: Japonica Partners L.P. said it would file suit in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Pittsburgh to block Allegheny International Inc.'s reorganization plan. Japonica contends Allegheny's plan was set up to allow a group that includes the company's senior management to seize control of Allegheny. Japonica last week filed its own amended cash plan of reorganization, which increases the price it is offering for Allegheny by $5 million, to an aggregate of $655 million.

headline: West Offers New Way to East
abstract: LEAD: Western Europe's Christian Democratic parties are trying to woo East bloc countries toward a form of capitalism that emphasizes Christian social values. Page A11.

headline: Reunification With West Spurs Uncertainty in East German Industry
abstract: LEAD: Ask Gunter Rhinow what will happen to his company, job and life when the two German economies merge and his answer rings of the uncertainty that grips all levels of East German society.

headline: A Guilty Plea by Emerson
abstract: LEAD: The Emerson Electric Company pleaded guilty today to making inflated cost estimates for electronic equipment it sold the Pentagon and agreed to pay a $40,000 fine and a $14 million civil settlement, the Justice Department said.

headline: Memorial Service
abstract: LEAD: A memorial service for the advertising copywriter John Caples will be held at 10:30 A.M. Friday at the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration (Little Church Around the Corner) at 1 East 29th Street in Manhattan. Mr. Caples died June 10 at the age of 90.

headline: COMPUTER PROJECT WOULD SPEED DATA
abstract: LEAD: A group of private companies, universities, research laboratories and Government agencies is planning to develop an advanced computer network in which data would be transmitted at speeds 700 times faster than possible now. The plan is to be announced today by the National Science Foundation. It would be the first comprehensive effort in the United States to advance the technologically critical area of computer networks and is being called an important model for cooperation between business and government.

headline: Plan for New Yugoslav Party
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Ante Markovic of Yugoslavia said on Friday that he and his Government planned to form a party separate from the ruling Communists to compete in a free general election expected later this year. Mr. Markovic, a Communist who advocates Western-style economic and political systems, is considered the person most capable of uniting Yugoslavia's ethnic groups under one banner.

headline: City's Heart, in Ashes Now, to Beat as It Did of Old
abstract: LEAD: With a plaintive ''Please visit us,'' a hand-painted sign on a burned-out building in the Chiado district here announces that after 100 years at that site, the Martins & Costa store has moved to a temporary address more than a mile away.

headline: Mexico Vote On Banks
abstract: LEAD: Mexico's Chamber of Deputies has approved a constitutional amendment to allow private ownership of banks, eight years after they were nationalized.

headline: Cookie Maker In Taiwan Sale
abstract: LEAD: The nation's third-largest cookie company, Wyndham Foods Inc., has been sold to a huge Taiwan company for $335 million.

headline: Y.&R. Makes A Hollywood Comeback
abstract: LEAD: YOUNG & RUBICAM re-entered the business of movie marketing yesterday with its appointment to plan and buy newspaper, radio and local television advertising for the 20th Century Fox Film Corporation. The studio spends about $45 million a year on local media.

headline: Your Money;   Burden of Loads On Mutual Funds
abstract: LEAD: Loads, as mutual fund fees are known, are aptly named. They can certainly weigh down a fund's return to shareholders.

headline: C.D. and Bank Fund Yields Are Mostly Down for Week
abstract: LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts were mostly down for the week ended yesterday.

headline: Mutual Funds;   Bracing for Tougher Times
abstract: LEAD: Once upon a time - more than 120 years ago - a small East Texas river town called Jefferson was thriving as steamships carried cotton and timber down the Red River to the Mississippi and thence to New Orleans. Then one day, the railroad magnate Jay Gould (no relation to this writer) came to Jefferson.

headline: Thatcher Said to Weigh Changes in Disputed Tax
abstract: LEAD: The British press reported today that the Government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher was considering major changes in an unpopular new Government tax.

headline: Car Bombs Kill at Least 19 In 2 Bogota Shopping Malls
abstract: LEAD: Car bombs today ripped through two malls packed with last-minute Mother's Day shoppers here, killing at least 19 people and injuring 143, the Health Ministry said.

headline: U.S. and Soviets Agree to Resume Ocean Traffic
abstract: LEAD: At the summit meeting, President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will sign a new shipping agreement that will open up 42 ports in each country to ships flying the other nation's flag, restoring widespread ocean traffic between the two countries for the first time since 1981.

headline: Move by Pilots At Eastern
abstract: LEAD: The leaders of the pilots' union at Eastern Airlines said yesterday that they would not take any action against the 600 union pilots who crossed picket lines after Aug. 6 of last year, months before the union called off its strike.

headline: Japan Trade Pact Brings Skepticism in Congress
abstract: LEAD: In the first public exchange between the Bush Administration and Congress over a new trade agreement with Japan, lawmakers voiced skepticism today about Tokyo's commitments and the extent to which the accord would help American exports.

headline: Liberia and Rebels Discuss A Cease-Fire, Mediator Says
abstract: LEAD: Talks to end Liberia's six-month rebellion adjourned today with little sign of progress as both sides appeared to hold firm to their demands.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Sluggish Period For Magazines
abstract: LEAD: Magazine advertising revenues rose only 1.54 percent, to $1.48 billion, in the first quarter of 1990 from the comparable period of 1989, according to the Publishers Information Bureau. Advertising pages fell 3.47 percent, to 39,339.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   NEGOTIATORS FIX CURBS ON ARMIES
abstract: LEAD: NATO and Warsaw Pact negotiators agreed today on definitions and limits for tanks and other armored combat vehicles, renewing hopes that a treaty on conventional arms in Europe could still be signed this year, diplomats here said.

headline: Microsoft Planning Bigger Work Force
abstract: LEAD: The Microsoft Corporation, the large independent software manufacturer, will increase its work force by more than 50 percent in the next year, a company official said. Employment of 5,200 will expand to about 8,000 by the end of June 1991, said Frank Gaudette, chief financial officer for the company, based in Redmond,

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Insulting Gorbachev Now Illegal, But It All Depends on the Tone
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Parliament enacted a law today that makes insulting the Soviet President a crime punishable by a prison term, but only if the insults are expressed ''in an indecent way'' - a legal turn of phrase that won support even from civil libertarians.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: LEAD:    In millions of barrels except refinery utilization            May 25   May 18   May 26       1990   1990   1989        Gasoline production, daily   6.9   6.6   7.1        Distillate production, daily   2.8   2.7   2.7        Gasoline stocks   214.2   213.2   221.7        Distillate stocks   100.0   99.2   95.3        Crude imports, daily   6.8   6.0   6.3        Product imports, daily   2.5   1.7   2.5        Crude stocks   381.8   379.7   341.3        Crude production, daily   7.2   7.2   7.8        Refinery utilization (%)   88.4   85.0   88.6

headline: Foe of Castro, Party of One, Is Fighting On
abstract: LEAD: Slight of build, his face framed by flowing hair and a beard, Roberto Luque Escalona seems a man whose greatest passions are chain smoking filterless cigarettes and reconstructing, if for now only in his mind, Cuban society.

headline: ON G.E. AND EATING OUR SEED CORN
abstract: LEAD: An article May 13 (''Are We Eating Our Seed Corn?'') discussed the extent to which many large American corporations, and the General Electric Company in particular, are buying back their stock and thus spending less on research and development and missing opportunities to develop innovative products.

headline: Auto Wiper Claim Limited
abstract: LEAD: The Ford Motor Company did not intentionally infringe on an inventor's patent rights to his intermittent windshield wiper, a Federal jury decided today.

headline: U.S. and Mexico Take Aim at Drug Chemicals
abstract: LEAD: Spurred by a new American law aimed at crippling the ability of drug cartels to manufacture narcotics, the United States and Mexico are stepping up efforts to prevent thousands of tons of American-made chemicals needed to produce cocaine, heroin and other illegal drugs from flowing into Mexico.

headline: Prices of Long-Term U.S. Bonds Ease
abstract: LEAD: Prices of long-term Government securities eased yesterday, but the market in shorter Treasury maturities was essentially unchanged in unusually lackluster trading. One reason was the absence of any significant economic news.

headline: LITHUANIANS OFFER NEW COMPROMISES TO AVOID BLOCKADE
abstract: LEAD: Lithuania is prepared to compromise on some of the independence measures that drove Moscow to threaten severe economic sanctions against the republic, the Lithuanian Prime Minister said today.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Saatchi Selling Peterson Unit
abstract: LEAD: Continuing to divest itself of its consulting businesses, the Saatchi & Saatchi Company P.L.C. agreed yesterday to sell Peterson & Company, Chicago, to its management.

headline: LEADER OF LIBERIA REFUSING TO QUIT
abstract: LEAD: With rebel columns bearing down on the capital, a group of prominent Liberian religious leaders has urged President Samuel K. Doe to resign and create a transitional Government. But Mr. Doe rejected the demand with a scornful tirade, several participants in the meeting said today.

headline: Cuba Seeking 10 to 12 Years For 7 Accused of Conspiracy
abstract: LEAD: Cuba's state prosecutor is seeking prison terms of 10 to 12 years for seven dissidents accused of conspiracy and rebellion against the Government, official news organizations reported today.

headline: Pathe Deal For MGM Extended
abstract: LEAD: Giancarlo Parretti, the Italian financier whose attempt to acquire the MGM/ UA Communications Company has been on the brink of collapse in recent days, said today that he had reached an agreement with MGM that will give him four more months to come up with the cash he needs to complete the deal.

headline: Mortgage Rates Up
abstract: LEAD: Fixed-rate home mortgages are averaging 10.16 percent, up slightly from 10.12 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.50 percent this week, up from 8.44 percent the week before.

headline: Real Estate;   Japanese Help Fill Trade Center
abstract: LEAD: ''THANK heavens for the Japanese!'' George Rossi exclaimed. They are making the office leasing numbers look respectable at the World Trade Center.

headline: Justice Agency Warned on Inquiry of Loans to Iraq
abstract: LEAD: State Department officials say they have cautioned the Justice Department over the agency's investigation of the Atlanta branch of an Italian bank accused of making more than $2 billion in unauthorized and unreported loans to Iraq.

headline: Simon Group Gets Aid For Savings Institution
abstract: LEAD: A group headed by William E. Simon, the former Treasury Secretary, said today that it had raised $50 million from a private investor to bolster the financial strength of one of its savings institutions.

headline: Soviet-South Korean Summit
abstract: LEAD: President Gorbachev plans to meet President Roh Tae Woo in San Francisco, the first such meeting between the countries, which have been adversaries for 40 years. Page A14.

headline: Panel to Seek Milken Testimony Under Immunity
abstract: LEAD: A House subcomittee has decided to offer the ''junk bond'' financier Michael R. Milken, who admitted he illegally manipulated financial markets, immunity from prosecution so that he will testify before Congress, a panel staff member said today.

headline: Technology Official Quits At Pentagon
abstract: LEAD: The director of the Defense Department program that monitors the advanced technologies of America's foremost economic competitors has resigned, saying he has become frustrated by the Bush Administration's refusal to support plans to assist the nation's high-technology industries.

headline: An Insider Conviction Is Overturned on Appeal
abstract: LEAD: A Federal appeals court yesterday overturned the conviction of a stockbroker who had been charged with trading on non-public information, saying it amounted to little more than gossip.

headline: Kirghizia; At A Glance
abstract: LEAD:    The People

headline: Baker Warns Shevardnadze Against Clamp on Lithuania
abstract: LEAD: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d cautioned Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union today that a crackdown in Lithuania could wipe out much of the progress made in Soviet-American relations in the last year.

headline: Western Union Stock-Sale Step
abstract: LEAD: The ITT Corporation and a group of 31 banks have registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell 22 million common shares of the Western Union Corporation.

headline: As in Art, Quality Sells
abstract: LEAD: In art as in stocks, the action is in the quality end of the spectrum, but the rest of the market seems to be alive as well.

headline: Soviet Oil Strike Delayed
abstract: LEAD: Workers in the Soviet Union's largest oil field have postponed until late April a planned strike over living conditions and improvements to the industry, a trade union leader said today. The leader, Nikolai Trifonov, who represents 700,000 oil workers in Tyumen, western Siberia, said his union had decided not to begin the strike on Sunday although they had not yet received a government response to their demands.

headline: Soviets Are Dismantling Big Asia Radar Station
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union has begun to dismantle its huge radar station at Krasnoyarsk, which the United States has long said was a violation of the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty, a Bush Administration official said tonight.

headline: Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week
abstract: LEAD: Treasury financings this week will be limited to the bill market beginning with today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of new one-year bills on Thursday.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Cedar Group, Philadelphia, a distributor of fasteners, said it would acquire Gardenbolt International Corp., Sayreville, N.J., an importer of fasteners, for $7 million.

headline: Burmese Vote Today, or Do They?
abstract: LEAD: The people of Myanmar, formerly Burma, vote on Sunday in the first multiparty election in almost 30 years, but Western diplomats based there and human-rights organizations say that the voting will not be free or fair and that the military will continue to rule.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Baker Has New Arms Deal For Moscow, Officials Say
abstract: LEAD: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d has taken new ideas for reducing conventional forces in Europe to Moscow, in an attempt to accommodate the Soviet position on a number of issues that have slowed completion of a treaty, American and Western diplomats said today.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   A Times Ad Director
abstract: LEAD: Charles T. Coyle has been named advertising director of The New York Times Magazine. Mr. Coyle will be responsible for advertising at The New York Times Magazine and the Magazine Part 2's.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD: * Linda C. Seale has joined Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising as executive vice president and human resources director for North America. Perry Davis, the agency's director of technology management, has been appointed a senior vice president.

headline: Lincoln Deal Is Questioned
abstract: LEAD: Government lawyers charged today that Charles H. Keating Jr., chairman of the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, had used $13 million in federally insured deposits to buy loans from the Saudi European Bank in exchange for a $3.75 million loan for Lincoln's parent, the American Continental Corporation.

headline: A U.S. Venture Capitalist With $240 Million for Poles
abstract: LEAD: For entrepreneurs in Poland, Robert G. Faris is a man who may help to make dreams come true. The venture capitalist has been named president and chief executive of the Polish American Enterprise Fund, and will be in charge of handing out American dollars to promote free enterprise in Poland.

headline: Dressmaker, Make Me a . . . Tie
abstract: LEAD: Some of the hottest-selling ties in the United States right now were created by a women's clothing maker that backed into what has become a $2 million business after deciding there had to be a way to use some leftover dress fabrics. And after circumstances both fortuitous and fortunate, the company, Nicole Miller

headline: BESIEGED AT HOME, GORBACHEV ARRIVES IN U.S. FOR SUMMIT
abstract: LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union arrived in Washington tonight for his third visit to the United States and his second summit conference with President Bush, as American officials searched for formulas to persuade him to accept Western plans for a unified Germany and a restructured Europe.

headline: Dataproducts Agrees to Sale
abstract: LEAD: After 16 months of negotiations, the Dataproducts Corporation agreed today to be acquired by a joint venture of two Japanese companies for $10 a share, or about $160 million.      The buyers are the Hitachi

headline: Kampala Journal;   The Land Amin Seized Now Preoccupies Uganda
abstract: LEAD: For sale or repossession: $1 billion worth of commercial buildings, tea and coffee plantations, residences.

headline: Fund Yields Rise Slightly
abstract: LEAD: Yields of tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were narrowly higher in the week that ended yesterday. Over all, the fixed-income market was flat, with some corrections in longer maturities, while the shorter maturities that are more closely tied to Federal

headline: Guatemala President Stars in Political Drama
abstract: LEAD: This country's most avidly watched drama features a dashing executive, a coterie of young women and a cabal of high-living friends whose reputations make J. R. Ewing look like a choirboy.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD: * Robert C. Erwin has been appointed senior vice president and director of client services at Robert A. Becker Inc., a health care communications subsidiary of Eurocom WCRS Della Femina Ball.

headline: Market Place;  Apparel Stocks Suffer for Fashion
abstract: LEAD: THIS summer, L.A. Gear Inc. will introduce its much-anticipated line of Michael Jackson athletic shoes, and analysts are already trying to assess whether the new line will top the sales charts as Mr. Jackson's recordings do or will flop.

headline: Lebanese Christians Ravaged, Now by Lebanese Christians
abstract: LEAD: The Christians of Lebanon, once the country's unchallenged and affluent rulers, are now a minority bleeding to death under civil war. Since the end of January, fighting for control of the country's 300-square-mile Christian enclave has killed more than 900 people, wounded 3,000 and forced about 300,000 to flee abroad.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:    Debt

headline: Cullinan Journal;   At Woodstock on the Veld, Rock Blasts Apartheid
abstract: LEAD: Joos Tinderbox and the Squabblers stepped up to the microphones and blasted a plea for amiable anarchy through a wall of amplifiers to some 10,000 young Afrikaners who had trekked to a dusty farm 20 miles northeast of South Africa's seat of Government in Pretoria.       As soon as you lie drooling on your cot,    Ideologies come howling like wolves.

headline: Mugabe Wins Decisively in Zimbabwe Voting
abstract: LEAD: President Robert Mugabe and his governing party decisively won the national election this weekend, apparently placing the nation firmly on the path to a one-party state.

headline: 3 Killed in Madagascar in Attempted Coup
abstract: LEAD: Rebels saying they wanted to end 15 years of dictatorship seized the Madagascar radio early today, but the Government quickly regained control after the coup attempt failed to obtain public support.

headline: Treasury Prices Rise in Slow Day
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved marginally higher in very sluggish trading yesterday, as dealers moved to the sidelines in advance of March employment data on Friday.

headline: Security Pacific's Net Increases 5%
abstract: LEAD: The Security Pacific Corporation, the nation's fourth-largest banking company, reported today that first-quarter earnings increased 5 percent, to $188.4 million, from $179.3 million in the period a year earlier.

headline: The 17 Westerners Left Behind in Captivity
abstract: LEAD: With the release yesterday of Robert Polhill, 17 Westerners, including 7 Americans, are missing in Lebanon and believed held by kidnappers.       The Americans       Terry A. Anderson, 42 years old, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, kidnapped March 16, 1985.    Thomas M. Sutherland, 58, acting dean of agriculture at the American University of Beirut, abducted June 9, 1985.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Kremlin Orders Special Flights For Mecca Trips
abstract: LEAD: After decades of severely restricting the number of Muslims allowed to visit Mecca, the Soviet Union announced today that it would charter special direct flights to Saudi Arabia for the pilgrimage this year. Muslim leaders said thousands of people had applied to go.  President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, whose administration has seemed alarmed by the revival of Islam in the country's southern republics, ''has instructed the Ministry of Civil Aviation to organize special Aeroflot flights during this period'' from Moscow and other cities with large Muslim populations, Mr.

headline: H & R Block in Buyback
abstract: LEAD: H & R Block Inc. said today that it intended to purchase from time to time up to 1.5 million of its 53.6 million common shares outstanding. The shares are expected to be used for employee stock ownership plans, the company said.

headline: How Gorbachev Rejected Plan To 'Shock Treat' the Economy
abstract: LEAD: In the middle of March, about 60 economists and lawyers began convening each day at a Government country house in the pine woods outside Moscow. Their assignment was to draft laws and decrees that would transform the lethargic, state-planned Soviet economy into a free market, and do it quickly.

headline: Looking for Moviegoers In a Magazine
abstract: LEAD: TO hear some Hollywood studio executives tell it, moviegoers absolutely loathe watching commercials before the main attraction.

headline: Mutual Funds;   How to Pick a Newsletter
abstract: LEAD: Dan F. Sullivan, who edits The Chartist Mutual Fund Timer newsletter, invests his own money in the funds he recommends to subscribers - and sends out his brokerage statements to prove it.

headline: Victories, and Reality
abstract: LEAD: The United States and the Soviet Union said they would work together to avert a famine in Ethiopia and bring an end to the war. Page A13.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, APRIL 21, 1990
abstract: LEAD:          The Economy

headline: Sales of U.S.-Made Autos Down 6% in May
abstract: LEAD: Sales of domestically produced cars fell 6 percent in May, as seven months of sluggish consumer demand showed a faint sign of revival during the last 10 days of the month. Sales of domestically produced light trucks rose nine-tenths of 1 percent for the 10-day period.

headline: The New Entrepreneurs
abstract: LEAD: The increasingly insecure corporate environment has led more executives who have been dismissed from their jobs to strike out on their own instead of looking for another corporate position, a study said last week. One of five managers dismissed in the first quarter chose to become an entrepreneur, four times the rate five years ago, according to the survey of 600 former executives by Challenger, Gray & Christmas Inc., an employment consulting firm.

headline: Business and the Law;   Biden's Challenge To Federal Courts
abstract: LEAD: ''THE real problem here is that Federal judges have lifetime tenure,'' said a senior Judiciary Committee aide last week, lamenting Article III of the Constitution. ''That would make it difficult to make judges accountable and force them to follow the Biden Act.''

headline: Market Place;  Masco Industries' Outlook Brightens
abstract: LEAD: A RETURN to more normal levels of automotive production and a first-quarter profit -in contrast to the loss that some analysts expected - have touched off a 41 percent increase in the share price of Masco Industries in the last four weeks.

headline: Apple Changing Software Setup
abstract: LEAD: The Claris Corporation, the software operation of Apple Computer Inc., will become a wholly owned independent subsidiary of the personal computer maker, Apple's chairman, John Sculley, announced. Claris, which develops and markets software for Apple's popular Macintosh and Apple II computers, has been a majority-owned subsidiary of Apple since April 1987, when Apple spun off its applications-software operations to form

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Graf Bertel Dominique
abstract: LEAD: Graf Bertel Dominique has resigned the advertising account of Paul Stuart Inc., after handling the Madison Avenue clothier for just several weeks. The agency said it had resigned the $2 million account because of creative differences.

headline: Difficulties in Real Estate Extend Even to Minneapolis
abstract: LEAD: Even as the Trammell Crow Company solves some of its problems in the Southwest, it is struggling in a metropolitan area not widely associated with real estate troubles. The difficulties of the nation's largest developer here are one more indication of the extent of the national real estate slump.

headline: France Regains Economic Strength
abstract: LEAD: Although German reunification worries many Frenchmen, its approach has been welcome news for the Paris Bourse and for France's economy in general.

headline: Faction Presses Campbell's Sale
abstract: LEAD: A dissident faction of the family that owns much of the Campbell Soup Company's stock said it would continue to press for the company's sale. The faction representing about 17.4 percent of Cambell's shares, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had formed a trust to make it easier to act together and communicate with

headline: Summit in Washington;   Gorbachevs' Trip: Today's Schedule
abstract: LEAD:    9:30 A.M.:  President and Mrs. Bush and president and Mrs. Gorbachev leave by helecopter for Camp David from the White House South Lawn       10 A.M.:  The Gorbachevs and the Bushes arrive at Camp David for Leisure time and informal talks.       5 P.M.:  Marlin Fitzwater, Mr. Bush's Spokesman, and Arkady A.

headline: Year Later, Chinese Father Grieves and Fears
abstract: LEAD: A year after soldiers shot dead his only son, the father's own odyssey through faith, heartbreak, bitterness and disillusionment with the Chinese Communist Party still leaves him confused and fearful.

abstract: LEAD:               New Orders for Durable Goods    April    March    Feb.
