headline: The Mandela Visit;   Mandela Sees Links to de Klerk
abstract: LEAD: Nelson Mandela appears to have held out the possibility of a political alliance between his African National Congress and President F. W. de Klerk's National Party in South Africa, if Mr. de Klerk can extend voting rights to the black majority.

headline: Investor Raises Stake in Ecogen
abstract: LEAD: Ecogen Inc., a maker of biological pesticides, said the New York investor David Blech had signed a letter of intent to increase his investment in the company by $6.5 million, raising his stake to 36 percent, from 9 percent. The company said that as a result of Mr. Blech's new investment, it was no longer seeking a buyer.

headline: Bored by Annual Reports? Try Time Warner's
abstract: LEAD: Wall Street, meet MTV.

headline: SmithKline Is Selling 2 Units to Germans
abstract: LEAD: SmithKline Beecham P.L.C., the giant pharmaceutical company, said today that it would sell two of its cosmetics businesses to a West German company for $358 million.

headline: Pessimism on Chinese Trade
abstract: LEAD: Ever since they sailed their clipper ships to China two centuries ago with cargoes of opium, foreign traders have brimmed with optimism about the potential of the vast China market. These days, however, on the first anniversary of the bloody suppression of the democracy movement, the flush of optimism is gone, along with much of the business.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Wizard of The Mailbox Is Honored
abstract: LEAD: YESTERDAY was gray and rainy in New York. It was a day for people to stay home and read their mail and pay their bills. It was, in short, the kind of day that direct marketers love.

headline: Texts of Gorbachev's Statements to Lithuanians
abstract: LEAD: Following are the texts of statements made yesterday by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union to the Lithuanian people and to the Lithuanian Parliament. The statements, as distributed in translation by Tass, the official Soviet press agency, were read by announcers on Radio Moscow and on the Soviet television.

headline: Rapid Moves to German Unity Vex Soviets
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union has spelled out concerns about German unification in an unofficial note to the new East German Prime Minister, Lothar de Maiziere, a Government spokesman said today.

headline: A Heavy Shadow Is Lifted, and Venice Sighs
abstract: LEAD: Along the Grand Canal and the latticework of alleys that it snakes past, there were relieved sighs today as Venetians learned that they had been saved from a world's fair that many feared would sink their fragile city beneath crushing new waves of tourism.

headline: Moynihan Rebuffed on Captives
abstract: LEAD: Israel has rejected calls by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan for the unconditional release of hundreds of Shiite Muslim prisoners in southern Lebanon as a good-will gesture to Iran for the recent release of two American hostages.

headline: Wasserstein, Perella To Acquire Maybelline
abstract: LEAD: Wasserstein, Perella Partners L.P. said today that it would buy the Maybelline Company for $300 million, after a deal for the beauty-products concern collapsed.

headline: Currency;   Ending the Week on an Up Note
abstract: LEAD: It was an up week, but just a little, for the dollar. After falling against the Japanese yen in the beginning of the week, the dollar inched back Thursday and Friday. It also rose those two days against other major currencies, except for the British pound. It is not clear if the rally is just a correction after the sharp drop of the week before or rather the start of a new trend.

headline: Simmons Ends Bid For Georgia Gulf
abstract: LEAD: The Dallas investor Harold C. Simmons has ended his $1.1 billion tender offer for the Georgia Gulf Corporation, deciding instead to back the chemical company's recapitalization plan at the April 19 annual meeting. But Mr. Simmons's NL Industries, which owns almost 10 percent of Georgia Gulf, left open the possibility of another tender offer if shareholders reject the plan.

headline: Summit in Washington;   Chevron and Soviets to Work Toward Oil Venture
abstract: LEAD: The Chevron Corporation signed an agreement today that could open the way for a major expansion of its commercial activities in the Soviet Union.

headline: Former Trader Settles Case
abstract: LEAD: A former trader at Marcus Schloss & Company, a New York Stock Exchange specialist firm, has settled Government charges that he traded inside information about possible corporate takeovers, the Securities and Exchange Commission said on Tuesday.

headline: Caterpillar Expects Profits to Plunge
abstract: LEAD: Caterpillar Inc., the world's largest maker of earth-moving equipment, said today that it expected earnings to plunge because of poor results at its Brazilian unit and high costs from its revamping program and its upgrading of factories.

headline: Senator to Finance Panel
abstract: LEAD: Senator John Breaux, a Louisiana Democrat, was chosen on Wednesday to succeed the late Senator Spark M. Matsunaga of Hawaii on the Senate Finance Committee. The panel has jurisdiction over taxes, trade, Social Security and half of Government spending.

headline: Ex-Nazi Is Sent to Germany In Extradition by Argentina
abstract: LEAD: Josef Schwammberger was returned to West Germany today, the first known Nazi war criminal to be extradited from Argentina.

headline: McDonnell Plans Additional Layoffs
abstract: LEAD: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation, plagued by operational trouble at its Douglas Aircraft subsidiary, raised the number of layoffs planned this summer to 4,000, from 3,000, the company said. The layoffs will be centered at the Douglas Aircraft plant in Long Beach, Calif.

headline: Contel to Offer 900 Early Retirement
abstract: LEAD: The Contel Corporation said it was offering early retirement to about 900 employees in a previously announced cost-cutting program. The company said it was using the program to avoid layoffs while reducing its work force. Under the plan, a retirement ''window'' will be created in July, during which retiring employees will have three years added each to their ages and to their service dates in determining individual benefits.

headline: Recreation Properties To Be Sold
abstract: LEAD: Some of the country's best-known golf resorts and developed communities will be put up for sale this week by the Landmark Land Company.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Canadian Pacific Ltd., Montreal, a holding company for real estate, transportation, telecommunications and manufacturing interests, said it would not proceed with its plan to distribute 80 percent of its subsidiary Marathon Realty Co. to its common share holders.

headline: 3d Hispanic Network Seeks Viewers
abstract: LEAD: The competition is heating up in the Hispanic television market. Galavision, the newest entrant, is threatening to steal viewers and advertising from Univision and Telemundo, the two struggling Spanish-language television networks.

headline: Treasuries Fall in Light Trading
abstract: LEAD: Treasury security prices inched lower again yesterday, in business so slow that dealers said the decline was virtually meaningless.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD: International

headline: Dow Up By 49.57 To a High
abstract: LEAD: Taking most traders by surprise, both the Dow Jones industrial average and the broader Standard & Poor's 500 stock index rebounded sharply yesterday to set new highs.

headline: Civvies for the American Military Economy?
abstract: LEAD: As the cold war fades into history, policy makers are beginning work on trimming the military budget. But how easily can companies that serve the military convert their operations to civilian use? Seymour Melman, professor emeritus of industrial engineering at Columbia University and chairman of the National Commission for Economic Conversion and Disarmament, and Lawrence Klein, Benjamin Franklin Professor of Economics at the University of Pennsylvania and a Nobel laureate, discussed the economic consequences of smaller military budgets with Joel Kurtzman of The New York Times.

headline: A Bonanza For Trump Shuttle Users
abstract: LEAD: For many travelers on the Northeast's air shuttles, clouds now do have a silver lining.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: LEAD:    General Assembly       AD HOC COMMITTEE ON THE INDIAN OCEAN - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.       PREPARATORY COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE FOR SPECIAL SESSION ON INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC COOPERATION - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.       SPECIAL COMMITTEE OF 24 - SUBCOMMITTEE ON SMALL TERRITORIES - 3 P.M.       Economic and Social Council

headline: Currency;   The Dollar Keeps to a Steady Course
abstract: LEAD: The dollar was generally steady last week against both the West German mark and the Japanese yen. It closed the week at 1.6980 marks to the dollar, down slightly from the 1.7005 at which it began; it was also down slightly against the yen, ending the week at 153.50, down from 152.40 at the start. Although the dollar pushed slightly above the 1.70 marks point, the trading range was narrow and the market lacked the momentum to sustain a big advance.

headline: Coalition Rule Seems a Safe Guess in Bulgaria
abstract: LEAD: Ten weeks before this country holds its first free elections in more than four decades, the outcome is a tossup. But whichever party comes out on top, Bulgaria's next government will be formed by a coalition.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:    Debt

headline: Advertising;   Sara Lee Gives Lintas A $100 Million-Plus Job
abstract: LEAD: A week after it was stunned by the loss of the $45 million Eastern Airlines account to Ogilvy & Mather, Lintas USA received cheering news from the Sara Lee Corporation, which consolidated most of its domestic food advertising accounts with Lintas yesterday.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   2 Baltic Republics Appeal To Yeltsin for Cooperation
abstract: LEAD: In a dramatic display of solidarity between the Soviet Union's rebellious republics, official representatives from Lithuania and Estonia met today with Boris N. Yeltsin, the newly elected president of the Russian republic, to discuss cooperation.

headline: Former GTE Officer Is Chief of Telecharge
abstract: LEAD: International Telecharge Inc., which specializes in operator-assisted long-distance phone services, has named Allan L. Rayfield, a former top executive at the GTE Corporation, to the posts of chairman and chief executive.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   U.S.-Japan Partnership Wins a Job
abstract: LEAD: IN an unusual cross-cultural pairing of agencies, NEC Technologies Inc. has awarded the advertising assignment for an innovative video game to a joint venture formed by TBWA Advertising and Hakuhodo Advertising America.

headline: Taiwan's New President Signals Major Softening in Relations With China
abstract: LEAD: President Lee Teng-hui said today that he would soon revoke his Government's 40-year-old declaration of a ''Communist rebellion'' on the Chinese mainland, and would immediately restore the civil rights of nearly 30 dissidents, including 2 of the Government's most prominent opponents.

headline: ON G.E. AND EATING OUR SEED CORN
abstract: LEAD: An article May 13 (''Are We Eating Our Seed Corn?'') discussed the extent to which many large American corporations, and the General Electric Company in particular, are buying back their stock and thus spending less on research and development and missing opportunities to develop innovative products.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Action on Romania Protest
abstract: LEAD: A parliamentary chamber today gave the police and soldiers the authority to clear anti-Government protesters from a square where they have reassembled since violence last week.

headline: Gunmen Fire at Officials in Haiti In Pre-election Surge of Violence
abstract: LEAD: Gunmen opened fire this morning at a hotel where the governing Council of State was meeting to discuss a wave of pre-election violence, killing one man and critically wounding two others.

headline: Interco Posts Quarterly Loss
abstract: LEAD: Interco Inc., the maker of Converse footwear and Broyhill furniture, today reported a $23.3 million loss for the fourth quarter and a 50 percent drop in profits for the year.

headline: German Coalition Leaders Split on Soviet Proposal for Unification
abstract: LEAD: Chancellor Helmut Kohl today rejected the notion suggested by Moscow that the Germans could accept unification before all the implications for other countries are worked out.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Europeans Meeting Today on Unity
abstract: LEAD: When they gather in Dublin on Monday to discuss European political and economic union, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's 11 European Community colleagues will find her ready to talk, but as skeptical as ever about both ideas.

headline: UAL's Finance Chief Leaving the Company
abstract: LEAD: John C. Pope said yesterday that he was resigning as executive vice president, chief financial officer and treasurer of the UAL Corporation, parent of United Airlines, the nation's second-largest carrier. No successor has been named.  Mr. Pope is expected to leave upon the completion of an employee-led buyout of the company, for about $200 a share, or $4.4 billion.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Age Hasn't Mellowed This Agency
abstract: LEAD: CONTROVERSIAL advertising campaigns are typically the province of young, upstart agencies trying to distinguish themselves in the cluttered precincts of Madison Avenue. The brash ''. . . And she drinks Johnnie Walker'' campaign, whose slice-of-life dialogues have managed to outrage feminists and intrigue gay organizations, may be the older folks' revenge.

headline: Cambodia Talks Quickly Collapse With Boycott by the Khmer Rouge
abstract: LEAD: A new round of talks on Cambodia lasted only 25 minutes today after the Khmer Rouge guerrillas complained about their representation here and boycotted the session.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Richmond Playing Host To Tobacco Exhibition
abstract: LEAD: Richmond, once a capital of the American tobacco industry, is the site of an exhibition entitled ''Smoke Signals: Cigarettes, Advertising and the American Way of Life.''

headline: A Sugar Quota For Nicaragua
abstract: LEAD: The United States said Tuesday that it planned to restore preferential treatment for Nicaraguan exports, including a quota for sugar exports to the United States.

headline: Trump Shuttle To Cut Flights
abstract: LEAD: Starting July 1, the Trump shuttle will cancel six of its hourly flights on weekends because they do not generate the traffic that would cover the cost of operating them, Bruce Nobles, the head of the Trump shuttle, said yesterday.      He said that on Saturdays the

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:    MARKETS       Both the Dow and the S.&P. 500 stock index rose sharply to set new highs. The Dow closed at 2,870.49, up 49.57, or 1.8 percent. The S.& P. 500 rose 6.07, to a record 360.65, breaking the former record of 359.80 set Oct. 9, 1989. [Page D1.]      Prices of Treasury securities moved higher in light trading as some strength in the dollar and a drop in commodity prices gave investors reasons to buy notes and bonds.

headline: Blinder, Robinson Chief Barred by S.E.C. Judge
abstract: LEAD: An administrative law judge today barred Meyer Blinder from the securities business for life, although Mr. Blinder, the head of the nation's best-known penny stock brokerage, can appeal the ban in two years.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:    Debt

headline: In Kashmir Valley, Alienation Turns Deadly
abstract: LEAD: Silent, barefoot men dug a very small grave recently at the Idgar Martyrs' Cemetery, a new landmark on the outskirts of this battered city. The grave was for 6-year-old Sajad Ahmad Sofi, shot by Indian troops, his relatives said, as he tried to hide between his father's legs during a search of the family home.

headline: Owner of Exco Seeking Bidders
abstract: LEAD: British and Commonwealth Holdings P.L.C. said it was seeking buyers for its Exco International P.L.C. subsidiary. Exco is a financial services firm specializing in wholesale markets, including money brokering and stock lending. The sale is part of British and Commonwealth's plan to raise $:750 million, or $12.6 million, by selling assets.

headline: G.M. Units Had Mixed First Period
abstract: LEAD: Military spending cuts and a sharp drop in demand for automotive components reduced first-quarter profits by 15.8 percent for the GM Hughes Electronics Corporation, the military and electronics subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation's said today.

headline: Paper Couldn't Crack Tough St. Louis Market
abstract: LEAD: Skeptics and fans of the publisher Ralph Ingersoll 2d agreed on one thing when The St. Louis Sun made its debut seven months ago: the start-up of the project would require deep pockets and patience. But last week, Mr. Ingersoll decided that neither would be enough. Wednesday's issue was The Sun's last.

headline: Tunnel Train Plan Is Stalled
abstract: LEAD: The British Government has said it will not provide any public money for a proposed multibillion-dollar high-speed rail link between London and the English entrance to the channel tunnel at Folkestone.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Font & Vaamonde
abstract: LEAD: As part of a reorganization, Font & Vaamonde, a Hispanic advertising subsidiary of Grey Advertising, named Luis Weksler general manager of its Northern and Southern divisions, and Rochelle Newman general manager of its Western division. Font & Vaamonde also named Mauricio Vives general manager of its New York office; Susan Nassberg general manager of its Los Angeles office and Marlena Delgado general manager of its Miami office.

headline: Tepid Outlook Cools Once-Hot L.A. Gear
abstract: LEAD: The stock of L.A. Gear Inc., the footwear and apparel maker that has undergone explosive growth since it went public three years ago, plummeted yesterday after the company said it expected sharply lower second-quarter earnings.

headline: Market Place;   A Plan to Limit Insurers' 'Junk'
abstract: LEAD: A GROUP of state regulators plans to issue new rules that may limit insurance companies' holdings of the high-risk, high-yield securities known as ''junk bonds.''

headline: Soviets Promise to Pull Back Some Tactical Nuclear Arms
abstract: LEAD: Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze announced today that the Soviet Union would withdraw a small number of its short-range nuclear weapons from Central Europe.

headline: Marion Merrell Stock
abstract: LEAD: The Dow Chemical Company said on Thursday that it would purchase an additional four million shares of Marion Merrell Dow Inc. stock. Dow currently owns 186.3 million shares of Marion Merrell Dow. At the end of the year there were 278.3 million shares outstanding. The stock will be bought either on the open market or in private transactions, the company said.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: LEAD:    General Assembly       AD HOC COMMITTEE OF SPECIAL SESSION -10 A.M.    SPECIAL COMMITTEE ON PEACEKEEPING OPERATIONS - 3 P.M.

headline: Chrysler-Renault Project Is Ended
abstract: LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation, which has lost several top executives in recent weeks, suffered another big disappointment today as an international joint venture with Renault, the French auto maker, fell apart.

headline: In Thatched Roofs of Argentine Poor, an Insect That Saps Health of Millions
abstract: LEAD: Ruben Juarez, a Government sanitary agent, stopped at the thatched-roof home of Luisa Chavez, opened two simple cardboard devices hanging on the bedroom walls and found what he feared.

headline: Vernon Figure Pleads Innocent
abstract: LEAD: The former owner of the Vernon Savings and Loan Association, Don Dixon, who is accused of illegally trying to raise money for former House Speaker Jim Wright and others, pleaded not guilty today to 38 Federal charges in the collapse of his savings institution three years ago.      United States District

headline: Cable Spinoff Plan Revised
abstract: LEAD: Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest cable television company, said yesterday that it was again altering the form of its planned spinoff of assets. Under the new plan, Tele-Communications said it would spin off part of its assets into a separate business.

headline: Dow Is Off 11.80 but Gains 18.33 for Week
abstract: LEAD: Stocks ran out of steam yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average slipping back 11.80 points, to 2,819.91, after eking out three new highs this week. The blue-chip barometer gained 18.33 points for the week.

headline: Prime Accepts Blackstone Bid
abstract: LEAD: Prime Motor Inns Inc. said it would sell its entire Ramada and Howard Johnson motel franchises to Blackstone Capital Partners L.P. for $170 million in cash and the assumption of $15 million in royalty obligations.

headline: Money Fund Assets Off
abstract: LEAD: The assets of the nation's 508 money market mutual funds declined by $2.22 billion, to $383.5 billion, in the week that ended last Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 160 institutional funds decreased by $831.2 million, to $91.48 billion. The assets of the 246 general-purpose funds were down by $531.6 million, to $132.17 billion.

headline: CANADA ABANDONS ACCORD ON QUEBEC
abstract: LEAD: The Canadian Government conceded tonight that a long and divisive effort to confer a special constitutional status on Quebec had failed.

headline: Japan to Help Clean Mexican Air
abstract: LEAD: Japan said today that it would provide $850 million in loans to Mexico to help battle air pollution there. It will be Tokyo's first expenditure from a $2 billion fund intended to help poorer countries deal with environmental problems.

headline: Gorbachev Returns to Duty As the Soviet Master of Spin
abstract: LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev returned home today from his dual summit labors as chief Soviet negotiator and the nation's principal journalistic analyst of his own performance.

headline: Stocks Continue Rise as Dow Gains 16.58
abstract: LEAD: Stocks advanced yesterday for the second day in a row, but volume continued sluggish and is expected to stay light until after next week's Fourth of July festivities.

headline: Low-Priced Work Station From Sun
abstract: LEAD: Sun Microsystems Inc. introduced and began shipping a low-priced computer work station today that will compete directly with personal computers. It is in the price range of powerful personal computers and works twice as fast.

headline: International Lease Accords for 15 Jets
abstract: LEAD: The International Lease Finance Corporation said it had leased 15 jets to 11 airlines in deals worth $705 million. The company, based in Beverly Hills, Calif., also completed several other transactions, including selling four aircraft and acting as agent in leasing two aircraft on behalf of the financial institutions that own them.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Crowd Attacks K.G.B. Site in Armenia
abstract: LEAD: About 1,000 protesters attacked the K.G.B. headquarters in the capital of the Armenian republic late Saturday, pelting the building with stones and torches, the official Soviet press agency said today. One man was killed in the violence.

headline: Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * Southeast Toyota Distributors Inc., Deerfield Beach, Fla., to Saatchi & Saatchi DFS/Pacific, with a budget of $20 million.

headline: BellSouth vs. Newspapers
abstract: LEAD: The BellSouth Corporation asked Congress on Wednesday to end the ban barring local telephone companies from providing information services, but the American Newspaper Publishers Association said the restriction should remain.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:          The Economy

headline: In Managua, New Rulers and Never-Ending Battles
abstract: LEAD: When striking Sandinista workers chained themselves inside state buildings this month and set barricades on fire, forcing the new Government to a halt, Yolanda Navarro Castro came to a bitter conclusion about her country.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Boeing Co., Seattle, said that Lynjeflyg, the domestic airline of Sweden, had ordered four additional Boeing 737-500 jetliners worth about $130 million, including spare parts.

headline: Peru's Debt And Politics
abstract: LEAD: The presidential candidate Alberto Fujimori has vowed that if elected he will resume payments on Peru's heavy foreign debt and end five years of isolation in the world financial community.

headline: 6,400 Jobs To Be Cut By Baxter
abstract: LEAD: Continuing to suffer from slow growth and pressures to hold down prices in its core medical-supply business, Baxter International Inc. said today that it was revamping the entire company and laying off 6,400 workers to try to improve operating profits and cash flow.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Prague Says Moscow Has Agreed to Turn the Warsaw Pact Into a Political Grouping
abstract: LEAD: Foreign Minister Jiri Dienstbier of Czechoslovakia said today that at last week's Warsaw Pact meeting the Soviet Union agreed in effect to convert the organization from a military alliance under Soviet control to a more political grouping fully respecting the sovereignty of its seven member nations.

headline: Finding Success in Movie Niches
abstract: LEAD: The last few years have been trying ones for the independent movie studios as they struggled with the rising costs of making and marketing movies. But recently things have gone strikingly well for the New Line Cinema Corporation. Last weekend, ''Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles,'' a film about the four turtles made famous in comic books and on television, opened to the ninth-biggest audience in history, grossing $25.4 million.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Randall Rothenberg Serious Plans Of Saatchi's New Leaders
abstract: LEAD: The Saatchi & Saatchi Company is planning to open agencies in Hungary and East Germany and is exploring the possibility of making its Campbell-Mithun-Esty agency in the United States a part of a small international advertising network, the company's chief executive and its group financial officer said yesterday.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, APRIL 28, 1990
abstract: LEAD:          The Economy

headline: New Disk Players
abstract: LEAD: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company and the Kenwood Corporation said they plan to market new disk players in the United States this year. Matsushita said it would sell players capable of playing both audio and video disks beginning in July for $850 and that it would also sell a higher-quality player at $1,400 later this year.

headline: Mexican Receives U.S. Account of Abduction
abstract: LEAD: Mexico's Attorney General said today that United States officials told him that senior Mexican police officers initiated the plan to abduct a Mexican doctor charged in the death of an American drug agent. But the Mexican official, Enrique Alvarez del Castillo, expressed skepticism about the account.

headline: U.S. Envoy to Bulgaria Reports to Baker on Campaign Irregularities
abstract: LEAD: The United States followed up its complaints about unfair campaigning by former Communists by having its Ambassador fly to Copenhagen today to make a personal report to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d on the prospects for unimpeded voting in elections here this Sunday.

headline: Guerrilla Says Arafat Can Penalize His Unit
abstract: LEAD: The Palestinian guerrilla leader Abul Abbas said today that he and his faction were prepared to accept disciplinary action by the P.L.O. chairman, Yasir Arafat, for the raid that they staged on an Israeli beach last month.

headline: Big Investor in Household Names
abstract: LEAD: The Arab-led investor group that agreed yesterday to buy the Saks Fifth Avenue chain for roughly $1.5 billion has in recent years bought parts or all of companies whose products carry brands that are household names, from Gucci handbags to Tiffany jewelry to Carvel ice cream. But none of its previous purchases have been as big as its deal with B.A.T.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   McDonald's Changes Its Campaign Slogan
abstract: LEAD: After extolling the ''good time, great taste of McDonald's'' for six years, the fast-food icon is changing its advertising slogan. Effective tonight, the theme will be ''You know the one, McDonald's, for food, folks and fun.'' In a statement, Paul D. Schrage, McDonald's senior executive vice president and chief marketing officer, called the new theme ''a message that reflects the basic values that set McDonald's apart.

headline: Retired Top Executive Hired as Celgene Chief
abstract: LEAD: For a small company with no products on the market, the Celgene Corporation has some high-powered executives. And now it is getting another, John L. Ufheil, the former chief operating officer of Mallinckrodt Inc.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Dubcek Rebukes Slovak Protesters Who Disrupted Speech by Havel
abstract: LEAD: Alexander Dubcek, the hero of Prague Spring, shed his image of kindly geniality today to chastise a large crowd of his fellow Slovaks after some of them had disrupted a speech by President Vaclav Havel, who comes from the Czech part of this country.

headline: Associates Buying A Unit of Mellon
abstract: LEAD: The Mellon Bank Corporation has agreed to sell its consumer finance subsidiary to the Associates Corporation of North America, the companies said. Mellon said the sale of the Mellon Financial Services Corporation, based in Oakbrook Terrace, Ill., would result in a one-time, after-tax gain of about $75 million.

headline: Elated Sandinistas, Ending Strike, Declare Victory Over Chamorro
abstract: LEAD: Jubilant leaders of the opposition Sandinista Front declared victory today in a weeklong Civil Service strike that ended late Wednesday with broad Government concessions to Sandinista-led unions.

headline: Group of 7 Meeting Is Expected to Be Quiet
abstract: LEAD: The top economic policy makers from the United States and its six main industrial allies, when they meet in Paris Saturday, will discuss the momentous political and economic changes that have swept the world since their last meeting in September: the moves toward free markets in Eastern Europe, the German unification effort and the battering of the

headline: To Our Readers
abstract: LEAD: Because of a malfunction in the computer system that receives and transmits financial market data at The Associated Press, several tables reflecting yesterday's trading in options on futures were not available.

headline: Concern Sold by Warsaw
abstract: LEAD: Dozens of people gathered today outside the headquarters of a leading Polish foreign trade company to buy shares of the biggest state-owned concern being sold by the Government.

headline: Control Data Deal To Sell Chip Unit
abstract: LEAD: The Control Data Corporation reached a tentative deal to sell VTC Inc., its money-losing computer chip subsidiary, to Seattle Silicon of Bellevue, Wash. Seattle Silicon would buy the assets of VTC, and Control Data would own 20 percent of the new company, which is to be headed by Amaury Piedra, Seattle Silicon's president and chief executive.

headline: U.S. Court Overturns S.E.C. Rule
abstract: LEAD: A Federal appeals court today threw out the ''one share one vote'' requirement imposed by the Securities and Exchange Commission in 1988, a time when many companies sought to thwart hostile takeovers by issuing shares with extra voting powers.

headline: MILKEN SET TO PAY A $600 MILLION FINE IN WALL ST. FRAUD
abstract: LEAD: Michael R. Milken, who created the ''junk bond'' market that financed many big corporate takeovers in the 1980's, agreed yesterday to plead guilty to six criminal charges related to securities transactions and pay $600 million in fines, people who have been briefed about the decision said.

headline: Bonn Works on Money Plan Amid Protests in East
abstract: LEAD: As hundreds of thousands of East Germans marched in protest today against Bonn's proposed currency conversion, the West German Government took the first legal steps toward monetary union for the two nations but did not discuss the conversion rate, senior Government officials said.

headline: Northeast Bancorp Merger Bid Ended
abstract: LEAD: After hinting for months that it was willing to forgo a previously announced merger with Northeast Bancorp of Shelton, Conn., the Bank of New York set terms yesterday for the merger that the Connecticut bank found unacceptable.

headline: Microsoft Set To Add to Staff
abstract: LEAD: The Microsoft Corporaton said today that it plans to add at least 1,000 employees this year, increasing its worldwide employment by about 20 percent.

headline: Affordable Housing;  The Two-Family House Is Revived in Jersey City
abstract: LEAD: The two-family house, a traditional form of affordable housing largely ignored by developers in the 1980's, is being revived in Jersey City, just across the Hudson River from lower Manhattan. Construction of a colony of such houses will begin next month on the 10-acre site of a former factory in the heart of the city's

headline: Drexel Plan Has Creditors Skeptical
abstract: LEAD: The creditors of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. voiced strong skepticism yesterday about the firm's reorganization plan, questioning whether Drexel's management should supervise the liquidation.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   YELTSIN IS ELECTED RUSSIAN PRESIDENT ON 3D-ROUND VOTE
abstract: LEAD: Boris N. Yeltsin, the maverick politician who has spent three years fighting the Communist Party establishment, today became President of the Russian republic, overcoming a last-ditch effort by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to block his election before departing for visits to Canada and the United

headline: Sallie Mae Prices Floating Notes
abstract: LEAD: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, priced $500 million in short-term floating-rate notes yesterday through a regular selling group led by the Government-sponsored private corporation.

headline: In Peru's 'Holy War,' Strange Allies
abstract: LEAD: With polls leading up to the presidential runoff election Sunday showing a dead heat, Mario Vargas Llosa, who says he is an agnostic, may benefit from support from an unlikely source: the Roman Catholic hierarchy.

headline: Liberia and the Rebels Agree To End Attacks on Civilians
abstract: LEAD: Liberian Government and rebel delegations met for six hours today and agreed to an appeal from Liberia's religious leaders to end attacks on civilians.

headline: Lebanese Christian Factions Now Hoping for Intervention
abstract: LEAD: Leaders of Lebanon's warring Christian factions sought help today after 63 days of fighting that have failed to give either side a military victory.

headline: Scherer Deal For Japanese
abstract: LEAD: The French fashion house Jean-Louis Scherrer today became the latest luxury clothing designer to agree to be bought out by a Japanese-controlled company.

headline: 52 Killed as Lebanese Rivals Resume Full Warfare
abstract: LEAD: Rival Christian forces pounded East Beirut with artillery fire today after a night of house-to-house fighting under parachute flares for control of Lebanon's Christian enclave.

headline: Hewlett's P.C. Boss Takes Post at Apple
abstract: LEAD: Robert Puette, the head of the Hewlett-Packard Company's personal computer operations, has been named president of Apple Computer Inc.'s U.S.A. division, filling a key vacancy at the Cupertino, Calif., personal computer company.

headline: Sale by Hershey
abstract: LEAD: The Hershey Foods Corporation signed an agreement to sell its shares in A.B. Marabou, a Swedish confectionery and snack food concern, to Orkla Borregaard A.S. of Oslo for cash in excess of $75 million. Hershey said the deal was expected to result in a one-time after-tax gain in excess of $35 million.

headline: Bill on Penny Stocks Draws Criticism From S.E.C. Chief
abstract: LEAD: Richard C. Breeden, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, expressed strong reservations today about key portions of a legislative package intended to strengthen Federal oversight of the nation's penny stock market.

headline: Pathe Extends MGM/UA Bid
abstract: LEAD: Pathe Communications Inc. extended its tender offer again yesterday for the shares of the MGM/UA Communications Company. Pathe's tender offer was set to expire tomorrow.

headline: Addenda
abstract: LEAD: * Meredith Corp. has agreed to sell MMT Sales Inc. to the unit's management. The unit, which is based in New York, represents 30 television stations to national advertisers.

headline: Cuban-American Takes Aim at Castro, on TV
abstract: LEAD: Using the infant medium of television to stunning political effect, a young Fidel Castro dominated the airwaves in 1960 seeking to rally supporters to his new rule.

headline: Limited and May Promote Officers
abstract: LEAD: The Limited Inc., the chain of specialty apparel stores, has named Thomas G. Hopkins vice chairman.

headline: Wall Street;   The Gumshoe of Annual Reports
abstract: LEAD: Do not expect to see Behind the Numbers spreading sunshine on coffee tables throughout greater corporate America. In the two years since the pricey, and influential, investment newsletter made its debut, it has recommended the stock of only one of the 78 companies it has written about.

headline: Boat People's Plight Seen as Likely to Worsen
abstract: LEAD: Despite a dramatic drop in the number of Vietnamese boat people seeking asylum here and in other parts of Southeast Asia in recent months, Hong Kong officials and international relief workers said this week that they expected to see scores of the fragile Vietnamese boats pushed back to sea this summer by angry

headline: Phnom Penh Journal;   Come to the Land of Angkor, War and Profiteers
abstract: LEAD: In that hazy period more than 20 years ago, before Cambodia became a scene of genocide, and notables like Jacqueline Kennedy were visiting the temples of Angkor, some 60,000 tourists a year came to Cambodia and 200,000 visited Thailand.

headline: Prague Communists Threatened With Ban
abstract: LEAD: The Prague prosecutor has threatened to outlaw the Communist Party within the city just as campaigning is about to begin for Czechoslovakia's first free elections, a newspaper said today.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Walesa, From Hero to Foe
abstract: LEAD: Lech Walesa's former comrades have asserted that he is becoming a threat to Poland's fledgling democracy and have rebuked him for his criticism of the Solidarity-led Government.

headline: Hostage Statement Issued by Militants
abstract: LEAD: Following is the text of a statement received today by a Western news organization in Beirut, as translated from the Arabic by Reuters. The statement was accompanied by a photograph of an American hostage, Jesse Turner.

headline: 2-Year and 5-Year Notes to Be Auctioned
abstract: LEAD: Treasury financings this week include today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, followed on Wednesday by the Treasury's auction of two-year notes and on Thursday by an auction of five-year notes.

headline: Korean Protesters and Police Clash for 3d Day
abstract: LEAD: Police officers firing automatic rifles held off demonstrators hurling firebombs at a police station today as about 10,000 protesters rampaged in this city for a third day.

headline: Stocks Edge Up as Dow Rises 4.03 Points
abstract: LEAD: Despite extensive profit taking, stocks edged slightly higher by late yesterday in the wake of weaker-than-expected car sales and sluggish orders for durable goods - both of which are bullish for stocks.

headline: Ferranti Case Accusations
abstract: LEAD: A former executive of a leading British military contractor used a bogus company based in a New York post office box to send shipments of embargoed military arms to South Africa, an F.B.I. agent said on Wednesday.

headline: A Less Expensive Supercomputer
abstract: LEAD: Cray Research Inc. introduced a supercomputer priced at $2.2 million and up, less than half the price of its existing Cray Y-MP products, which start at $5 million. The new machine, the Cray Y-MP2E, can be air-cooled, which is less costly than the liquid refrigerants used by the Y-MP family. ''Until now the cost of ownership has put supercomputing out of reach for many organizations,'' John A.

headline: Economic Scene;   Broader Medicaid: Who Would Pay?
abstract: LEAD: A RECENT Supreme Court decision is expected to add to growing pressure for changes in Medicaid. The Court ruled on June 14 that hospitals and nursing homes can file lawsuits to demand ''reasonable and adequate reimbursement'' for their services to Medicaid patients.

headline: Sony Is Said To Be in Deal For TV Plant
abstract: LEAD: The Sony Corporation is expected to announce today that it will produce television picture tubes in a vacated Volkswagen factory near Pittsburgh.

headline: All About/AM Radio;   Struggling Stations in Search of a Niche
abstract: LEAD: In April last year, Howard Goldsmith bought station WSBR-AM in Boca Raton, Fla. Its ''oldies'' format had been losing money. Because Boca Raton is popular with wealthy retirees, Mr. Goldsmith immediately changed the station's format to all-business. This year, he said, the station will make a profit.

headline: First Thompson Ad For Wall St. Journal
abstract: LEAD: In its first advertising campaign from the J. Walter Thompson Company, The Wall Street Journal will try to assure media planners that it is not a stuffy business newpaper read only by the gray old men of high finance.

headline: Europe Prices Up 0.4%
abstract: LEAD: Consumer prices in the European Community rose an average of four-tenths of a percent last month from April, Eurostat, the European statistics office, said on Monday. Despite the increase, the annual inflation rate in the 12-nation community held steady in May at a provisional 5.4 percent. The highest jump from April to May, 3 percent, was in Greece, where the annual inflation rate rose to 21 percent - the highest in the community - from 17.9 percent a month earlier.

headline: Macy's Expects 5th Straight Deficit
abstract: LEAD: In what will be its fifth straight quarterly deficit, R. H. Macy & Company will report a loss for the quarter ended April 28, but it will be lower than the $64 million deficit it had in the period the year before, Macy's has told investors in its 1986 leveraged buyout.

headline: Building a Better Air Grinder, Faster
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Israeli Is Given 3 Years For Desecrating Graves
abstract: LEAD: A court today sentenced a Jew to three years in prison after he confessed to desecrating more than 300 Jewish graves in the hope that Arabs would be blamed.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:    Debt

headline: Aid Resumed Too Argentina; Debt Talk Set
abstract: LEAD: The International Monetary Fund approved the resumption of aid to Argentina yesterday and, at the same time, Argentina and its commercial bankers said they will start debt negotiations on June 7.

headline: LITHUANIA LEADER SOFTENS HIS TONE TOWARD MOSCOW
abstract: LEAD: After three weeks of tension, discord and daily pressure from Moscow, the leadership of Lithuania softened its tone today, insisting that it never expected immediate independence despite declaring itself free of Soviet rule on March 11.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Amoco Oil Co., Chicago, appointed David L. Lemmon president of its pipeline transportation subsidiary, Amoco Pipeline Co.

headline: Report Causes Tonka Plunge
abstract: LEAD: The Tonka Corporation's stock plummeted today after the company said it expected sharp declines in its toy market share and earnings.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Calvin Klein Tops Ad Poll
abstract: LEAD: Once again, Calvin Klein can take credit for the top print campaign of the year, said Commercial Break, the newsletter of Video Storyboard Tests, an advertising research organization based in New York.

headline: Ex-Sergeant, Charged as Spy, Is Ordered Held Without Bail
abstract: LEAD: Roderick James Ramsay, a former Army sergeant arrested on espionage charges last week, was ordered held without bail today by the United States District Court in Tampa.

headline: Price-Blind Smoker Loyalty Defies Economics and Critics
abstract: LEAD: About two weeks ago, something happened that may subtly undermine the recent efforts of antismoking advocates: the tobacco industry raised cigarette prices and most smokers went along.

headline: New Beginnings, Second Quarter And Fiscal Year
abstract: LEAD: Traders are hoping that the arrival of the year's second quarter today will enliven the market, after last week's various departures - one clumsy, one graceful, the rest routine - gave Wall Street the meandering air of a mid-afternoon train station.

headline: Market Place;   Less Euphoria On East Germany
abstract: LEAD: Christian Picot, the chief of equities trading at Banque Paribas in New York, spent several days last week visiting factories in East Berlin and East Germany, talking to workers and managers. ''You have to be there to see what is going to happen,'' he said. His conclusion: not much for now.

headline: Police Colonel Slain in Chile
abstract: LEAD: Two gunmen today shot to death a former Chilean police intelligence chief, Col. Luis Fontaine, the police and witnesses said. Colonel Fontaine was shot seven times in the head.

headline: Statements by Chinese Dissidents and Beijing
abstract: LEAD: Following are the text of a statement by the Chinese dissidents Fang Lizhi and Li Shuxian, as made public by the State Department yesterday and reported by Reuters, and the official New China News Agency's report on their release, as distributed in translation by the press agency:       Statement by

headline: Seidman Traces Start Of Conflict
abstract: LEAD: In his first public comments on his relations with the Bush Administration, L. William Seidman, the outgoing chief of the savings and loan bailout, said today that his difficulties with the White House went back to the earliest days of the Administration when he irritated John H. Sununu, the chief of staff.

headline: Italy Ends Its Controls On the Lira
abstract: LEAD: Italy removed the last of its controls on capital movements today, freeing Italians to send money overseas but also potentially shrinking the captive pool of savings the Government has tapped to finance its huge budget deficits.

headline: China Flood Toll Put at 254; Thousands of Houses Ruined
abstract: LEAD: The death toll from flooding in the southern Chinese province of Hunan has reached 254, a province official said today.

headline: Company-Financed Pensions Are Failing to Fulfill Promise
abstract: LEAD: The company-financed pension, once envisioned as a principal source of retirement income for millions of Americans, is instead an ever-shrinking portion of the money they receive in later years. The trend could force today's generation of wage earners to rely heavily on Social Security and savings.

headline: House Panel Wants Milken
abstract: LEAD: Almost two years to the day when Michael R. Milken appeared before a House panel and refused to answer any questions by invoking his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination, John D. Dingell, the chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, said today that he would ask Mr. Milken to return and complete his testimony.

headline: Despite Tensions With Iran, Americans Aid Quake Relief
abstract: LEAD: Despite tensions between the United States and Iran, relief officials say American citizens and businesses are offering money, medicine and other aid to victims of the earthquake that struck northwestern Iran on Thursday.

headline: Arab Uprising Seeking New Tactics for Revival
abstract: LEAD: As their uprising against Israeli occupation unfolds through a 30th month, Palestinians confront a range of divisive and unresolved questions that turn on a central issue: what new tactics can re-invigorate the revolt and counter Israeli assertions that its flame has dimmed?

headline: Brazil Backed on Economy
abstract: LEAD: United States Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher expressed strong support today for President Fernando Collor de Mello's sweeping economic changes and the opening of Brazil's economy.

headline: Vice Chairman Named New Chief at Fairchild
abstract: LEAD: The Fairchild Space and Defense Corporation has named Richard E. Brackeen as chairman and chief executive to succeed Richard D. DeLauer, a well-known aerospace executive and former Pentagon official who died Sunday at age 71.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   'Open Skies' Talks Hit Snag, Cutting Chances of Pact in May
abstract: LEAD: A stalemate has emerged at the second round of the the 23-nation ''open skies'' conference, sharply reducing any chance that a treaty allowing mutual aerial inspection of military sites will be signed next month as scheduled, Soviet and United States negotiators said today.

headline: Workers of the World, Innovate!
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Bankruptcy Filings Up
abstract: LEAD: Personal bankruptcy filings in the United States rose 15 percent in the first three months of the year, led by sharp increases in the Northeast, a financial industry group reported on Thursday. There were 166,694 personal bankruptcy filings in the first quarter, compared with 144,725 a year earlier, said the group, the American Financial Services Association.

headline: Romania, Preparing to Vote, Wears a Look of Menace, Squalor and Fear
abstract: LEAD: Five months after the only violent revolution in Eastern Europe, Romania heads into its first free elections on May 20 with only a tenuous hold on its newly won freedoms, facing a future that looks almost menacing.

headline: Economic Scene;   German Worries On Unification
abstract: LEAD: The stunning defeat of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democratic Union by the Social Democratic Party in two key West German states reflected voters' anxieties that unification with East Germany will cost them heavily. Mr. Kohl is now moving to head off a buildup of political pressures that could disrupt unification.

headline: 2 More Earthquakes Rock Iran; Rescue Efforts Stall as Toll Rises
abstract: LEAD: Two more large earthquakes struck Iran today even as rescue workers continued combing through the rubble left by last week's violent temblor along the Caspian Sea.

headline: Bristol-Myers Deal
abstract: LEAD: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company, the New York-based pharmaceutical company, reached an agreement to acquire Concept Inc., a developer and manufacturer of orthopedic surgery products based in Largo, Fla. The stock swap is valued at about $205 million. The deal, intended to qualify as a tax-free pooling of interests, must be approved by Concept's shareholders by July.

headline: The Other Agreements, in Brief
abstract: LEAD:    SIGNED BY BUSH AND GORBACHEV       AGREEMENTS       Peaceful Uses of Atomic Energy

headline: Upjohn Selling South African Unit
abstract: LEAD: The Upjohn Company agreed to sell its 100-employee South African vegetable-seed operation, Asgrow S.A., to local management. But an Upjohn spokesman, John P. Lambrechts, said the company was not pulling out of South Africa and would continue operating its 150-employee Upjohn Ltd. pharmaceutical and animal health products business there.

headline: Pathe Again Extends Offer for MGM/UA
abstract: LEAD: The Pathe Communications Corporation said yesterday that it was again extending its $1.2 billion offer for of MGM/UA Communications.

headline: The Executive Life;  Branded by Drexel, And Still Out of Work
abstract: LEAD: To wear a Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. windbreaker around town these days is to invite abuse.

headline: MCI Plans to Pay Dividend on Stock
abstract: LEAD: The MCI Communications Corporation announced it would pay dividends on its common stock for the first time in its 27-year history. The nation's second-largest long-distance telephone company told shareholders at its annual meeting in Washington that it would begin paying a regular semiannual dividend of 5 cents a share on its common stock on June 11.

headline: Reports of Saudi Price Cuts Depress Energy Contracts
abstract: LEAD: Reports that Saudi Arabia reduced prices for its July oil exports to the United States by 40 cents a barrel from June levels sent energy futures traded at the New York Mercantile Exchange tumbling today.

headline: Effort to Cut OPEC Output
abstract: LEAD: The Saudi oil minister announced new efforts today to bring back into line the OPEC partners violating the group's oil production quotas and driving prices down, an official report said.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   At Romanian Inauguration, Promises and Doubts
abstract: LEAD: Ion Iliescu was inaugurated President today, ending six months of provisional rule that began with the violent overthrow of President Nicolae Ceausescu last December.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * ACF Holding N.V., a diversified Dutch pharmaceutical company, said it was looking for foreign pharmaceutical companies to take a stake of up to 20 percent in the company through a private placement of new shares.

headline: Fed Voted in March for Tight Rein
abstract: LEAD: Federal Reserve policy makers concluded at their March meeting that excessive inflation would continue and decided to maintain high interest rate policies in the face of a moderately growing economy, according to minutes of the meeting released today.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   3 Accounts to McCann
abstract: LEAD: McCann-Erickson announced Friday that it had won three accounts, including the consolidated facsimile business of A.T.& T. The agency estimated the billings for that account, to be handled by McCann New York, at $15 million to $20 million. McCann also won the $10 million multinational advertising account of Nordica S.p.A., a ski company based in Milan.

headline: New York State Pollution Bonds
abstract: LEAD: A $166.5 million bond offering by the New York State Environmental Facilities Corporation was tentatively priced yesterday to yield a maximum of about 7.719 percent for bonds due in 2012.

headline: In Possible Compromise, Moscow Is Said to Invite Lithuanian
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov has invited the Prime Minister of Lithuania to Moscow for talks this week, Lithuanian officials said today, giving rise to speculation in Lithuania that the Kremlin was preparing to end its partial economic blockade of the republic.

headline: Investor Reduces Stake in Harley
abstract: LEAD: The Rochester investor Malcolm I. Glazer disclosed he had sold 1.2 million shares of Harley-Davidson Inc. for $5.625 a share, or a total sale price of $30.75 million. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Glazer said the sale reduced his holding in the Milwaukee-based motorcycle manufacturer to less than 1 percent, from 7.29 percent.

headline: FOREIGN REPORTERS COMPLAIN TO CHINA
abstract: LEAD: The Foreign Correspondents Club of Beijing complained to the Government today about a series of assaults in recent days against foreign reporters by security forces. But the Government immediately rejected the complaint as ''utterly unreasonable.''

headline: Data Bank/May 20, 1990
abstract: Industrial Production Index

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Altschiller: A Merger That Works
abstract: LEAD: THE new midtown Manhattan headquarters of the Altschiller Reitzfeld Davis/Tracy-Locke advertising agency came with several unusual features. Consider, for example, the exposed pipes in the ceiling, a design statement usually associated with young, downtown agencies, not a 13-year-old shop. And instead of doors with hinges and knobs, the offices feature metal doors that slide and lock like bank vaults.

headline: Political Violence on the Rise Again in Guatemala, Tarnishing Civilian Rule
abstract: LEAD: Five months before elections, this country is being swept by growing waves of political violence and human rights abuses.

headline: Devon's Aztech Chief Will Head New Unit
abstract: LEAD: Andrew I. Cramer was a bit beside himself yesterday, trying to figure out how to meld his relatively new Aztech Financial Printers unit with elements of the Chas. P. Young Company, one of the nation's oldest financial printing firms.

headline: Eastern Deal Advances
abstract: LEAD: The Transportation Department today tentatively approved the sale of several of Eastern Airlines' international routes to American Airlines. The route sale is expected to bring Eastern about $350 million as it tries to consolidate its operations under bankruptcy protection. Pan American World Airways and Eastern's unions are expected to express opposition.

headline: Spending Falls in Britain
abstract: LEAD: Britain's consumer spending fell last month, indicating that Government efforts to reduce inflation through high interest rates were beginning to take hold. The Central Statistical Office said today that provisional March retail sales fell by 1.4 percent. February's retail sales figures had shown a marked rise of 2.4 percent, which market analysts had described as a one-time abnormality.

headline: Mutual Funds;   On the Road With Grace Pineda
abstract: LEAD: Grace Pineda, daughter of a Filipino diplomat, lived in France, Switzerland and the Philippines before her family settled in the United States. Here she studied Russian, one of four languages she now speaks, and later earned a graduate degree in international business from Fordham University. She has specialized in the Pacific markets since 1982, when she got her first money management job and was assigned to watch a promising spot called

headline: New York's Magazines In a Slump
abstract: LEAD: For magazines, New York has be-come a town without pity.

headline: For Insider, Fine and 4-Month Term
abstract: LEAD: Closing one of the most difficult criminal cases the Government has brought in its pursuit of corruption on Wall Street, a Federal judge in Manhattan yesterday sentenced a former stock speculator to four months in prison and fined him $1 million for a single incident of insider trading.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: LEAD:    Economic and Social Council

headline: Health-Care Bonds In Minnesota Cities
abstract: LEAD: A $159.4 million tax-exempt bond issue by Minneapolis and the Housing and Redevelopment Authority of St. Paul was priced yesterday through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Expanding Services in Marketing
abstract: LEAD: BACKER SPIELVOGEL BATES WORLDWIDE is likely to become the next large advertising agency to create a comprehensive program to coordinate various forms of marketing communications for its clients, says a vice chairman of the agency.

headline: Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * Lexus Dealer Association, to Team One Advertising.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Interpublic Group
abstract: LEAD: The Interpublic Group of Companies yesterday reported earnings of $8.64 million, or 26 cents a share, for the first quarter, up 8 percent from $8.01 million, or 24 cents a share, for the comparable period in 1989.

headline: Burmese Rights Abuses Are Said to Continue
abstract: LEAD: Amnesty International has charged in a report that ''severe human rights violations'' have continued to be frequent in Myanmar, formerly Burma, under the current military Government.

headline: The Executive Computer;   The Power Culture Elbows In at Macworld
abstract: LEAD: Tens of thousands of Apple Macintosh users visited the Macworld trade exposition here earlier this month, examining the hardware and software on offer. But unlike the Macworld shows of a couple of years ago, when people in blue jeans and polo shirts came to look at Apple's small and relatively underpowered computer family, this year's show attracted what appeared to be an unusually high percentage of corporate users.

headline: HAILS A NEW ERA
abstract: LEAD: Ending more than a decade of rule by the Sandinista National Liberation Front, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro was inaugurated today as Nicaragua's President. In a gesture of reconciliation, she then retained the top Sandinista military leader as the senior commander in the armed forces.

headline: Vernitron in New Bid For Kollmorgen Corp.
abstract: LEAD: The Vernitron Corporation announced today that it will renew its attempt to take over the Kollmorgen Corporation by starting a proxy fight for control of the company's board at the annual meeting scheduled for May 24.

headline: Commodity Trader Plan
abstract: LEAD: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission proposed a rule today that would require traders to disclose any informal relationships among one another on the floor of the nation's futures exchanges. Under the plan, traders who work with each other, even if informally, would have to register as ''broker associations.

headline: Where St. Paul Ran Aground, A Pope Finally Makes a Visit
abstract: LEAD: This will long be remembered by Maltese as the week when the Pope paid them a visit and their tiny archipelago got its only traffic light.

headline: NBC Alters Its Count Of Viewers
abstract: LEAD: NBC announced yesterday that it would change the system it uses to account for the number of viewers its programs deliver to advertisers.

headline: Interest Rates Fall On Job Data
abstract: LEAD: Interest rates plunged yesterday, as prices of Treasury securities soared in response to news of an unexpectedly small increase in nonfarm employment in April. Only 64,000 non-farm jobs were added in April, and the unemployment rate rose by two-tenths of 1 percent, to 5.4 percent, its highest level in 15 months.

headline: China Gives Cool Reply to Taiwan Overture
abstract: LEAD: China issued a cool response today to Taiwan's offer last month to allow contacts between the rival Governments, and said direct trade and telecommunications links should be established before formal negotiations begin.
