headline: Pro Bono
abstract: LEAD: * Research!America, a new organization formed to educate the public about medical research, to Sutton Communications.

headline: Tech Notes;   How Does the Micro-Motor Wear?
abstract: LEAD: Researchers at the Massachussetts Institute of Technology and the University of California at Berkeley have been working for years to develop micro-motors. Now, they say, they know a bit about how these tiny engines wear. ''We are beginning to get a foothold in understanding the wear process and in learning how bearings hold up,'' said Jeffrey Lang, an associate professor of electrical engineering at M.I.T., who is building the motors.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: LEAD: * BankAmerica Corp., San Francisco, appointed Martin A. Stein head of BankAmerica Systems Engineering. Bankamerica also promoted Eric Von Pingel, the director of the appraisal department of its real estate division, to senior vice president.

headline: Micro Devices' Revenue Flat
abstract: LEAD: Advanced Micro Devices, a maker of semiconductors, reported today that it had only ''marginal profitability'' on operations and flat revenue in the first quarter of 1990.

headline: Memoirs From the I.B.M. Dynasty
abstract: LEAD: As a small boy in knee breeches, he tossed confetti made from keypunch cards, was dragged along to sales conventions, and played on the Oriental rugs in the Fifth Avenue office where his father ran the tabulating machine business that in 1924 became the International Business Machines Corporation.

headline: Japanese Computer Rated The Fastest by One Measure
abstract: LEAD: A Japanese supercomputer has for the first time taken the title of the world's fastest single-processor computer, according to a study released yesterday by a researcher at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory, an Energy Department research center.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   East German Parliament Opens; No Cabinet Picked
abstract: LEAD: East Germany's first freely elected Parliament held its inaugural session today, but with the major parties still negotiating a coalition, no government was installed.

headline: Zambian Is Arrested After Reporting Coup
abstract: LEAD: A man who described himself as a Zambian Army lieutenant was seized by soldiers early today after he announced on state radio that President Kenneth D. Kaunda had been toppled from power after five days of violent unrest over increases in food prices.

headline: Cuba Starts Jamming Radio Marti Full Time
abstract: LEAD: Cuba today started 24-hour jamming in Havana of Radio Marti, the United States's Spanish-language station transmitted from Miami, and said it would extend the jamming to the whole island.

headline: Volkswagen Profit Up 5.5%
abstract: LEAD: Volkswagen A.G., West Germany's largest auto maker, reported today that its first-quarter profit rose 5.5 percent from the results in the period last year.

headline: Reporter's Notebook;   Behold Bush, A Diplomat Of the Mists
abstract: LEAD: Is George Bush really Joe Btsfplk in disguise?

headline: Upheaval in the East;   East Germans Form 'Grand Coalition'
abstract: LEAD: East Germany's new political leaders reached agreement today on a ''grand coalition'' government whose major task will be to lead the nation to union with West Germany.

headline: Ames Chain Closing 188 More Stores
abstract: LEAD: Ames Department Stores Inc. yesterday took its biggest cost-cutting step since its April 25 bankruptcy filing by announcing the closing of an additional 188 stores. The chain had reported earlier that 33 would be closed.

headline: Soviets Unveil Limited Plan Toward 'Regulated Market'
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov proposed a package of changes for the Soviet economy today that combine a small dose of free-market liberalization with continued heavy Government regulation.

headline: Mitsui Bank Expansion
abstract: LEAD: The Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank Ltd. announced plans yesterday to create a new company to specialize in interest-rate and currency swaps and options.

headline: Comedy Channels Likely to Merge
abstract: LEAD: Time Warner Inc and Viacom Inc. have agreed in principle to merge Time Warner's Comedy Channel and Viacom's HA!, a rival channel, a person involved in the negotiations said yesterday.

headline: Peru Limits Withdrawals
abstract: LEAD: Peru imposed sharp restrictions on withdrawals from savings accounts last week to apparently try to ease speculation in the American dollar.

headline: Profits Rise by 48% at Intel On Demand for Its PC Chips
abstract: LEAD: Despite a continuing slump in the personal computer market, the Intel Corporation today reported record first-quarter earnings. Intel's strong earnings, which exceeded the highest Wall Street estimates, were driven by demand for its 32-bit microprocessors, the 80386 and 80486, which form the heart of the most powerful

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Lithuanians Debating a Freeze on Independence
abstract: LEAD: Lithuania's legislators began debating a freeze of their declaration of independence today, and some questioned whether President Mikhail S. Gorbachev had the credibility or staying power to stick to a compromise.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * Showtime Satellite Networks, to Rosenfeld, Sirowitz, Humphrey & Strauss for its consumer and trade advertising.

headline: First National Has 8.4% of Ultimate
abstract: LEAD: The First National International Corporation, a venture-capital holding company based in Midvale, Utah, has acquired an 8.4 percent stake in the Ultimate Corporation and said in a Federal filing that it may seek control of the computer-services concern. Norman Elowitz, a New York fashion executive who also controls 8.4 percent of Ultimate's shares, said earlier that he was considering seeking control of the company, which is based in East Hanover, N

headline: The Great New Drive to Rescue Wang's Computers
abstract: LEAD: Richard W. Miller wasn't frightened by difficult business situations. After all, his first job after finishing business school in 1970 had been at the Penn Central Corporation, which was going through what was then the largest bankruptcy proceeding in the nation's history.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: LEAD: * Baroid Corp., Houston, a supplier of titanium and petroleum services and equipment, appointed Joseph S. Compofelice chief financial officer. He will remain president of Baroid's two oilfield equipment operations, Shaffer Inc. and Atlas Bradford.

headline: MANDELA DEPARTS ON A WORLD TRIP
abstract: LEAD: Nelson Mandela left today on a wide-ranging tour that will take him to the United States and a dozen other countries over the next six weeks.

headline: C.D. and Bank Fund Yields Show Slight Drop in Week
abstract: LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts edged downward nationally in the week ended yesterday.

headline: Currency;   Surprise Figures Shake the Dollar
abstract: LEAD: THE employment numbers for April took the market by surprise on Friday and knocked the dollar lower. The surprise was that the report showed a weaker economy than expected. Rather than declining, the unemployment rate rose two-tenths of a percentage point, to 5.4 percent. After adjusting for an influx of census workers, non-farm payroll jobs declined.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   Gorbachev Hands Over Katyn Papers
abstract: LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today gave President Wojciech Jaruzelski of Poland cartons of documents that the Soviet leader said ''indirectly but convincingly'' proved that the Soviet secret police killed thousands of Polish officers in Katyn Forest in the spring of 1940.

headline: MCI to Acquire Telecom USA
abstract: LEAD: The MCI Communications Corporation, the nation's second-largest provider of long-distance telephone services, announced a $1.25 billion agreement yesterday to buy Telecom USA Inc., the No. 4 company.

headline: Dollar Off More Than 2 Yen In Tokyo Morning Session
abstract: LEAD: The dollar plummeted more than 2 yen against the Japanese currency this morning. The American currency closed the morning session here at 151.15 yen, down 2.20 yen from Monday's close of 153.35 yen.

headline: Warsaw Fire That Killed Wife Of Journalist Is Called Arson
abstract: LEAD: Investigators have concluded that a fatal fire at the apartment of a journalist who specialized in exposing abuses by the secret police was arson.

headline: Now, Milken The Investor Is Tarnished
abstract: LEAD: Mike Milken is a crook. That he now admits. But is he also a poor investor?

headline: Sales Weighed By Harcourt
abstract: LEAD: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. has been discussing the sale of all or a part of its huge debt at a discount to book value along with the possible sales of some of its businesses, according to a statement last night by Peter Jovanovich, the publishing company's president and chief executive.

headline: YELTSIN TAKES AIM AT CENTRAL RULE
abstract: LEAD: In his first day as President of the Russian republic, Boris N. Yeltsin put the Kremlin on notice today with an aggressive program to free Russia from ''the dictates of the center.''

headline: S.E.C. Brings Insider Case
abstract: LEAD: The son of a Washington real estate magnate was accused today of passing confidential information about one of his father's deals to a friend who allegedly traded illegally on the inside information.

headline: U.S. IS TO RETURN LAND IN OKINAWA
abstract: LEAD: The United States and Japan announced today that the American military had agreed to return about 4 percent of the land from its base installations on the southern Japanese island of Okinawa, in a long-awaited move that appears likely to leave the strongly anti-military residents of Okinawa unsatisfied.

headline: In Magazine Publishing, Gloom but Not Doom
abstract: LEAD: Joseph J. Hanson, the publisher of Folio and Publishing News, has an analogy for the current state of the magazine business.

headline: Unocal to Buy Energy Tracts
abstract: LEAD: The Unocal Corporation said today that a subsidiary, Union Exploration Partners Ltd., had agreed to acquire a crude oil and natural gas subsidiary of Placer Dome Inc. in a deal valued at $336 million.

headline: Eastern Air To Cooperate With Inquiry
abstract: LEAD: The court-appointed trustee for Eastern Airlines said yesterday that he had offered his cooperation in a Brooklyn grand jury investigation of whether the airline had ordered some employees to falsify maintenance records more than a year ago.

headline: Gorbachev Meets With Assad
abstract: LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Hafez al-Assad of Syria met today and asserted that United States policies were an obstacle to Middle East peace, the official news agency Tass reported. In their talks, Mr. Assad raised the issue of emigration of Soviet Jews to Israel. Tass said any problems caused by emigration must be solved in the context ''of the rights of the Arabs and not just of human rights.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Burkhardt & Christy's Spot for Sony Tapes
abstract: LEAD: Because audio tape is a product whose quality varies little from brand to brand, most advertising for the product relies on image. Burkhardt & Christy's first campaign for Sony audio tape, which starts next month, is no exception.

headline: U.S. JEWISH GROUP CRITICAL OF ISRAEL ON AID TO SETTLERS
abstract: LEAD: The leading pro-Israeli lobby in the United States told the Israeli Government today that its covert sponsorship of a Jewish settlement in the Christian Quarter of Jerusalem could seriously damage American-Israeli relations.

headline: Eastern to Seek Escrow Funds
abstract: LEAD: Martin R. Shugrue, the trustee appointed by the bankruptcy court to run Eastern Airlines, said yesterday that he would ask the unsecured creditors and the court to approve the withdrawal from escrow of $50 million for lease payments due in July on many of its planes.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Cray Research Inc., Minneapolis, the computer company, named Franklin J. Parisi vice president of corporate communications.

headline: Deal-Making in Israel Spurs Demands for Reform
abstract: LEAD: Their voices are difficult to hear above the din of promises, threats and warnings that characterize politics here, but the Israeli people are once again demanding that their Government reform itself.

headline: U.S. Lawmakers Tie Soviet Trade Pact to Kremlin Progress on Lithuania
abstract: LEAD: Members of Congress warned today that Congressional approval of an agreement expanding American trade with the Soviet Union would hinge on President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's willingness to end Moscow's economic crackdown on Lithuania.

headline: Making Foreign Auto Makers the Scapegoats
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: 34 Killed in Bomb Blast at Hindu Rite in Punjab
abstract: LEAD: At least 34 people were killed in Punjab State today when a bomb believed to have been set by Sikh radicals exploded in the middle of a Hindu religious procession.

headline: Liberia Capital Fearful as War Nears
abstract: LEAD: This is a city awaiting the unknown. From the main roads to the east and the north, after five months of often-brutal fighting in the countryside, a rebel army is advancing.

headline: New York State Revenue Bonds
abstract: LEAD: The State of New York Mortgage Agency, which issues bonds to create a pool of funds for loans to first-time home buyers, is offering $48.4 million in homeowner mortgage revenue bonds through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company.

headline: Asset Sales By Campeau
abstract: LEAD: The Campeau Corporation, which this week reported a $1.7 billion loss for 1989, said yesterday that it would ask shareholders at its annual meeting on July 30 to approve the sale of all or part of the company's Canadian real estate.

headline: U.S. Says Shamir Is Risking Chances for Mideast Peace
abstract: LEAD: The United States warned Israel today that rejection of Secretary of State James A. Baker's proposals for opening talks with Palestinians would probably mean losing an important chance to move toward Middle East peace.

headline: Why is the Boss Wearing a Hula Skirt?
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Anti-Apartheid Editor To Return From Exile
abstract: LEAD: Donald Woods, the white journalist and opponent of apartheid whose life was portrayed in the film ''Cry Freedom,'' plans to return from exile in London after a personal assurance from President F. W. de Klerk, an associate of Mr. Woods said today.

headline: BUSH AND GORBACHEV SIGN MAJOR ACCORDS ON MISSILES, CHEMICAL WEAPONS AND TRADE
abstract: LEAD: President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today consolidated the gains of their new relationship by signing the broadest Soviet-American understandings in two decades, including commitments to cut stockpiles of long-range nuclear arms and to eliminate most of their chemical weapons.

headline: Older Pass-Throughs Called Stronger Than New Ones
abstract: LEAD: Analysts at Salomon Brothers Inc. noted that moderately seasoned pass-through securities now offer a better value than new pass-through issues, a recent research report shows.

headline: Circle K Debt Plan
abstract: LEAD: The Circle K Corporation, the nation's second-largest chain of convenience stores, said today that it had reached an agreement with lenders to restructure part of its $1.3 billion debt. It said the agreement was with its bank lenders, holders of $200 million in senior secured notes and the American Financial Corporation, Circle K's largest shareholder and a creditor.

headline: Talking Deals;   The Slowdown In Bank Mergers
abstract: LEAD: WHEN the Bank of New York acquired the Irving Bank Corporation in 1988, the combination was hailed as an example of the wave of bank mergers that would create a new generation of larger, more profitable banks.

headline: U.S. Debates Aiding Burmese in Drug Fight
abstract: LEAD: With nearly half the world's opium now being grown in Myanmar, formerly Burma, and increasing amounts of Southeast Asian heroin going to the United States, a squabble has broken out between the State Department and the Drug Enforcement Administration over whether to renew ties and financing to the Burmese military Government, Western diplomats and law-enforcement authorities say.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Uzbek Leader Pleads for Moscow's Aid on Unrest
abstract: LEAD: The President of Soviet Uzbekistan said today that ethnic violence was spreading to his republic from neighboring Kirghizia and he asked Moscow to help stop skirmishes from degenerating into full-scale conflict in Central Asia.

headline: Socialists Are No Spoilers
abstract: LEAD: West Germany's divided opposition Social Democrats said today that they would not block an economic treaty with East Germany that is scheduled to take effect in three weeks.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   Hungarian Opposition Party Plans Coalition Government
abstract: LEAD: The party that finished first in this week's elections said today that it hoped to form Hungary's first non-Communist government in four decades by mid-May.

headline: American Financial In Circle K Filing
abstract: LEAD: The American Financial Corporation said it might exercise its right to name two more directors to the board of the troubled Circle K Corporation. Circle K, the Phoenix-based chain of convenience stores, filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code earlier this month, after it failed to pay overdue interest to its bondholders.

headline: Procter & Gamble TV Ads
abstract: LEAD: The Spanish-language television network Telemundo and the Procter & Gamble Company, the consumer-products giant, said yesterday that they would begin a half-hour program today in which Procter's products would be prominently featured as solutions to a variety of common domestic problems.

headline: Debt Is Squeezing Hotels in China
abstract: LEAD: Crippled by the collapse of the tourism industry, foreign-financed hotels across the country are struggling to meet their debt payments.

headline: Stake Is Sold By Alleghany
abstract: LEAD: After nearly three years of seeking permission to raise its 8.9 percent stake in the St. Paul Companies, the Alleghany Corporation is selling its 4.4 million shares back to St. Paul for a market value of $260.7 million, plus $5 million in expenses.

headline: Soviet Party Official Denies Plans for Total Blockade of Lithuania
abstract: LEAD: A senior Soviet Communist Party official denied today that the Kremlin was planning a total blockade of Lithuania.

headline: Nepalese Police Reported to Fire On Political Dissidents, Killing 5
abstract: LEAD: The police opened fire today on protesters demanding legalization of political parties in Nepal, killing at least 5 people and wounding 17, hospital workers and witnesses said.

headline: Rising Iron Curtain Exposes Haunting Veil of Polluted Air
abstract: LEAD: In the depths of a salt mine in Poland, men, women and children lie in bed, bundled in coats and tugging at heavy blankets. In an upside-down world, they have come to this underground clinic to breathe clean and healing air.

headline: Move to Ease Trust Law
abstract: LEAD: In a move meant to strengthen the competitiveness of United States business, the Bush Administration proposed legislation today that would ease antitrust restrictions on joint production ventures between American companies.

headline: Chrysler Shifts Top Management
abstract: LEAD: A day after the abrupt resignation of the Chrysler Corporation's No. 2 executive, the auto maker swiftly realigned top management today but did so in a way that appeared to add to uncertainty about who would succeed Lee A. Iacocca as chairman and chief executive.

headline: Wall Street;   In April, the 'Sell' Signals Were Right
abstract: LEAD: SeveraL months back, a market forecaster in Chicago named Robert P. Moseson started warning his institutional clients to avoid the stock market during April. Unless there's a handsome rally tomorrow, it was certainly sound advice.

headline: Soviet Thaw With Seoul: What Is Real Depends on Whom You Listen To
abstract: LEAD: Within moments of the end of his meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Monday, the South Korean President, Roh Tae Woo, was broadcasting a message of victory back home, declaring that ''the cold war ice on the Korean peninsula has now begun to crack'' and predicting the imminent establishment of diplomatic relations with Moscow.

headline: All About: Discount Brokers;   Now Fewer Firms Are Chasing Small Investors Discount Brokers
abstract: LEAD: Like most of their more glamorous Wall Street cousins, discount brokers have never fully rebounded from the 1987 stock market crash. They are uniquely dependent on the small investor, who remains stubbornly aloof even as the market reaches new heights. While a few firms continue to profit, the industry is being buffeted by consolidation and change.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Slovaks Pressing Czechs For an Equal Partnership
abstract: LEAD: When Slovaks took to the streets in April to demand equal billing in their country's name, many Czechs found the idea of a change ridiculous.

headline: Text of Statement at South African Talks
abstract: LEAD: Following is the text of the statement issued today at the conclusion of a meeting between the South African Government and the African National Congress:

headline: Home Resales Fell in April
abstract: LEAD: Sales of existing homes fell by 2.1 percent in April, the third drop in four months as mortgage rates remained high, a real estate trade group reported today.

headline: Arafat, in Geneva, Calls on U.N. To Send Force to Occupied Areas
abstract: LEAD: Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, urged the United Nations Security Council today to send a new international force to the Israel-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip to protect Palestinians and pave the way for eventual Israeli withdrawal.

headline: President's Post Added At Kemper Securities
abstract: LEAD: Thomas E. Meade was named yesterday to the newly created position of president and chief operating officer of the Kemper Securities Group. In his new position, Mr. Meade will oversee the activities of the Kemper Corporation's group of regional brokerage firms.

headline: Oil Deal By Soviets And French
abstract: LEAD: In a move that seemed to reflect Moscow's concern about falling energy exports, the Soviet Union today signed its first oil exploration and production agreement with a Western company, the state-owned Elf Aquitaine of France.

headline: Fiat Deal Rumors Lift Chrysler Stock
abstract: LEAD: The shares of the Chrysler Corporation rose amid speculation about a possible link between the American auto maker and Fiat S.p.A. of Italy. Chrysler confirmed it was in discussions with Fiat but would not provide details. Fiat would not discuss the rumors.

headline: Lippincott Sale Seen By Harper
abstract: LEAD: Harper Collins, the publishing subsidiary of Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, announced yesterday that it would sell its J. B Lippincott unit as part of an effort to raise about $500 million to reduce Harper's debt.

headline: How 'Fuzzy Logic' Improves TV Clarity
abstract: LEAD: Compared with high-definition television and its movie-like clarity, standard television technology seems a bit bland. But the Sony Corporation has recently developed a computer circuitry for its top-of-the-line set, the Trinitron XBR, that it says markedly improves screen clarity.

headline: Lean Beef at Hardee's
abstract: LEAD: Hardee's Food Systems Inc. today announced the debut of a light hamburger sandwich called the Lean 1. The hamburger is the lowest-fat quarter-pound burger offered as a standard-menu item by any national fast-food chain, company officials said. According to Bill Prather, Hardee's president and chief executive officer, the Lean 1 is made entirely from American beef and contains an average of 18 grams of total fat, which is about 30 percent less than the chain's other quarter-pound hamburgers.

headline: F.C.C. Finds Phone-Rule Violations
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Communications Commission announced yesterday that it had documented widespread abuses in the operation of pay telephones and guest room phones at hotels and other institutions.

headline: Jump in Industrial Output Seen as Temporary
abstract: LEAD: Industrial production jumped by six-tenths of 1 percent in May, the Federal Reserve reported today, but analysts said the sharp increase was mainly because of a temporary buildup in automobile inventories.

headline: MALAYSIA ACCUSED ON BOAT PEOPLE
abstract: LEAD: Despite continued protests from the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, Malaysia is turning away Vietnamese boat people with increasing frequency, diplomats and international relief workers say.

headline: New Shearson Official Expects Brighter Days
abstract: LEAD: Jonathan S. Linen, named yesterday, as expected, to oversee Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.'s brokerage and investment management divisions, said he was too new to the job to say how the securities firm might be rejuvenated. But imbued with the optimisim that came with his succcess as a top executive at the American Express Company, Mr.

headline: Accounting Group Urged To Admit Non-C.P.A.'s
abstract: LEAD: A special committee of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants has urged the organization to admit people other than certified public accountants for the first time.

headline: U.S. Reports April Surplus
abstract: LEAD: A surge in income tax payments helped the Government set a record budget surplus of $42.52 billion in April, one month after a record monthly deficit, the Treasury Department reported today.

headline: New President Chosen At Deprenyl of Toronto
abstract: LEAD: Deprenyl Research Ltd., a Toronto company that has received approval to market a drug to treat Parkinson's disease in Canada, has named James P. Doherty, a seasoned pharmaceutical industry executive, as its new president and chief operating officer.

headline: Leaders of Lithuania Meet With Gorbachev
abstract: LEAD: The President and the Prime Minister of Lithuania flew to Moscow today to meet with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union on the deadlock over the Baltic republic's declaration of independence.

headline: LITHUANIA IS ASKED BY PARIS AND BONN TO HALT DECISIONS
abstract: LEAD: France and West Germany jointly urged Lithuania today to suspend its Parliament's moves toward independence and to seek negotiations with Moscow with a view to finding ''a solution acceptable to all parties.''

headline: Money Fund Assets Off
abstract: LEAD: The assets of the nation's 509 money market mutual funds decreased by $2.14 billion, to $385.72 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 161 institutional funds increased by $1.71 billion, to $92.32 billion. The assets of the 246 general-purpose funds were down by $912.60 million, to $132.70 billion.

headline: Brokers Press For Standards
abstract: LEAD: Representatives of securities dealers in the United States and four other nations have agreed to work toward international standards for settling trades.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   Li Peng to Visit Gorbachev
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Li Peng will visit the Soviet Union from April 23 to April 26, becoming the first Chinese head of government to travel to Moscow since 1964, the Foreign Ministry said today. Mr. Li was invited to the Soviet Union last May, when President Mikhail S. Gorbachev made the first trip to Beijing by a Soviet leader in three decades.

headline: Befouled to Its Romantic Depths, Danube Reaches a Turning Point
abstract: LEAD: Swollen and pearly gray, the Danube makes a spectacular turn here, pushing into gentle woodlands as it surges south toward Budapest. It is the river at its most seductive: winding through the valleys of Central Europe, where it has inspired poets and composers and generations of painters who still work on its banks today.

headline: British Jet Down Off Sardinia
abstract: LEAD: A British military jet taking part in a NATO exercise crashed 20 miles southwest of Sardinia shortly before dawn today. Searchers found the wreckage of the plane, an AV-8 Harrier, but the pilot was missing and presumed dead, a British Defense Ministry official said. The cause of the crash was not known.

headline: Money Fund Assets Off
abstract: LEAD: The assets of the nation's 508 money market mutual funds decreased by $1.25 billion, to $388.6 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 160 institutional funds decreased by $1.02 billion, to $90.23 billion. The assets of the 246 general-purpose funds were down by $467.30 million, to $133.05 billion.

headline: Threats From 3 Already Rattle Shamir's Coalition
abstract: LEAD: Acting Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's proposed new governing coalition appeared in danger of unraveling tonight when three members of Mr. Shamir's party told him that he could not count on their votes because they had not been offered posts in the government.

headline: The Executive Computer;   'Little Black Boxes' That Can Save a Hard Disk
abstract: LEAD: When mainframes and minicomputers first arrived in corporations, they were typically accompanied by small armies of white-coated lab technicians. These high priests kept the computers humming and tried to support the people who waited in line to tap their wisdom. Years later, when microcomputers started appearing on everyone's desk, the computer support staffs did not grow proportionately.

headline: ASSEMBLY ACCEPTS SHAMIR'S COALITION
abstract: LEAD: The Israeli Parliament narrowly approved Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's new right-wing Government tonight after a day of suspense over whether he could count on his party's full support.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * Taj International Hotels, to Lipman, Richmond, Greene Advertising.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;  Long Island Monthly Closing After May Issue
abstract: LEAD: Long Island Monthly is the latest casualty of the magazine industry's shakeout. Just a week after 7 Days closed, CMP Publications, the publisher of Long Island Monthly, announced that the magazine's May issue would be its last.

abstract: LEAD: Movement toward compromise on the Baltic republics' campaign for independence stopped today, as Lithuania rejected demands to suspend its declaration of independence and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev warned all three Baltic republics that they must abide by Soviet law.

headline: Lack of Ads Kills 7 Days Magazine
abstract: LEAD: Just two years after it was started with great fanfare, 7 Days magazine has ceased publishing.

headline: Sallie Mae Chief Takes A Post at Dartmouth
abstract: LEAD: Edward A. Fox, who built the Student Loan Marketing Association into a major financial enterprise, is leaving as its president and chief executive to become dean of the Amos Tuck School of Business at Dartmouth University.

abstract: LEAD: * Glenn E. Corlett has joined Ayer as chief financial officer.

headline: Ford and Fiat Discuss Farm Equipment Units
abstract: LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said today that it was negotiating with Fiat about possible ''worldwide arrangements'' involving their tractor and farm equipment operations.

headline: Keating Sues His Insurers
abstract: LEAD: Charles H. Keating Jr. and his law firm have sued a group of insurance companies for legal costs incurred in defending lawsuits related to the failure of the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association.

abstract: LEAD: President F. W. de Klerk confronted a delegation from the far right of white South Africa's political spectrum today and left its angry representatives convinced that he was determined to share some power with the African National Congress.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Airbus Industrie, Paris, the European aircraft consortium, said Iraqi Airways would buy five of its A310-300 jets and would take options on five additional planes, for an undisclosed price.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Shevardnadze Seeks Curbs On Forces in New Germany
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union proposed unexpectedly today that an international endorsement of German unity include provisions for a staged withdrawal of all foreign troops from a united Germany and strict limits on its military.

headline: Posner Discloses Move by Guilford
abstract: LEAD: Victor Posner, the Miami financier, said he had been approached by the senior management of Guilford Mills Inc. about ''a possible business combination'' with the Graniteville Company, a private South Carolina textile manufacturer that Mr. Posner acquired in 1982. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr.

headline: Mexico Asks For Trade Pact
abstract: LEAD: President Carlos Salinas de Gortari called today for a free-trade agreement with the United States and said Mexico would also consider a similar accord with Canada.      But he rejected a North

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Bang & Olufsen A.S., Denmark, which makes audio-visual products, said Philips Consumer Electronics International B.V., the Netherlands, would buy 25 percent of the total capital shares of Bang & Olufsen Holding A.S. for $50 million, double the shares' face value.

headline: A Novel Way to Sell Books: More Titles, Learned Clerks
abstract: LEAD: After a decade marked by the rapid growth of book chains selling mainly best sellers, a quiet revolution has begun. Emerging out of it are an increasing number of comfortable, expertly staffed bookstores with an immense range of titles.

headline: Omens of Intolerance Among Cairo's Muslims
abstract: LEAD: At dusk the streets are empty and the traffic dies down and a calm settles on this most rambunctious of cities, for this is Ramadan, the Muslim month of daytime fasting that represents one of Islam's sacred duties.

headline: Teetering on the High Wire in Brazil
abstract: LEAD: Two months after taking office, President Fernando Collor de Mello is fast approaching the moment of truth for his plan to integrate Brazil into the world economy.

headline: Japan's Personal Savings
abstract: LEAD: The Japanese are saving more than ever despite American demands that the country reduce its emphasis on thrift. Personal savings in Japan grew by 71.6 trillion yen, or about $468 billion, in the fiscal year that ended in March, to reach a record high of 713.5 trillion yen ($4.66 trillion).

headline: If the News Is Bad, Silence the Messenger
abstract: LEAD: Sy Jacobs, a Wall Street analyst, knew that the executives at Household International Inc. would not be pleased after he advised clients in February to sell the company's stock. What he did not expect was the silent treatment.

headline: Europeans to Consider Proposal on Economic Help for Soviet Union
abstract: LEAD: The 12 European Community heads of government, meeting in Dublin next week, will consider a proposal for aid to help the Soviet Union overcome its deepening economic crisis, according to diplomats and government officials.

abstract: LEAD: * Chiquita Brands International to W. B. Doner & Company, for its blended fruit juices.

headline: Eastern Plan for Creditors
abstract: LEAD: The president of Eastern Airlines is expected to outline a new proposal today aimed at persuading unsecured creditors to back away from their tough stand of last week, a person close to the creditors said.

headline: Most Stock Advisers Failed To Match S.&P. in Quarter
abstract: LEAD: The first quarter proved a tough one for the nation's investment advisers, with most failing to match the total return of the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks.

abstract: LEAD: NOT long ago, Alan J. Gottesman, an advertising analyst for Paine Webber Inc., was musing about the agencies best positioned for global expansion. headline: Lin Seeks Change In Cellular Deal
abstract: LEAD: The Lin Broadcasting Corporation said it had entered talks with the Metromedia Company to modify the terms of Lin's pending acquisition of Metromedia's 46 percent interest in the cellular telephone system serving New York City. headline: Evolution in Europe: Gorbachev's Game;   The Soviets Must Make Things Hard Or Risk More Calls for Independence
abstract: LEAD: In closing the energy tap on rebellious Lithuania, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is struggling with a far larger sovereignty crisis than the one presented by the resilient Baltic republic.

abstract: LEAD:    General Assembly       DISARMAMENT COMMISSION - 10 A.M.       Economic and Social Council       SOCIAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: O.A.S. Cautions Mexicans on Election Fraud
abstract: LEAD: Responding to allegations by opposition political parties of widespread electoral fraud here, the Organization of American States has warned the Mexican Government ''it must comply exactly with the obligation to guarantee the free and full exercise of political rights.''

headline: Currency;   Losing Steam at the Close
abstract: LEAD: The dollar fizzled as the week ended. It closed slightly lower against the German mark, after managing to trade at times above the key level of 1.70 marks to the dollar. Dealers said the dollar still appeared to be locked in a fairly narrow band of trading, despite the release of a slew of economic indicators in the United States.

headline: Singapore Journal;   'Nightmare Death' Fells Thais, and Nations Bicker
abstract: LEAD: A medical mystery about why young workers from Thailand should be dying in their sleep in Singapore has turned into an emotional debate about their living conditions in this wealthy city-state, straining relations between the countries.

headline: Cubans Parade Hardware to Jam TV Marti
abstract: LEAD: President Fidel Castro has opened his country up to the foreign press this week for a glimpse at what Cuban officials describe as a nascent war of the airwaves.

headline: Arms Sales to Third World Said to Decline Sharply
abstract: LEAD: Arms sales to the third world decreased sharply last year as the United States, the Soviet Union, China, France and Britain found fewer buyers for their weapons, the Congressional Research Service reported today.

headline: A Glitch in the System Halts Five New York Exchanges
abstract: LEAD: Trading was halted for more than three hours yesterday at five New York futures and options exchanges because of a communications glitch that was believed to have been caused by an electrical short in some damaged cables.

headline: Norway Sets Up Fund for Oil Revenue
abstract: LEAD: Worried that huge North Sea energy wealth has lulled it into laziness, Norway's Parliament has decided to siphon oil and gas revenues out of the budget and into a special fund.

headline: BUCHAREST BLOCKS KING FROM VISITING
abstract: LEAD: King Michael, who was forced from his throne by the Communists in 1947, was barred from the country today after the Romanian Government withdrew his visa.

headline: 5 Western European Countries To Establish a Common Border
abstract: LEAD: France, West Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg agreed today to allow the free movement of people across their borders in a step toward the elimination of all frontiers in the 12-nation European Community by 1993.

headline: G.M. Shifting Some Output
abstract: LEAD: The General Motors Corporation today annnounced plans to shift production of the Chevrolet Camaro and Pontiac Firebird models to a Canadian plant in Ste. Therese, Quebec, from its factory in Van Nuys, Calif.

headline: Tokyo Call Warrants Are Offered on Amex
abstract: LEAD: Two international financial institutions signaled yesterday that they were ready to bet that the Tokyo stock market, after some of its worst days in history, had bottomed out.

headline: Varian Begins A Revamping
abstract: LEAD: Varian Associates Inc., which manufactures electron devices and analytical instruments, said today that it would sell some non-core operations and product lines to improve performance.

headline: Technology;   The Phone Company Untangles Its Lifelines
abstract: LEAD: Simple diagrams of how a local telephone call reaches its destination usually show a line from the customer to a telephone company switch, and then another line from the switch to the desired party.

headline: WORLD COURT PLAN MEETS DIFFICULTIES
abstract: LEAD: An attempt by the United States and the Soviet Union to expand the authority of the World Court has run into difficulties, with Britain and other critics contending that the initiative might reduce the role of international law rather than enhance it.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Publishing;   The World Is Often Too Much to Grasp
abstract: LEAD: AS big publishing houses have gone on an international buying spree, ''globalization'' has become the buzzword of the industry. But now, some people are wondering whether there are really that many advantages in being a worldwide book business.

headline: Havel's Movement Seen Winning Majority Control in Parliament
abstract: LEAD: President Vaclav Havel's citizens' movement, which swept the Communists from power last November, completed its victory today by winning majorities in both houses of Parliament in Czechoslovakia's first free elections since 1946, official forecasts indicated.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: LEAD: * John H. Harland Co., Atlanta, a printing company, named Robert R. Woodson chief executive. He replaces J. William Robinson, who remains chairman.

headline: Eurotunnel Cost Estimate Up Again
abstract: LEAD: Eurotunnel, the British-French company, today raised its estimate again for the cost of completing the channel tunnel and predicted that the rail line linking France and England would cost as much as $:7.5 billion, or about $12.27 billion.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Avery International Corp., Pasadena, Calif., a manufacturer of office products and specialty chemicals, announced the retirement of Richard J. Pearson as president and chief operating officer, effective July 1. Charles D. Miller, chairman and chief executive, will take the additional title of president.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Aztar Corp., Phoenix, a casino gaming company, said it would make discretionary purchases of up to two million shares of its common stock, or about 5 percent of the shares outstanding.

headline: Zulus' Buthelezi: Statesman or Scoundrel, He'll Count in Pretoria's Future
abstract: LEAD: Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi, the most powerful political leader of the Zulus, South Africa's largest ethnic group, is a man with regal bearing - charismatic, proud, intolerant of criticism, and widely admired or detested.

headline: House Approves More Assistance for East Europe
abstract: LEAD: The House of Representatives approved a $15.6 billion foreign aid package today that would reduce United States military assistance to its allies for the 1991 fiscal year and would increase spending on the emerging democracies in Eastern Europe.

headline: After the Summit;   Gorbachev at Stanford: Excerpts From Address
abstract: LEAD: Following are excerpts from President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's address at Stanford University yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of Cable News Network. Mr. Gorbachev spoke through an interpreter.       Imagining Destiny

headline: Market Place;   First Chicago Action Questioned
abstract: LEAD: Last Thursday's announcement by the First Chicago Corporation that a small number of its major real estate loans had gone bad further depressed the bank-holding company's stock. It closed today at $29 a share, down from $49 less than a year ago.

headline: CONGRESS HOLDS UP PART OF U.N. DUES
abstract: LEAD: Congress is withholding part of the United States' 1989 dues to the United Nations and its specialized agencies to offset emergency expenses caused by the California earthquake and Hurricane Hugo. The delay comes despite President Bush's recommendation that Washington pay the dues in full.

headline: Burmese Party Is Prevented From Election Campaigning
abstract: LEAD: Burmese military leaders have disrupted opposition campaigning for this month's multiparty elections by arresting officials of the major party, diplomats there said today.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Sosa Takes The Off Path To Success
abstract: LEAD: ONLY days away from completing the sale of 49 percent of his agency to D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, Lionel Sosa was overflowing with enthusiasm. From his San Antonio home, he came to New York last week to meet his new partner's Latin American executives.

headline: LITHUANIA AGREES TO 100-DAY DELAY ON INDEPENDENCE
abstract: LEAD: Lithuania agreed today to suspend its declaration of independence for 100 days in exchange for negotiations with Moscow and the lifting of economic sanctions.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: LEAD: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.       Monday     None       Tuesday    Housing Starts . . . May       Wednesday     None       Thursday     G.N.P. . . . 1st Qtr.     Corporate Profits . . . 1st Qtr.       Friday     Durable Goods .

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Magazines Sold
abstract: LEAD: Capital Cities/ABC has agreed to sell the magazines Compute!, Compute's Gazette, Compute's PC and Compute's Amiga Resource to General Media International, whose other titles include Omni and Penthouse. Terms were not disclosed. General Media said it would reduce the frequency of Compute!, a monthly, and would ''evaluate'' the other three computer magazines.

headline: Ciba-Geigy Unit
abstract: LEAD: Ciba-Geigy Ltd. of Switzerland said it had agreed to sell its Spectra-Physics subsidiary to Pharos A.B. of Sweden for an undisclosed amount. Spectra-Physics, which makes lasers and laser systems, had sales of $324 million in 1989. Ciba-Geigy said it expects to continue cooperative business arrangements with Spectra-Physics in the chemistry field.

headline: Deficit Posted By Philippines
abstract: LEAD: The Philippine balance of payments showed a large deficit in the first three months of 1990, as imports surged and money to pay back the country's large foreign debt flowed out, the central bank said today.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Abraham & Straus, New York, a unit of Campeau Corp., promoted Rita Steffee to senior vice president for visual merchandising presentation.

headline: Bank Revamping In New England
abstract: LEAD: The Bank of New England Corporation announced plans to sell or consolidate more than 95 branch offices to help streamline the financially troubled company. A spokesman, James Dorsey, declined to disclose the value of the assets involved or the amount the company hopes to make from the sales. He said about 450 employees would be affected.

headline: Some Smog in Pledges To Help Environment
abstract: LEAD: On the bottom of the paperboard container that McDonald's uses for its hash-brown potatoes is the three-arrow symbol that generally denotes a product made of recycled material, and the words ''Recyclable Paper.'' But McDonald's officials concede that the package is not made of recycled paper, is not being recycled and may not even be capable of being recycled because of a promotional label glued to the back.

headline: Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week
abstract: LEAD: Treasury financings this week are confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

headline: Real Estate;   Pressures In the Flower District
abstract: LEAD: NEW YORK CITY'S flower market district, a bright spot since the 1890's in the often dour countenance of midtown Manhattan, is fighting for its life under pressure from urban planners, developers and the high value of midtown land.

headline: U.S. Security Prices Are Stable
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities were essentially unchanged yesterday after moderate losses earlier in the day were erased toward the close. The declines after the opening in New York followed earlier weakness in the Tokyo and London markets for Treasury debt issues.

headline: Angola Railway Attacks Hit the Starving Hardest
abstract: LEAD: The train lurched, screeched and shuddered to a halt. ''Bandits!'' a conductor screamed, but a crackle of gunfire from both sides of the track kept the passengers from scattering.

headline: Poland Receives Loan
abstract: LEAD: The World Bank is providing a $250 million loan to help Poland develop natural gas. The new non-Communist Government of Poland has received $781 million in loans from the bank. The loan for natural gas is repayable in 15 years.

headline: Generics Case Guilty Pleas
abstract: LEAD: A former Food and Drug Administration official and a generic drug company pleaded guilty Friday to racketeering and illegal payment charges stemming from an investigation of fraud in the generic drug industry.

headline: Poland's 'Big Bang': Too Much Too Fast?
abstract: LEAD: I have just returned from Poland where I met with many of its leading economists and politicians. From the vantage point of the United States, it may look like that country's commitment to a quick transition to a market economy, which some call the ''big bang,'' is universal. But my discussion with economists and politicans in Warsaw, revealed that some

headline: CHOOSING A NEW ROMANIAN LEADER
abstract: LEAD:    THE PARTIES

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   People
abstract: LEAD: * Roger W. Yost has been appointed vice president for advertising and sales promotion at Jantzen.

headline: Hundreds Rally in Mongolia As Their Leader Tours China
abstract: LEAD: About 1,000 Mongolians demonstrated today in support of pro-democracy protesters staging a sit-in in the capital, and hunger strikers in other parts of the country fasted through an eighth day.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Soviet Aide Rejects Notion That Military Opposes Gorbachev
abstract: LEAD: A top aide to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev denied today that the Soviet leader faced a challenge from the military, but the aide condemned ''ultrarightists,'' who he said were working to destroy reform.

headline: BANK OF ISRAEL EASING RULES ON CURRENCY
abstract: LEAD: The Bank of Israel said today that it would relax its tough currency restrictions to allow companies to strengthen their trade ties through foreign investments.

headline: Salvador and Rebels Agree to New Talks
abstract: LEAD: Representatives of El Salvador's United States-backed Government and the rebel movement opposing it signed an agreement here today to resume talks to end the country's civil war.

headline: Treasuries Fall in Light Trading
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds sagged in thin trading yesterday, pushed down by a report from the National Association of Purchasing Managers that the economy's manufacturing sector had improved in April.

headline: Smokers Should Not Have to Hide
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Lawmakers See No Shift By Bush on Raising Taxes
abstract: LEAD: Ask a Republican on Capitol Hill whether the Bush Administration is ready to talk seriously about raising taxes, and the answer is yes, as part of a bigger budget deal. Ask a Democrat the same question and the answer is no, any such idea is a political trap. Ask the Administration, and the answers are a bit of both and largely off the record.

headline: Lionel to Ketchum
abstract: LEAD: Lionel Leisure Inc., the toy retailer, has awarded Ketchum Advertising in Philadelphia the creative portion of the accounts for its Lionel Kiddie City and Lionel Playworld. Ketchum replaces LevLane Advertising, Bala-Cynwyd, Pa. Lee Media will continue to do the media buying for the accounts, which have a broadcast budget of $6 million to $8 million.

headline: Amatex Corp.
abstract: LEAD: The Amatex Corporation, a privately held manufacturer of fire-resistant textiles, said it had emerged from bankruptcy and that independent trust funds had been established to handle all asbestos claims against the company. Amatex, based in Norristown, Pa., at one time used asbestos in its products.

headline: S.C.I. Is Selling Insurance Unit
abstract: LEAD: The Service Corporation International, the world's largest funeral services company whose earnings have been hurt by a slowing mortality rate, said it would sell its insurance subsidiary to the Torchmark Corporation for $165 million.

headline: World Markets;  Deutsche Bank's Self-Deprecating Style
abstract: LEAD: To hear the executives at Deutsche Bank A.G. describe the institution's financial health, one would think West Germany's largest commercial bank was plugging steadily along, somehow managing to eke out higher earnings in a business fraught with more perils than prospects.

headline: OVERSIZED TAXES FOR THE MIDDLE CLASS?
abstract: LEAD: One of Washington's annual springtime rites is the required Congressional budget resolution. This year, the debate will encompass many things, but a centerpiece will be the proposal by many leading figures in Congress to raise tax rates for the rich, starting with the infamous ''bubble.'' The bubble is, of course, the anomaly in the income tax code that has marginal tax rates rising to 33 percent for taxpayers at roughly the $75,000 level, then dropping back down to 28 percent for those with incomes over roughly $200,000.

headline: U.S. Doubts on Gorbachev
abstract: LEAD: Moscow's hard line in Lithuania and tough arms-control stance in last week's talks have revived doubts in Washington about Mikhail S. Gorbachev's future. News analysis, page 15.

headline: Profits Rise For Lilly And Upjohn
abstract: LEAD: Eli Lilly & Company and the Upjohn Company reported gains in first-quarter earnings yesterday.

headline: Disney Cites Survey on Theater Ads
abstract: LEAD: The Walt Disney Company today defended its policy of banning commercials on movie screens before its pictures are shown by releasing a study that concludes that 90 percent of moviegoers do not want commercials in theaters.

headline: Bidder Sees 2 Years of Losses for Bonwit
abstract: LEAD: Providing new details of its $20 million offer for five Bonwit Teller stores, the Pyramid Companies, the Northeast's largest builder of shopping malls, said it expected the stores to lose about $17 million in the first two years.

headline: Notes Are Priced For Asian Bank
abstract: LEAD: Underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. yesterday priced $300 million in notes issued by the Asian Development Bank.

headline: Chrysler Pact With Honda To Sell Jeeps
abstract: LEAD: The Honda Motor Company Ltd. has agreed to make part of its dealer network in Japan available to the Chrysler Corporation to sell two Jeep sport-utility vehicles, the companies said today.

headline: All About/Texas Real Estate;   A Glut of Office Space Turns Enticing
abstract: LEAD: Texas real estate people, dazed after the debacle of the 1980's, are now daring to brag of a rebound. The office market in the Northeast came back, so why not Texas, they ask. ''I really believe that great fortunes will be made over the next decade in Texas real estate to rival when Olympia & York made their big hit in New York in the 1970's,'' said Charles G.

headline: Israeli Held in Massacre Says He Sought Revenge for Rape
abstract: LEAD: The Israeli who confessed to killing seven Palestinian workers last month, touching off a chain of rioting, death and terrorism, now says the massacre was a premeditated act of personal revenge for a gang rape he suffered at the age of 12.

headline: Ethnic Warfare Grows in Soviet Asia, With Toll at 48 in One City
abstract: LEAD: Ethnic warfare in Central Asia continued to grow today as mobs roamed the capital of the republic of Kirghizia demanding that the local government resign and armed militants reportedly massed on the Uzbek border.

headline: Turner Plans Latin Network
abstract: LEAD: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. will start an entertainment-oriented cable television network in Latin America next January, Ted Turner, the company's chairman, said Wednesday.

headline: Patents;   Are Disputes Too Complex For Juries?
abstract: LEAD: The failure of a jury to agree this week on damages for Robert W. Kearns, the inventor of the intermittent windshield wiper, has lent new vigor to the debate about the role of juries in deciding complex patent disputes.

headline: In Bulgaria, Hard Times Are Harder
abstract: LEAD: The economy of Bulgaria is in bad shape.

headline: Recycled Paper Is Not the Only, or Best, Answer
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Black & Decker Corp., Towson, Md., named Michael L. Convey president and general manager of Price Pfister, a division of the company's hardware and home improvement group.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Fallon a Big Winner
abstract: LEAD: Fallon McElligott took top honors at the Art Directors Club annual Gold and Silver Awards show Tuesday. The agency won 13 awards for clients like Hush Puppies, Jim Beam, Porsche and Rolling Stone magazine, which also won big on the editorial side. Its art director, Fred Woodward, won 17 awards. BBDO led the television category with six awards.

headline: Despite Sanctions, Steel From Pretoria Is Entering the U.S.
abstract: LEAD: The Bush Administration has allowed thousands of tons of South African iron and steel into the United States because of the way it has interpreted a 1986 sanctions law intended by its sponsors to ban such imports.

headline: Chairman Quits Great Northern
abstract: LEAD: The chairman of the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation, William R. Laidig, who led the paper company's unsuccessful effort to fend off the Georgia-Pacific Corporation, left the company today with a lucrative severance package.      A company spokesman said

headline: 2 Rival Computer Groups Break Off Talks on Merger
abstract: LEAD: Two rival computer-industry groups trying to set software standards said today that they had broken off merger talks.

headline: Columbia Savings Move
abstract: LEAD: The Columbia Savings and Loan Association said today that its chief financial officer, David A. Sachs, had resigned effective May 11 to pursue other opportunities. Edward G. Harshfield, Columbia's chief executive, will serve as acting chief financial officer until a successor is named. Mr. Sachs took on the position in January after serving as executive vice president.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Banner Industries, Cleveland, a diversified industrial company, said it would sell its Thompson Aircraft Tire Corp. subsidiary for an undisclosed sum. Further details were not disclosed.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD: * George Constantinoff, director of medical and scientific affairs at Klemtner Advertising, has been promoted to executive vice president, as has Robert Brilliant, the company's chief financial and administrative officer.

headline: Bankruptcy Court to Assess Validity of Revco Takeover
abstract: LEAD: A United States bankruptcy court yesterday appointed a law professor to answer the novel question of whether the leveraged buyout of Revco D.S. Inc. in 1986 was so poorly constructed that the company was essentially bankrupt from the moment the buyout was completed.

headline: Hard Times for Pretoria's Police
abstract: LEAD: The impartiality and competence of the South African police are being subjected to public scrutiny after violence Sunday in a gold-mining area that left 11 people dead and 91 wounded, according to latest reports today.

headline: Port-au-Prince Journal;   A Hospice Gives Testimony to AIDS's Rising Toll
abstract: LEAD: Past the huge mound of rotting garbage that stands in the place of a long-toppled statue of Francois Duvalier, to the muddiest recesses of a neighborhood called Sans Fil, threadbare Haitians come by the dozens to die.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   Nothing but Nice Things to Say of Gorbachev
abstract: LEAD: A week after the Kremlin barred foreign correspondents from the crisis in Lithuania, they were invited today to get their news directly from the new office of the presidential press secretary and its inaugural occupant, Arkady Maslennikov.

headline: Britain Accepts Rover Ruling
abstract: LEAD: Britain said today that it had accepted a judgment by the European Community's Executive Commission against the Government's aid to British Aerospace P.L.C. in the sale of the state-owned Rover automobile group.      Trade Secretary Nicholas

headline: Mortgage Rates Rise
abstract: LEAD: Fixed-rate home mortgages averaged 10.67 percent this week, their highest rate since May 1989, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. Last week they were at 10.56 percent. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.62 percent this week, up from 8.56 percent the week before.

headline: For Trump, Seeds of a Comeback
abstract: LEAD: Donald J. Trump has lost his aura, and a substantial amount of management freedom. But he has maintained his ownership of 100 percent of his empire. And in that small victory could lie the seeds of a comeback for the battered developer.

headline: Fed Official On Inflation
abstract: LEAD: A Federal Reserve governor, John P. LaWare, said today that the nation's high inflation rate in the first quarter might have been an aberration.

headline: Lithuania Pays the Price And Acquires a Stoicism
abstract: LEAD: By squeezing Lithuania's economic lifeline, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev may have brought his conflict with the errant republic closer to compromise, but many Lithuanians say his embargo has had another, unintended effect: the quick maturing of an independent Lithuania.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * ANR Freight System Inc., Denver, a subsidiary of the Coastal Corp., Houston, announced the resignation of Joseph F. DeBella, its president. The company named Larry R. Jouett executive vice president and chief operating officer.

headline: Top Executive Retires At Citizens Utilities
abstract: LEAD: In a long-planned move, Ishier Jacobson, president and chief executive of the Citizens Utilities Company, yesterday announced his retirement after more than 35 years with the company. Daryl A. Ferguson, senior vice president for operations and engineering, will replace him as president and chief operating officer, but the chief executive position remains vacant.

headline: Labor Party Makes Big Gains In Local Elections in Britain
abstract: LEAD: The governing Conservative Party suffered another setback today as British voters gave strong support to the opposition Labor Party in nationwide local elections.

headline: Chamorro to Cut Army by a Third, With Sandinista General's Assent
abstract: LEAD: President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro of Nicaragua announced today that she had ordered a one-third reduction in the size of the Nicaraguan Army, the biggest force in Central America and the most powerful political weapon in the arsenal of the opposition Sandinista Front.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:       Debt

headline: Europeans Come to Aid of English Cathedral
abstract: LEAD: John Lang, Dean of Lichfield, tells visitors that his red sandstone Cathedral of St. Mary and St. Chad crumbles so easily after seven centuries that tiny pieces of it flake off in every downpour.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Walesa Sees a Need to Split Solidarity to Insure Reforms
abstract: LEAD: Lech Walesa said today that his Solidarity labor movement, rocked by a power struggle, must split to insure the success of Poland's reforms.

headline: Compaq Computer
abstract: LEAD: The Compaq Computer Corporation cut the retail prices of its notebook-sized computers in a bid to make the line more accessible to a wider audience. The Houston-based computer maker said the suggested retail price of its LTE/286 model 40 had been reduced to $4,799, from $4,999, and its LTE/286 model 20 cut to $3,999, from $4,499.

headline: Bush Tries to Push Shamir to Peace Talks
abstract: LEAD: President Bush warned today that if he was ''stiff-armed'' by Israel in his effort to help put Israel's own peace plan into effect, he would consider other approaches, ''because we're not going to sit here and do nothing.''

headline: MCA Will Decide On European Park
abstract: LEAD: Executives from MCA Inc., the American entertainment giant, met with the French Prime Minister, Michel Rocard, about the proposed construction of a movie-oriented theme park and studio near Paris to compete with the Walt Disney Company's Euro Disneyland. The MCA delegation is considering Paris and

headline: Court Bars Torchmark From a Proxy Fight
abstract: LEAD: A Federal judge barred the Torchmark Corporation today from waging a proxy fight to gain a foothold on the board of the American General Corporation.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Baker Is Off to Europe, Ready to Sell Soviets on United Germany in NATO
abstract: LEAD: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d leaves for Europe on Wednesday for the first six-nation talks about the future of a united Germany, carrying a briefcase full of ideas that he hopes will help the Soviets accept what the United States sees as inevitable: a unified Germany in NATO.

headline: Home Sales Down 1.6%; Lowest Level Since '82
abstract: LEAD: Sales of new single-family homes fell for the fifth straight month in April to their lowest level in more than seven years, the Commerce Department said today.

headline: Your Own Account;  Picking a Better Credit Card
abstract: LEAD: Americans spend $32 billion a year just to use general-purpose credit cards - for fees, interest and other charges, according to H. Spencer Nilson, publisher of an industry newsletter called The Nilson Report. But, Mr. Nilson says in a new study, they could save at least 25 percent of that by tailoring the cards to their spending habits.

headline: New President Named At Software Toolworks
abstract: LEAD: Software Toolworks Inc., a five-year-old software company in Chatsworth, Calif., has named Elizabeth Barker as president and chief operating officer.

headline: Olivetti Venture
abstract: LEAD: The Italian computer maker Ing. C. Olivetti & C. S.p.A. formed a joint venture with the Yugoslav Energoprojekt Holding Corporation, an engineering and data processing company, to sell Olivetti systems and products in Yugoslavia. Olivetti said its Olivetti System and Networks subsidiary would hold 50 percent of the new venture, to be called Olivetti Energodata, while Energoprojekt would hold a 46 percent stake.

headline: India's Growing Peril: Kashmir and Punjab Separatism
abstract: LEAD: The Indian Government's increasingly shrill accusations that Pakistan is trying to provoke India into another war over Kashmir are diverting attention from the inability of Prime Minister V. P. Singh's Government to stem resurgent tides of secessionism in not one but two strategic border states, Punjab as well as Jammu and

headline: Gorbachev Is 'Pretty Darn Strong,' Bush Declares
abstract: LEAD: President Bush gave President Mikhail S. Gorbachev another vote of confidence today, disagreeing with those who think that the Soviet leader's position is growing more tenuous.

headline: North Korea Faults Roh and Gorbachev
abstract: LEAD: North Korea indirectly lashed out at President Roh Tae Woo of South Korea today for what it said was his ''shameless, flunkyist'' meeting with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in San Francisco on Monday. It also rebuked Moscow in milder terms for embarrassing Pyongyang by meeting with its archenemy in the United

headline: Report on OPEC Production Sends Oil Prices Skidding
abstract: LEAD: Crude oil prices plunged yesterday, largely on a report that OPEC's production had soared to its highest level since 1981. Global demand for oil has also been declining because of the uncommonly mild winter in the Northern Hemisphere as well as softening in the economies of industrial countries.

headline: Outlays in Quarter $1.6 Billion at Ford
abstract: LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said its first-quarter capital spending amounted to $1.6 billion, but the company would not project total spending for 1990. The auto giant's 1989 capital outlays were $6.8 billion, according to its chairman and chief executive, Harold Poling, who spoke at a news conference after the company's annual meeting.

headline: Booksellers Mixed on Fall Outlook
abstract: LEAD: The annual convention of the American Booksellers Association is as much a pep rally for publishers as an occasion to show off their wares for the fall. So it is understandable that many publishers exude optimism despite what others say are troubling times.

headline: Article 972490 -- No Title
abstract: LEAD: In a stock swap deal that would create the world's fourth-largest insurance brokerage, London-based Willis Faber P.L.C. and the New York-based Corroon & Black Corporation today announced plans for a $731.6 million merger.

headline: Top Holder Of Reebok To Sell Stake
abstract: LEAD: Reebok International Ltd., a major producer of athletic footwear, said yesterday that its largest stockholder planned to sell its Reebok shares.

headline: Soviet Military Is Reported To Reassert Itself at Kremlin
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet military, unhappy over President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reforms and its diminished status, is trying to reassert itself in Moscow, specialists from the Rand Corporation said today.

headline: Cadence Acquires Software Company
abstract: LEAD: Cadence Design Systems Inc., a leading producer of software for designing integrated circuits, agreed to acquire Automated Systems Inc. of Milwaukee, which produces printed circuit board design software. The deal, which is structured as a stock swap, is valued at about $23.8 million.

headline: Jeans Makers Settle 7-Year Fraud Case
abstract: LEAD: A seven-year legal battle between two highly successful jeans companies, Guess and Jordache, and the families that run them ended today when the sides reached an out-of-court settlement returning all of Guess to its founders.

headline: A KOREAN DEMAND UNSETTLES JAPAN
abstract: LEAD: Nearly a year and a half after ascending the Chrysanthemum Throne, Emperor Akihito has become entangled in an old dispute over Japan's responsibility for World War II reminiscent of the issues that many hoped had been buried with the death of Emperor Hirohito.

headline: Japanese Trade Surplus Down
abstract: LEAD: Japan's trade surplus declined slightly in May, the 12th month in the last 13 during which the surplus narrowed from a year earlier, the Finance Ministry reported today.

headline: Income Fell 14.8% at NCR
abstract: LEAD: The NCR Corporation said today that its net income fell 14.8 percent in the first quarter as a result of lower profit margins and the cost of a share repurchase program.

headline: Nynex Plan Spurs 4,000 Retirements
abstract: LEAD: The Nynex Corporation said about 4,000 managers had taken advantage of a special retirement incentive program that ended last week. The company said 2,100 managers retired from its New York Telephone Company unit, 900 from the New England Telephone and Telegraph Company, 600 from the Nynex Service Company and the rest from other operations.

headline: CBS Sets Role for News Technicians
abstract: LEAD: CBS will allow technicians assigned to its news division to continue working exclusively on news programs, a CBS executive said yesterday.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: LEAD: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of June 25, 1990:       MONDAY       Ameron Inc Del    General Mls    Bellsouth Corp    Standard Prods Co    Boeing Co       TUESDAY       Bell Atlantic Corp    Montana Pwr Co    Centerior Energy    Nipsco Inds    Delmarva Pwr & Lt    Public Svc Co Colo    Disney Walt Co    Quick & Reilly Group    Elcor Corp    Rubbermaid Inc    Hydraulic Co    Signet Banking    Kerr Glass MFG    Union Camp Corp

headline: Terror Creates a Need: Better Bomb Detectors
abstract: LEAD: A dozen companies in several countries, pushed by growing fears of terrorist attacks, are racing to build detectors capable of sniffing out even the best-concealed explosive. But the machines are not foolproof, and some technology is meeting resistance from the airlines, the biggest potential customer for the devices.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Acton Corp., Raleigh, N.C., an insurance and real estate company, said its Hickory White Co. subsidiary had completed the acquisition of Hickory Furniture operations for $44.5 million.

headline: Kodak Raising Prices
abstract: LEAD: The Eastman Kodak Company said today that it had increased prices for rental, service and supplies for most of its copier and electronic publishing system lines. List prices for the equipment itself will remain the same, the company said. Kodak said it would increase copier equipment rental and service rates by 5 percent.

headline: The Long Campaign for a Perfect Prom
abstract: LEAD: Esther Truzman, the class secretary, fiddled with her notes and spoke up: ''The club has to be a nice space. A lot of clubs, you walk in and they're so blah. Hot Rod last year was nice, but the music wasn't so hot.''

headline: Allegheny Sues Japonica on Votes
abstract: LEAD: Allegheny International Inc., a Pittsburgh-based maker of small appliances, said it had sued Japonica Partners L.P., seeking to disallow its votes on Allegheny's plan to reorganize under Chapter 11 bankruptcy. In the suit, Allegheny said a bankruptcy court had the right to rule that the vote on a reorganization plan by certain parties was not in good faith and could be disallowed.

headline: VOLUNTEER CORPS FOR EAST EUROPE
abstract: LEAD: President Bush said today that he would create a volunteer corps to try to strengthen the emerging democracies in Central and Eastern Europe.

headline: Chairman of Perrier Leaves; Post Goes to Vice Chairman
abstract: LEAD: The chairman and founder of Source Perrier, Gustave Leven, stepped down yesterday and was replaced by the company's vice chairman, Jacques Vincent.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Gianettino & Meredith
abstract: LEAD: Gianettino & Meredith, an agency based in Short Hills, N.J., said it had won five accounts, the most prominent being the Ricoh Company's consumer products group. The other accounts include International Paint and the Pittsburgh Chevrolet/GEO dealer association. Combined billings are $8 million.

headline: U.S. Role In Aid Bank Draws Fire
abstract: LEAD: The Bush Administration faces stiff opposition from conservative Republicans, organized labor and some special-interest ethnic groups to American membership in a new regional development bank for Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: LEAD: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of June 4:       MONDAY       Alaska Air Group Inc    Cincinnati Bell    Davis Wtr & Waste Inds    Harnischfeger Inds    Smith Corona Corp    Zurn Inds       TUESDAY       Conseco Inc    McDermott Intl    Premier Indl Corp    Witco Corp       WEDNESDAY

headline: Soviet Troops Kill an Inmate During Riot in Ukrainian Jail
abstract: LEAD: Soviet troops sent into a prison to quell mass rioting opened fire on escaping inmates, killing one and wounding another, the official press agency Tass said today.

headline: Pic 'N' Save Corp. Wins Injunction

headline: Argentine Soap Opera: 'First Family'
abstract: LEAD: Although the separation of President Carlos Saul Menem and Zulema Yoma de Menem has the flavor of a melodrama, she says the real issue between them is that he is unable to control corruption in his Government.

headline: Bank of New England Plans to Cut 5,600 Jobs
abstract: LEAD: The Bank of New England Corporation announced a drastic plan yesterday to cut expenses and return to profitability by eliminating about a third of its payroll, The banking company, which had already begun to reduce its size by selling loans, said it planned to cut 5,600 jobs. headline: Death Toll Put at 17 in Crash Of Cargo Plane in Guatemala
abstract: LEAD: A Miami-bound DC-6 cargo plane crashed in a crowded residential neighborhood on Saturday, killing its 3-member American crew and at least 14 people on the ground, officials said today. Several houses were destroyed.

headline: New Chief Taking Over Savings Bailout Board

headline: Senator Takes Savings-Issue Stance
abstract: LEAD: Following the political strategy of another member of the ''Keating Five,'' Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr. today criticized regulators and Federal prosecutors for moving too slowly in resolving the savings and loan crisis.

headline: Shaver Victory By Windmere
abstract: LEAD: A Federal jury today awarded about $100 million to the Windmere Corporation in an antitrust suit that accused NV Philips of monopolizing the rotary shaver market.

headline: Boise Cascade Net Down 57%
abstract: LEAD: Weak demand for paper products coupled with higher prices for logs and wood chips sent the Boise Cascade Corporation's first-quarter net income plunging by 57 percent, the company said today.

headline: Managing;   Headhunting From a Data Base
abstract: LEAD: The Intel Corporation's strategic staffing manager, Alexis DiFirenzi-Swale, is filling 19 jobs through University Pronet, an electronic data base of graduates from several universities that is headquartered at Stanford University in California, because it offers ''a focused shot into the precise groups we wish to hire from.

headline: U.S.-Soviet Meeting Set
abstract: LEAD: The United States and the Soviet Union have tentatively agreed to hold trade talks in Paris from April 24 to 26, a United States Embassy spokeswoman said today. The meeting will be the fourth in a series aimed at gaining most-favored-nation trade status for Moscow, allowing its exports to enter the United States with lower duties.

headline: Royal Dutch Net Falls 37.5%
abstract: LEAD: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group said on Thursday that its net income dropped 37.5 percent in the first quarter, reflecting a weak performance by its chemical group and a gain from property sales a year earlier.      The oil giant, based in the

headline: Right-Wing Christian Party Takes Clear Lead in Hungarian Voting
abstract: LEAD: The Hungarian Democratic Forum, a conservative party, emerged today with a decisive lead in the final round of elections for Hungary's Parliament, guaranteeing it the dominant role in the country's first freely elected government in more than four decades.

headline: B.A.T. Sells Unit
abstract: LEAD: B.A.T. Industries P.L.C. sold its Eurotec car components business to Klockner-Werke A.G. of West Germany for $:155 million (about $263 million), including the assumption of debt. The sale is part of B.A.T's program to sell assets and focus on tobacco and financial-services operations. The conglomerate's strategy was devised in the face of a hostile takeover effort, since abandoned, by Sir James Goldsmith, the British-French financier.

headline: Lebanese Christian Fighting Goes On in Beirut; 3 Killed
abstract: LEAD: Rival Lebanese Christians fought with artillery and rocket fire today, killing 3 people and wounding at least 16, security informants said.
