abstract: LEAD: Soviet border guards refused today to allow Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato to enter Lithuania, which has been locked in a war of wills with the Kremlin since declaring independence on March 11.

abstract: LEAD: William L. Godsey had headed the General Dynamics Corporation's European operations in Brussels for three years when he got a call from Frederick S. headline: Medellin Journal;   In the Capital of Cocaine, Savagery Is the Habit
abstract: LEAD: Viewed from the window of a commuter helicopter, Medellin offers much of the provincial charm long associated with Colombia's second largest city.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Oops, There Goes Another Soviet Set
abstract: LEAD: THE gravest problem facing Western companies hoping to advertise on television in the Soviet Union may not be Government bureaucracy, consumer apathy or the lack of programming. It seems to be exploding television sets.

headline: A Constitution for Andorra
abstract: LEAD: The principality of Andorra has decided to draft its first constitution. The legislature, the General Council of the Valleys, agreed unanimously Monday night to draft a constitution for the little principality of 50,000 betweeen France and Spain in the Pyrenees Mountains, which is ruled by two co-princes - the President of France and the Roman Catholic Bishop of the Spanish town of Urgel under a 700-year-old agreement.

headline: Market Rebounds as Dow Climbs 11.71
abstract: LEAD: Bargain hunters and program traders lifted the market out of a slump yesterday. After dipping as much as 11 points by shortly after noon, the market turned around and the Dow Jones industrial average rose briskly, ending the day at 2,656.76, up 11.71 points.

headline: U.S. Says It Will Consider U.N. Observers for Occupied Territories
abstract: LEAD: The United States is ready to consider an Arab plan to send United Nations observers to the Israeli-occupied territories to monitor the treatment of Palestinians by Israeli security forces, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today.

headline: Contras Will Begin Disarming as Army Is Cut
abstract: LEAD: Nicaraguan rebels today agreed with the new Government to begin disarming next week, and President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro pledged to start reducing the size of the Sandinista-controlled army. headline: Norton Resisting Acquisition Offers
abstract: LEAD: Despite the interest of outside parties in acquiring it, the Norton Company reiterated in documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it would try to remain independent. Advisers to Norton, which is resisting a takeover bid of $75 a share, or $1.64 billion, from BTR P.L.C., a British conglomerate, said the company was still holding talks with third parties interested in taking minority positions.

headline: Three Decades Ago, Another Visitor

headline: Domino's Pizza Suitors Cited

headline: Bombing in Jerusalem Kills Jewish Man
abstract: LEAD: A bomb planted near a restaurant on a busy market street in the Jewish sector of Jerusalem exploded today, killing a 72-year-old man and wounding nine others, including a 6-year-old boy.

headline: Dual Trade Ban Challenged
abstract: LEAD: Two studies that were released this week have attacked the underlying premise of a rule proposed by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission that would restrict dual trading.

headline: In AIDS-Stricken Uganda Area, The Orphans Struggle to Survive
abstract: LEAD: Josephine Senyonga, a diminutive woman with decades of hard farm labor etched into her face, sat on the floor of her one-room house, surrounded by 12 grandchildren.

headline: Trump Is Reportedly Selling Yacht
abstract: LEAD: Donald J. Trump has arranged to sell his 282-foot yacht in Japan for about $110 million, Wall Street executives and a lawyer close to the deal said yesterday.

headline: Shutdown by Ford To Furlough 2,700
abstract: LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said it would halt production of the Thunderbird and Cougar models for a week beginning on April 30. About 2,700 hourly workers will be laid off at Ford's assembly plant in Lorain, Ohio, as a result.

abstract: LEAD: A House subcommittee today unanimously approved a bill that would reimpose some regulations on the cable television industry.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   AC & R Promotions
abstract: LEAD: Karen Amorelli has been promoted from executive vice president to the newly created position of president of AC & R New York. AC & R also promoted Richard Cohn and Robert Goolrick to executive vice presidents and co-directors of creative services, and Randy Novick to senior vice president and media director.

headline: Foreign Investment Dip
abstract: LEAD: Foreign direct investment in the United States last year was $64.6 billion, down from $72.7 billion in 1988, but well above outlays in earlier years, the Commerce Department said this week. It said in a preliminary report that British concerns continued to lead in direct investment, with purchases worth $22 billion last year.

headline: Condominium Conversions;   New Jersey Developer Offers a Lease-Purchase Plan
abstract: LEAD: The soft New Jersey real estate market has led the sponsors of a condominium conversion to offer potential buyers a lease-purchase program, which state officials say might set a trend. Although many publicly financed projects offer similar programs, the Commons at Princeton Landing in Plainsboro Township is apparently the first privately financed condominium development in the state to offer such terms.

headline: Prices of Treasury Issues Rise a Bit
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities were slightly higher yesterday despite several seemingly negative currents swirling about the credit markets.

headline: Jury Supports Genentech In Patent Infringement Case
abstract: LEAD: In an important victory for Genentech Inc., a jury in United States District Court in Delaware ruled today that the company's patents for tissue plasminogen activator, or T.P.A., its main product, were valid.

abstract: LEAD: The Justice Department, expanding its inquiry into pricing and competition in the airline industry, has asked airlines for detailed information about their computerized system of publishing fares, according to Government and industry officials.

headline: 6 Arab Guerrillas Reported Killed in Israeli Attack in Lebanon
abstract: LEAD: Israeli soldiers killed six Arab guerrillas of the pro-Iranian Party of God militia in an overnight attack on the group's training headquarters in southeast Lebanon, the army said today.

abstract: LEAD: John Wiley & Sons Inc., a publisher of textbooks and educational and scientific books and journals, has named Charles R. Ellis its president and chief executive.

abstract: LEAD: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation said yesterday that it would cut 10 percent of its corporate finance staff.

headline: Tokyo Journal;   She's Shy and Not So Shy, Japan's Princess Bride

headline: Most Units Of Bonwit Will Close
abstract: LEAD: Most of the Bonwit Teller specialty retail chain, including the main store in Trump Tower in Manhattan, will go out of business by June under several arrangements announced in bankruptcy court yesterday.

abstract: LEAD: Lech Walesa, the leader of the Solidarity trade union, declared today that Poland's revolution has stagnated and pledged to foment ''permanent political war'' that would shake the Government he helped create last year.

abstract: LEAD: Shareholders of Rorer Group Inc., fulfilling a condition of Rorer's planned merger with Rhone-Poulenc S.A. of France, voted to exempt the company from certain antitakeover provisions. In addition, Rhone-Poulenc's $78-a-share offer, worth a total of $3.2 billion, for 50.1 percent of Rorer, based in Fort Washington, Pa., was extended until Saturday from today.

abstract: LEAD: In an age when millionaire no longer sounds very rich, billionaire still has a certain ring to it. Last week, on Manhattan's East Side, two very different men, each of whom became the best-known ''billionaire'' of an era, could reflect on shifting fortunes.

headline: Furor Over British Poll Tax Imperils Thatcher Ideology

abstract: LEAD: * Airbus Industrie, a consortium of companies in France, West Germany Britain and Spain said Olympic Airways of Greece had ordered two Airbus A300-600R airliners and placed options for two more. No financial details were available.

abstract: LEAD: For Dalva Ferreira da Vitoria, wife of a building superintendent, Brazil's radical new economic plan means frozen prices in supermarkets here, a welcome respite after prices jumped 84 percent in March.

headline: Villagers Say Sandinista Raid Breaks Cease-Fire
abstract: LEAD: Five rebels were ambushed and nearly killed on Sunday by Sandinista troops while preparing a feast for villagers here, residents say.

abstract: LEAD: Spending for motor vehicle advertising on broadcast television rose 15 percent in 1989, to $2.84 billion, the Television Bureau of Advertising reported yesterday. The leader was the General Motors Corporation, which spent $846.7 million, an increase of 17 percent. The Ford Motor Company, in second place, spent $381.9 million, up 12 percent.

abstract: LEAD: Alberto Fujimori, the 51-year-old son of Japanese immigrants who displaced Mario Vargas Llosa last week as presidential frontrunner, is vowing to shake up Peru, attacking coca cultivation and guerrilla violence and pushing for the entry of this Andean land into the booming economy of the Pacific.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Newspaper Ads Down
abstract: LEAD: Newspaper advertising spending for the first quarter of the year fell by three-tenths of a percent, to $7.296 billion, compared with the first quarter of 1989, according to preliminary estimates by the Newspaper Advertising Bureau. While retail advertising rose by 2.7 percent, to $3.835 billion, classified advertising dropped by 6.4 percent, to $2.495 billion.

headline: President Adds Post At Sherry-Lehmann
abstract: LEAD: Sherry-Lehmann Inc., the New York wine merchant, has announced changes in its top management. Michael Aaron, the president, has added the title of chairman, and Sam Aaron, his uncle and the dean of New York wine merchants, has stepped down.

abstract: LEAD: THE cost of the savings and loan bailout could be a lot larger than anyone has expected - indeed, more than $1 trillion.

abstract: LEAD: The Cigna Corporation said today that its earnings fell by half in the first quarter, partly because of large claims resulting from severe winter storms in Europe. The big insurance company said profits fell to $42 million, or 54 cents a share, from $85 million, or $1.02 a share, in 1989. Revenues fell slightly, to $3.8 billion, from $3.6 billion.

headline: Unilever Is Buying Margarine Maker
abstract: LEAD: Unilever, the giant consumer products company, said it planned to buy the 50 percent of a Swedish margarine maker that it does not already own for $35.8 million. Unilever, which is based in London and Rotterdam, the Netherlands, said it would buy the stake in Margarinbolaget A.B. from the Aritmos Group.

abstract: LEAD: The Salvadoran Government vowed today to cooperate with a judge's investigation into the killing of six Jesuit priests and two women in November and to take action if any obstacles are put in the judge's way.

abstract: LEAD: Alexander Dubcek, the father of the Prague Spring, came to Washington today, not as the leader of a free Czechoslovakia, as he had thought likely for a fleeting moment last fall, but to remind Americans that Slovaks as well as Czechs carried out the revolution of 1989.

An amendment to the Clean Air Act approved by the Senate would mandate such a change.

UJB, which owns United Jersey Bank, has been hurt by the slowdown in the New Jersey economy, but has remained profitable.

headline: Ozone Fading Fast, Thatcher Tells World Experts
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher warned representatives of more than 100 nations today that destruction of the earth's ozone layer was proceeding even faster than scientists had feared.

headline: Britain Gets 2d Satellite TV
abstract: LEAD: Britain's newest satellite television system began its five-channel service on Sunday after months of delay, but it faces a tough battle to win over the nation's viewers.

abstract: LEAD: H. F. Ahmanson & Company moved to expand in New York today by agreeing to acquire the Home Savings Bank of New York in a stock deal valued at approximately $300 million.

headline: Efforts to Curb Buying By Boesky Recounted
abstract: LEAD: A former executive who had worked for Ivan F. Boesky testified yesterday that Mr. Boesky was so unable to control his appetite for takeover stocks that executives at his New York trading firm felt compelled to lie to him about the firm's capital position.

abstract: LEAD: ''We want to develop magazines in the top 20 markets in the United States,'' said Thomas Ryder, president and executive publisher of the American Express Publishing Corporation. headline: Assad Tells Visiting Senators He Wants Better U.S. Ties
abstract: LEAD: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria told a visiting delegation from the United States Senate today that his nation wants better relations with the United States and a peaceful and just settlement of the Arab-Israeli conflict.

abstract: LEAD: As the Dow Jones industrial average flirts with 3,000, many market watchers are wondering whether a group of professional investors will be forced by their clients to join the rally and spend their huge sums of cash, thus pushing stock prices even higher.

abstract: LEAD: In a move that could lead to the restoration of one of Wall Street's most famous names, Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. is examining a plan to reorganize its four operational units into two divisions, Wall Street executives said yesterday.

abstract: LEAD: The Colgate-Palmolive Company said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings rose 20.8 percent as its revenue increased 8 percent. headline: Your Own Account;  When Women Manage Money
abstract: LEAD: According to Esther M. Berger, who specializes in financial planning for women, at least 90 percent of American women will be making their own financial decisions at some point in their lives. She can rattle off the statistics: 48 percent of all women will be widowed in their lifetime; 36 percent will be divorced and about 6 percent will remain single.

headline: Burst of Freedom in Czechoslovakia May Split Czechs From the Slovaks
abstract: LEAD: Seven months after the peaceful revolution that ended four decades of Communist rule in Czechoslovakia, the biggest political question is whether President Vaclav Havel can keep Czechs and Slovaks from going separate ways after free elections on June 8 and 9.

abstract: LEAD: As the cost of Colombia's war on cocaine trafficking rises, officials here are growing more impatient with the United States.

abstract: LEAD: President Roh Tae Woo of South Korea met here today with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union and said later that the two nations would establish diplomatic relations in the future.

abstract: LEAD: East Germany's main political groups agreed today to try to form the nation's first non-Communist government before April 15 and resolve lingering differences over unification with West Germany.

abstract: LEAD: The First Chicago Corporation, parent of the First National Bank of Chicago, reported a sharp drop in first-quarter earnings today as expected. The decline was attributed to a big run-up in its portfolio of troubled real estate loans.

abstract: LEAD: With mounting indignation, British farmers are protesting the French Government's decision to ban imports of British beef in reaction to ''mad cow disease,'' a newly discovered nerve disorder that has infected more than 13,000 British cattle.

abstract: LEAD: Americans took out $3.4 billion more in consumer credit than they repaid in February, but the pace slowed because of slackening demand for car loans, the Government said today.

headline: Sales of Vehicles Down By 11.3% in Early April
abstract: LEAD: Sales of domestically produced cars and light trucks fell by 11.3 percent in early April, compared with relatively strong sales a year ago, despite aggressive cash rebates and other discounts.

headline: Advertising Agency With a Cause
abstract: LEAD: Most advertising agencies are in the business of persuading consumers to buy their clients' products. But a tiny San Francisco agency specializes in telling consumers what they should not buy.

headline: Peruvians Vote Today in Neck-and-Neck Runoff
abstract: LEAD: After a bitter campaign, Peruvians go to the polls on Sunday to choose a President to lead them out of a decade of economic collapse and spreading guerrilla war.

abstract: LEAD: Ending a year of struggle that bruised the First Boston Corporation, Sealy Holdings Inc., formerly the Ohio Mattress Company, announced yesterday that it had agreed with a series of lenders on terms for permanent financing for the company.

headline: As Proxy Use Widens, New Rules Are Urged
abstract: LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission is considering the most sweeping changes in its history in the rules that govern proxy contests. The move, which is still in the preliminary stages, could increase the power of dissident shareholders and make it easier to oust corporate boards of directors.

headline: Du Pont to Construct Plants For Ozone-Safe Refrigerant
abstract: LEAD: Du Pont announced yesterday that it would design four plants to produce refrigeration chemicals that do not endanger the earth's ozone layer, but said it was continuing to delay a commitment to produce another family of compounds that would have a different use.

abstract: LEAD: A group led by Carl C. Icahn, the New York investor who is proposing to spin off the steel holdings of the USX Corporation, said yesterday that such a separation would yield about $48 a share for stockholders.

abstract: LEAD: A Chinese diplomat said today that he was seeking political asylum in the United States because he supports the democracy movement in China. The diplomat, Xu Lin, said his duties at the Chinese Embassy here had included assisting Chinese students with the renewal of their passports.

abstract: LEAD: Sears, Roebuck & Company is offering $400 million in notes due 1993 through underwriters led by Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. The size of the offering was originally set at $300 million, but it was increased because of investor demand.

headline: Business and Health;   Employers Resist Accounting Rule
abstract: LEAD: FORECASTING health costs, an uncertain art at best, has become the subject of a vigorous debate between employers and the accounting profession's rule-making board.

headline: Stora Paper Deal
abstract: LEAD: The Swedish paper company Stora A.B. said it would acquire Feldmuehle Nobel A.G., a West German paper and armaments concern, for four billion marks, or about $2.38 billion. Stora's president, Bo Berggren, said, ''We are taking a decisive step in the creation of a very good forestry industrial structure.

headline: FRAUD UNCOVERED IN PROPERTY SALES IN SAVINGS RESCUE
abstract: LEAD: The Federal rescue program to sell billions of dollars worth of property seized from failed savings and loans is just beginning, but Government auditors have already detected evidence of misconduct.

headline: Bank Trial Starts in Italy
abstract: LEAD: The trial of 35 people charged with fraudulent bankruptcy in the 1982 collapse of Banco Ambrosiano, one of Europe's biggest bank failures, began today, but only six of the accused appeared in court.

headline: I.B.M. Investment In Valid Noted
abstract: LEAD: Valid Logic Systems Inc. said the International Business Machines Corporation would acquire a minority equity interest in Valid, a developer of integrated electronic design-automation software. Under the agreement, I.B.M. would make an initial investment of $11.2 million in the form of newly issued voting convertible preferred stock representing an interest in

headline: CHINA'S UNTOLD STORY: WHO DIED IN THE CRACKDOWN?
abstract: LEAD: A year ago there was no more potent symbol of China's crackdown than the television image of the young man who halted a convoy of tanks near Tiananmen Square. And today, there is no better example of the uncertainties of what really happened than the confusion about that man's identity and fate.

headline: Ex-Party Chief Cleared In Yugoslavia Unrest
abstract: LEAD: The ethnic Albanian former Communist Party chief of Yugoslavia's strife-torn Kosovo region was acquitted today of criminal charges that he instigated a wave of strikes and protests that set off popular unrest in the region a year ago.

headline: Bankrupt Ames Hires A Turnaround Expert
abstract: LEAD: Ames Department Stores, the discount retailer that filed for bankruptcy last Wednesday, yesterday named a retailer and turnaround expert to help solve its financial problems.

headline: Producer Signs Disney Deal
abstract: LEAD: Dawn Steel, the former president of Columbia Pictures, has signed a long-term agreement to produce films and television shows for the Walt Disney Company, Disney said yesterday.      Ms. Steel was president of

headline: Lionel Is Urged To Sell Big Stake
abstract: LEAD: An investment group led by a Florida brokerage, which controls a 5 percent stake in the Lionel Corporation, has asked the New York toy retailer to set up a committee to consider the sale of a large stake in the company.

headline: FYI, Mr. Baker: No Israeli Calls
abstract: LEAD: The White House's switchboard operators were not amused. Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d gave out the White House's telephone number - (1-202) 456-1414 - during Congressional testimony on Wednesday and, in a stern rebuke to Israel's leaders, invited: ''When you're serious about peace, call us.

headline: Lower Cigarette Sales Linked to Tax Rise
abstract: LEAD: A new study suggests that raising taxes on cigarettes helps to reduce smoking, lending momentum to a movement in Congress to raise Federal levies on tobacco as a way to curb use and to ease the Federal deficit.

headline: Your Own Account;  Planning for Catastrophe
abstract: LEAD: In 1986, Lois and Bob Ardery were struggling to keep the steel company they owned out of Chapter 11 bankruptcy when he developed a cerebral hemorrhage. Trying to separate the emotional devastation of losing her husband from the fear of financial ruin was one of the first hurdles Mrs. Ardery had to get over.

headline: New Software System Due
abstract: LEAD: Computer Associates International Inc. said today that it had developed a computer software system that lets clients run their Computer Associates software using the hardware of their choice or even on a combination of hardware.

headline: Iran Indicates It Will Seek Release Of More Hostages if U.S. Responds
abstract: LEAD: Iran and its Lebanese Shiite Muslim allies signaled their willingness today to keep pushing for the release of more American hostages if the United States responds to their effort with reciprocal moves.

headline: Article 786790 -- No Title
abstract: LEAD: Saks Fifth Avenue, one of the world's premier high-fashion retailers, will be sold by its British owners for $1.5 billion to a Mideast financial group known as Investcorp.

headline: BellSouth License For New Zealand
abstract: LEAD: The BellSouth Corporation said it had been awarded one of three licenses to provide cellular telephone service in New Zealand. Two consortiums identified as Ready Form No. 43 Ltd. and Write or Wrong Ltd. won the other licenses.

headline: Early June Vehicle Sales Down 12.6%
abstract: LEAD: Sales of domestically produced cars and light trucks declined 12.6 percent in early June, puncturing hopes by manufacturers that a surge in late May signaled an end to the auto industry's eight-month slump.

headline: African National Congress Reaches Out a Little for Negotiators
abstract: LEAD: When the African National Congress announced its delegation for preliminary talks with the Government next week, the lineup offered more than a few surprises.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:    COMPANIES       In asbestos-related suits against Owens-Illinois, insurance companies are liable for $960 million in damage and injury claims, a New Jersey superior court has ruled. [Page D1.]      MCI Communications has agreed to buy Telecom USA in a deal worth $1.25 billion. The deal is the latest and largest in a series of acquisitions by MCI.

headline: Lockheed Expected To Move Aircraft Unit
abstract: LEAD: The Lockheed Corporation would move the headquarters of its aeronautics division from Burbank, Calif., to Marietta, Ga., under a plan considered today by its board.

headline: Aided by U.S. Waiver, China Launches First Foreign Satellite
abstract: LEAD: China launched a foreign telecommunications satellite tonight, setting off a national celebration to mark its entry into the international launching business.

headline: Soviets Buy More Wheat
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union has bought an additional 149,000 metric tons of United States wheat at subsidized prices for delivery next month, the Agriculture Department said this week. It said the wheat had been sold by two private companies, which will receive subsidies under the department's Export Enhancement Program.

headline: AFGHAN CEREMONY ENDS IN BLOODSHED
abstract: LEAD: Afghan rebels turned a reconciliation ceremony into a deadly ambush today, killing at least 10 people, including 2 generals, and wounding many other Government officials, witnesses said.

headline: Creator of Companies Builds Profit by Region
abstract: LEAD: Ten years ago, Ian R. Wilson was a vice chairman of the Coca-Cola Company when, as he put it the other day, ''they chose the wrong guy as chairman, and I left.''

headline: A Worry in West Germany: Indolence in East Germany
abstract: LEAD: At a construction site on the Leipziger Strasse in downtown East Berlin, a workman is cutting plywood on a table saw. The blade's high-pitched whine echoes through the brick-and-concrete shell of the unfinished six-story structure. No other human life is visible.

headline: Mongolian Leader in Beijing to Improve Ties
abstract: LEAD: The President of Mongolia arrived in China today for a six-day visit intended to improve relations and increase economic links between the neighboring countries.

headline: Merger Deals Fall 13%
abstract: LEAD: A battered junk bond market and other financing difficulties contributed to a 13 percent drop in proposed mergers and acquisitions in the first quarter, according to a survey released today by W. T. Grimm & Company, a unit of Merrill Lynch.

headline: I.M.F. Sees Slower Growth, but No Slump
abstract: LEAD: In a less optimistic assessment than it made in October, the International Monetary Fund projected today that world economic growth would slow to 2 1/4 percent in 1990, but it said that ''no recession is in sight.''

headline: Brazil Reform Seen Hurting U.S. Earnings
abstract: LEAD: Brazil's new economic reform program, which in three weeks has brought Latin America's largest economy to a near standstill, is expected to have a significant impact on American companies as well.

headline: Program Trade Curbs Advance
abstract: LEAD: The House approved legislation today that would allow the Securities and Exchange Commission to curb computerized program trading.      Under the measures, the

headline: Promise Into Peril: The Kirby Fight
abstract: LEAD: It all began with a letter that ended, ''With Kindest Regards.'' Sent in the spring of 1986, the letter caused long-simmering family frictions to erupt in a battle over an obscure charitable foundation. Since then, the Kirby family feud has turned into a tale of sibling rivalry played out on a billion-dollar stage.

headline: Honduran Army Seeks U.S. Troops' Attackers
abstract: LEAD: The Honduran military began a nationwide search today for the gunmen who wounded eight United States airmen over the weekend.

headline: Israel Says It Helped Finance Settlers in Christian Quarter
abstract: LEAD: The Israeli Government acknowledged tonight that it had secretly provided almost $2 million to help establish a new Jewish settlement in the Christian quarter of Jerusalem's Old City 10 days ago.

headline: Markets Closed For Holiday
abstract: LEAD: In observance of Memorial Day, all financial markets in the United States are closed today. The financial markets in Britain are closed in observance of a bank holiday.

headline: 8 Die in Philippine Accident
abstract: LEAD: A delivery truck filled with soft drinks and about 35 hitchhikers lost its brakes and overturned today, killing at least 8 people, a survivor and hospital authorities reported. Most of those killed were crushed to death by the cases of soda. At least 27 people were injured. The truck was reportedly delivering cases of Coca-Cola to Marawi city when the accident occurred near the town of Pantar in southern Lanao del Norte province.

headline: Productivity Down by 2.7%
abstract: LEAD: The productivity of American businesses outside the farming sector was revised downward to 2.7 percent in the first quarter, the largest drop in more than eight years, the Labor Department said today.

headline: Home Builder In Chapter 11
abstract: LEAD: The General Development Corporation filed for Federal bankruptcy protection on Friday, less than a week after revealing a severe cash shortage and agreeing to a $100 million repayment program for victims of a scheme to sell overpriced homes.

headline: Quakes Are Unrelated
abstract: LEAD: Despite the nearness in time of the quakes that struck Peru and Romania late Tuesday and early yesterday, one earthquake rarely, if ever, touches off a quake in some other part of the globe, according to Lynne Sykes, an earthquake specialist at Columbia University's Lamont-Doherty Geological Observatory.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:          The Economy

headline: Continental Adds Nicaragua Route
abstract: LEAD: Continental Airlines announced it would add nonstop service to Nicaragua from Houston's Intercontinental Airport, giving it flights to each of the seven Central American countries. The nonstop service to Managua is scheduled to begin on July 1.

headline: Hong Kong's 'Hostage' in China Won't Give In
abstract: LEAD: Almost everyone wishes he would confess to some counterrevolutionary crime or another, if only to get his sentence reduced, but Liu Shanqing sits in his unheated prison cell in China and obstinately refuses to admit that it was wrong to believe in democracy.

headline: CNB Bancshares Is Acquiring Bank
abstract: LEAD: Valley Federal Savings Bank agreed to be acquired by CNB Bancshares Inc. of Evansville, Ind., for $10.50 a share, with 60 percent of the transaction to be in common stock. The company said the conversion value of the CNB stock to be exchanged in the transaction had been set at $21 a share.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Tighter Defense Links For London and Paris
abstract: LEAD: Britain and France announced today that they would forge closer links in security and defense matters, and included the possibility of cooperation on unspecified nuclear programs.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:    THE ECONOMY       The savings bailout effort has a high potential for fraud and abuse, Government officials and real estate experts say. The problem is expected to worsen as the Government moves quickly to expand sales of properties acquired from failed institutions. [Page A1.]  If Republicans and Democrats move to a full-scale battle over who is to blame for the savings crisis, the outcome may be decided by how far back the public can remember.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Doctors Spot X-ray Mistake
abstract: LEAD: Korey, Kay & Partners might know advertising, but they are a bit weak on biology.

headline: Late Soviet Payments Irk Sellers
abstract: LEAD: Frustrated by slow bill payments by the traditionally prompt Soviet Union, some American companies are slowing shipments to Moscow or avoiding new export commitments, various industry, Government and other sources said today.

headline: Feud Over Futures Trading
abstract: LEAD: Top Federal regulators continued a bitter public battle today over which agency should control futures trading in a new breed of financial products.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   John Paul Says a Prayer For Lithuania's Success
abstract: LEAD: Celebrating the revival of democracy across the globe, Pope John Paul II offered an Easter prayer today that Lithuanian hopes for independence would be realized through discussions with Moscow.

headline: A Head Testimony By Boesky
abstract: LEAD: Under a blistering cross-examination, Ivan F. Boesky testified yesterday that he had lied more times under oath than he could remember before he admitted to illegal insider trading in 1986 and began cooperating with the Government's investigation of crimes on Wall Street.

headline: World Markets;   Where to Gain From the Dollar's Loss
abstract: LEAD: While the dollar has been relatively tame this year, it has still raised the returns of some Americans who invested away from Wall Street.

headline: Greeks to Upgrade Israeli and P.L.O. Ties
abstract: LEAD: Greece's new conservative Government announced today that it would establish full diplomatic relations with Israel, making it the last of the European Community's 12 members to do so.

headline: Walesa Again Chosen Chairman of Solidarity
abstract: LEAD: Lech Walesa was easily re-elected chairman of Solidarity today, and he pledged to continue the union movement's sometimes-conflicting roles as workers' advocate and supporter of Poland's new democratic Government.

headline: SALVADOR ACCUSED ON JESUIT INQUIRY
abstract: LEAD: A special panel of House Democrats said today that the investigation into the killing of six Jesuit priests in El Salvador had come to ''a virtual standstill'' because authorities there were making little effort to determine if senior Salvadoran military officers ordered or concealed the crime.

headline: The Executive Computer;   Put on Your Data Glove and Goggles and Step
abstract: LEAD: The concept of cyberspace, which first gained popular appeal in a 1984 science-fiction novel, is so radical that even today few people agree on its definition. Some describe cyberspace as an infinite, computer-generated artificial world where humans experience an approximation of reality. There, geographic distance is irrelevant and participants can see, hear and even touch objects that exist only as computer data - pure information.

headline: Hewlett-Hughes Computer Venture
abstract: LEAD: The Hewlett-Packard Company and the Hughes Aircraft unit of the General Motors Corporation agreed to develop and produce advanced work stations, personal computers and related equipment that meet United States Government, military and aerospace standards.

headline: Where Sites Are Rare;  Montclair Projects Echo Older Housing
abstract: LEAD: Even the smallest bit of buildable land is treated like gold in Montclair, a nearly fully developed New Jersey suburb that has long maintained its cachet as one of the most popular communities in the state.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Centerbank, Waterbury, Conn., a savings bank, appointed Robert T. Kenney president.

headline: Westinghouse Profits Are Up 11.1%
abstract: LEAD: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said today that its first-quarter profit increased 11.1 percent in part because of the sales of two radio stations and a minority interest in a nuclear power project.

headline: Sales Officer For Apple Unit
abstract: LEAD: Apple Computer Inc. said today that Michael L. Dionne had been named vice president, sales, of the Apple U.S.A. division, effective immediately.

headline: Union Assails Pickens Plan
abstract: LEAD: The labor union at the Koito Manufacturing Company today denounced an attempt by the Texas oilman T. Boone Pickens to get a seat on the company's board.

headline: Liberia Talks in Lull; Rebels Take Town
abstract: LEAD: Efforts to reach a peaceful settlement of the Liberian crisis made little headway today, and there were indications that the rebel forces are poised to advance on Monrovia unless major political concessions are offered soon.

headline: World Markets;  A Reality Check for the 'East Fantasy'
abstract: LEAD: Since the Berlin Wall opened last November, West German stock trading has been dominated by a phenomenon called Ostphantasie, or east fantasy.

headline: 'Junk Bond' Changes Proposed
abstract: LEAD: The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission has asked a securities group to explore the development of an electronic pricing system for the high-yield ''junk bond'' market, industry executives said yesterday.

headline: Field Narrows for Envoy to Managua
abstract: LEAD: A career United States Foreign Service officer emerged today as the leading candidate to be Ambassador to Nicaragua, Administration officials said.

headline: Eastern Creditors Reported To Reject Latest Debt Plan
abstract: LEAD: The unsecured creditors of Eastern Airlines yesterday voted to reject the carrier's latest proposal to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy and they agreed to seek the appointment of a trustee to sell the airline, two people close to the creditors' committee said.

headline: JAPANESE EXPRESS REMORSE TO KOREA
abstract: LEAD: Emperor Akihito apologized tonight for Japan's brutal subjugation of Korea nearly a half century ago. It was the first time that unambiguous acceptance of responsibility for Japanese wartime aggression had ever been expressed at such a high level.

headline: Mutual Funds;   When You Have a Choice of Fees
abstract: LEAD: When it comes to fees, mutual funds get you coming or going. But you may be able to start picking the direction.

headline: Treasury Securities Inch Higher
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities inched higher in slow trading yesterday, as dealers began to position themselves for tomorrow's release of May employment data.

headline: Comerica in Deal
abstract: LEAD: Comerica Inc. said it had agreed to acquire Inbancshares, a bank holding company based in City of Industry, Calif., for $20.25 a share, or about $40 million. The acquisition, which is subject to regulatory approval, would add $242 million to Comerica's assets of about $12 billion. Inbancshares has four offices and 70 employees.

headline: Market Place;   Drop in Risk Seen By Hungary Fund
abstract: LEAD: WHEN the Hungarian stock market officially opened last week, Ibusz, the former state-owned travel agency, became the first privatized company to be traded. The buyers are thrilled.

headline: Revamping Ordered For Manville's Fund On Asbestos Claims
abstract: LEAD: Two judges in New York reopened the bankruptcy proceeding of the Manville Corporation yesterday by ordering a bankruptcy judge to overhaul drastically the procedures for compensating tens of thousands of victims of asbestos.

headline: IRAQ SAYS IT MADE AN ATOM 'TRIGGER'
abstract: LEAD: President Saddam Hussein asserted today that Iraq had acquired a secret American electronic device that could be used to detonate a nuclear bomb and that it was now able to make the detonators itself.

headline: Argentine Phone Deals
abstract: LEAD: Two groups, one led by an American bank and the other by a Spanish telephone company, were each awarded a majority stake today in a portion of Entel, Argentina's state telephone monopoly, according to a decree signed by President Carlos Saul Menem. The American group, led by the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation and including the Bell Atlantic Corporation, was awarded a 60 percent stake in a new regional telephone company to serve northern Argentina and half of Buenos Aires.

headline: South Korean Leader Accepts Japanese Emperor's Apology
abstract: LEAD: President Roh Tae Woo said today that Japan's expressions of regret for its brutal colonization of Korea were the basis for a new relationship.

headline: Ames Posts Larger Loss
abstract: LEAD: Ames Department Stores Inc., which has been in voluntary bankruptcy since April 25, said yesterday that it had a much larger net loss of $431 million in the first quarter that ended on April 28 than the year before, while its revenues dropped slightly, to $935 million from $1 billion. The previous year's loss was $16.5 million.

headline: Bush's Son Defends Role at Failed Savings Unit
abstract: LEAD: Neil Bush went before Congress today to defend his role as a director of a failed Denver savings institution, saying he had not violated any rules when he approved and sought loans for two real estate developers with whom he had other business dealings.

headline: For Lithuanian City, the Embargo Is No Reason to Lose Composure
abstract: LEAD: If it is a war of nerves that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has been waging against Lithuania, there is no sign that he is winning it here in the republic's second city.

headline: Money-Fund Yields Down
abstract: LEAD: Yields of taxable and tax-exempt money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were down slightly for the week ended yesterday.

headline: Amid Doubts, Cambodian Factions Agree to Truce
abstract: LEAD: Cambodia's four warring factions have signed a cease-fire that is to take effect next month, but one guerrilla official today called the agreement a mere ''play on words.''

headline: U.S. Is Artfully Silent on Oil Threats to Lithuania
abstract: LEAD: The Bush Administration, which has been trying to avoid becoming embroiled in the struggle between Lithuania and Moscow, said late today that until it could confirm reports that the Kremlin had cut off Soviet oil to Lithuania it would not have any response.

headline: Evolution in Europe: Moscow Journal;   His Only Crime Was Being the First
abstract: LEAD: At a time when everyone in the Soviet Union from President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on down is bracing for the conversion to a market-oriented economy, Ramiz Shabanov sits in jail, serving a 15-year term for ''private entrepreneurial activities.''

headline: Namibia in I.M.F. Bid
abstract: LEAD: Namibia, newly independent of South Africa, has asked to join the International Monetary Fund, the fund announced on Monday. Switzerland, Bulgaria and Czechoslovakia are also seeking to join the 152 governments that are now members.

headline: Bush Promising Quicker Pursuit In Savings Cases
abstract: LEAD: President Bush entered the political battle over his Administration's handling of the savings and loan crisis today by announcing a plan to send ''teams of razor-sharp prosecutors and auditors'' to pursue and speed hundreds of investigations into savings and loan fraud.

headline: New Paper Containers Extending Shelf Life
abstract: LEAD: The paper industry, trying to counter gains by plastics in the packaging industry, is developing new kinds of containers that are not only cheaper than plastic but significantly extend the shelf lives of juices, soups, fabric softeners, cereals, insecticides and many other products.

headline: Orders for Durable Goods Fell 4.1% Last Month
abstract: LEAD: Orders for durable goods reversed direction in April after two months of increases and fell 4.1 percent, the Government said today.

headline: Markets Closed For Holiday
abstract: LEAD: In observance of Memorial Day, all financial markets in the United States were closed yesterday. The financial markets in Britain were closed in observance of a bank holiday.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD: The Economy

headline: Strategic Interests Tie U.S. to Liberia
abstract: LEAD: United States strategic interests tie Washington to the Liberian crisis, even as American officials privately voice criticism of the nation's embattled President and the leader of rebel forces moving on the capital.

headline: Stocks Up; Dow Rises 6.53 Points
abstract: LEAD: Stocks advanced yesterday in cautious trading for the fourth day in a row, falling back from a strong gain to end the day only slightly ahead.

headline: A Color Fax Machine Will Make Debut in Japan
abstract: LEAD: The Sharp Corporation of Japan says it will soon introduce a desktop machine for full-color facsimiles in that country, but has not decided whether to sell the device in the United States because of concerns that American business will find it too expensive and lack needed high-quality telephone lines.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Avondale Mills Inc., Sylacauga, Ala., a fabrics and yarns company, said John G. Hudson, its president and chief operating officer, will retire on Aug. 31. The company promoted Richard H. Monk Jr. to executive vice president and said he was expected to succeed Mr. Hudson. The company also announced the resignation of George B.

headline: German Union Instills Vision Of a Great Continent Reborn
abstract: LEAD: When European business leaders describe their vision of Europe, they usually talk of building a bigger, more united, more dynamic continent. German unification fits neatly into that vision.

headline: Milken Plea Is Said to Be Set for Today
abstract: LEAD: Michael R. Milken, who created the high-yield ''junk bond'' market that financed many of the big corporate takeovers in the 1980's, will plead guilty today to violating a series of regulations governing securities transactions, people who have been briefed about the plea agreement said.

headline: China Cuts Deposit Rates
abstract: LEAD: Interest rates on bank deposits here have been reduced by 1.26 percentage points in a move intended to stimulate China's sluggish economy.

headline: Jordan Halts March to West Bank
abstract: LEAD: Jordanian police officers and troops backed by tanks threw tear gas and fired into the air today to disperse thousands of demonstrators who tried to enter the Israeli-occupied West Bank during a pro-Palestinian march.

headline: Yield Is 9.814% On Maytag Issue
abstract: LEAD: A $200 million debenture issue by the Maytag Corporation was priced yesterday through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

headline: MILITANTS PROMISE TO FREE AMERICAN
abstract: LEAD: A pro-Iranian group believed to be holding three American hostages in Beirut said today that it would release one of them within 48 hours.

headline: Market Place;   The Mystery Of the Gold Selloff
abstract: LEAD: NEARLY a month after investors in gold suffered their biggest losses in seven years, precious metals analysts are still trying to find out who or what caused the March 26 selloff, and why.

headline: Keating Files Third Lawsuit
abstract: LEAD: Charles H. Keating Jr. has filed a new lawsuit contending that Federal banking regulators waged a vendetta against him, destroying the American Continental Corporation and his personal fortunes.

headline: Lisbon Plans Cutbacks
abstract: LEAD: The Portuguese Government plans to cut the country's deficit and lower inflation to prevent Portugal from falling behind as Europe approaches economic and monetary union by the end of 1992. The Finance Minister, Miguel Beleza, said Friday that the economic adjustment plan would cut Government spending and possibly raise some tax rates on purchases.

headline: President Aims to Cut Debt At Hotel Investors Trust
abstract: LEAD: Hotel Investors Trust, which owns and manages hotels throughout the United States, has named John D. Morrissey as its president and chief executive.

headline: Treasury Prices Dip in Slow Day
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities dipped in lethargic trading yesterday, as credit market participants chose to ignore potentially favorable developments in other markets.

headline: Farm Credit Bonds To Yield 8.807%
abstract: LEAD: The Farm Credit System Financial Assistance Corporation yesterday priced $325 million in 8.80 percent bonds due 2005 at a price of 99 30/32, to yield 8.807 percent, through 25 securities dealers and dealer banks.

headline: Few Subscribe to Private Trading System
abstract: LEAD: A new computerized trading system intended to match buyers and sellers of private securities is off to a slow start. The system, called Portal, is scheduled to begin on June 15,but large insurance companies and other institutional buyers have been reluctant to subscribe - even though the system is being offered for free.

headline: Wieden & Kennedy Wins the Kelly Award
abstract: LEAD: Wieden & Kennedy last night won advertising's most lucrative award, the $100,000 Kelly Award, given by the Magazine Publishers of America for best magazine ad of the year.

headline: Bush and Kohl Discuss Moscow's Concerns
abstract: LEAD: After meeting with Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany, President Bush said Friday night that ''we're making progress'' in easing Soviet fears about a united Germany in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Mr. Bush said he and Mr. Kohl agreed that Moscow has ''understandable interests'' in the military future of

headline: Ireland Bans Smoking In Buses and Movies
abstract: LEAD: The Irish Government outlawed smoking in theaters and buses today and ordered segregated smoking areas to be set up in Government buildings, trains, schools, libraries, hospitals, airports, supermarkets, restaurants and art galleries.

headline: The Latest Penny-Stock Shuffle
abstract: LEAD: Aviation Education Systems of Melville, L.I., sells preparatory courses to would-be air traffic controllers. The Southnet Corporation of Tampa, Fla., is asking hotels to use its telephone operator assistance services. Exten Ventures of San Diego calls itself a merchant banker and collects fees for helping tiny companies become publicly traded.

headline: Patents;   Tube Device May Replace Insulin Shots
abstract: LEAD: To free diabetes patients from the need to inject themselves with insulin each day, a surgeon in Texas has invented what amounts to a drug factory that could be inserted into a vein.

headline: Penguins Stampede and Die
abstract: LEAD: Thousands of king penguins at a rookery on Macquarie Island stampeded, leaving 7,000 penguins dead, and officials said today that they were investigating the mysterious occurrence. ''We don't know at this stage why they stampeded,'' a spokesman for the Australian State Parks Wildlife and Heritage Ministry said.

headline: Prices Paid to Farmers Show April Rise of 0.7%
abstract: LEAD: Prices farmers get for raw products increased by seven-tenths of 1 percent in April, raising the overall commodity index 2 percent above a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Busch-ESPN Pact
abstract: LEAD: The Anheuser-Busch Companies and the cable sports network ESPN said yesterday that they had agreed to a five-year contract worth ''in excess of $100 million.'' The companies' last five-year contract was reportedly worth $70 million. Anheuser-Busch became ESPN's first advertiser in 1979, when it signed a one-year agreement for $1.4 million.

headline: Pinnacle Unit Sells Resort to Japanese
abstract: LEAD: The Pinnacle West Capital Corporation said its Suncor Development Company subsidiary had sold an Arizona resort to a Japanese company for $70 million. Suncor said that Kabuto International Phoenix Inc., a subsidiary of Kabuto Decom Inc. of Japan, had purchased the Wigwam Resort and Country Club in Litchfield Park, Ariz.

headline: Article 012790 -- No Title
abstract: LEAD: The City and County of Denver are tentatively offering $600 million in airport system revenue bonds to help finance a portion of the costs of the new Denver International Airport and some related costs.

headline: 93 NATIONS MOVE TO BAN CHEMICALS THAT HARM OZONE
abstract: LEAD: In a landmark agreement, most of the world's nations vowed today that by the end of the century they would halt the production of chemicals that destroy the atmosphere's protective ozone layer.

headline: German Unification Means Taxes for the East
abstract: LEAD: If the Government's proposals for monetary and economic union of the two Germanys are adopted, East Germans can expect to find their freshly printed and minted West German marks quickly falling prey to a less pleasant element: taxation.

headline: Refiners Are Pushed to Clean Fuel
abstract: LEAD: When Congress talks about clean air these days, it is focusing heavily on the refinery - the jumbled maze of pipes and tanks that stands between 7.5 million barrels of oil a day and 140 million tailpipes.

headline: Morocco Plans Offshore Bank
abstract: LEAD: Morocco plans to create an offshore banking system and a large industrial free zone to capitalize on its proximity to the European Community, the Finance Minister, Mohamed Berrada, said Wednesday night.

headline: Electronic Headhunting
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Air Link Snag Seen
abstract: LEAD: The European Commission will block a linkup of British Airways, Belgium's Sabena World Airlines and the Netherlands' KLM Royal Dutch Airlines on the ground that it restricts competition, commission sources said.

headline: Angola Says It Will Begin Talks With Rebels Soon
abstract: LEAD: Leaders of the Angolan Government said today that they would soon begin peace talks with rebel forces in an effort to end 15 years of civil war.

headline: Faces of the Summit: 30 Years of High Drama
abstract: LEAD:       September 1959: President Eisenhower and Nikita S. Khrushchev meet at Camp David, Md. The talks result in the ''spirit of Camp David,'' an effort to press for scientific and cultural exchanges and disarmament.       June 1961: Khrushchev and President Kennedy have heated exchanges in Vienna.

headline: Governor of Kashmir Resigns
abstract: LEAD: The Governor of the state of Jammu and Kashmir, who oversaw the four-month crackdown against Muslim militants here, resigned today and is likely to be replaced by a top security official. The resignation of the Governor, Jagmohan, came as members of Parliament in New Delhi demanded his removal over the killing of at least 50 people by paramilitary troops on Monday after the assassination of a top religious leader here.

headline: 'Twin Peaks' May Provide A Ratings Edge for ABC
abstract: LEAD: ABC, which already broadcasts the hottest new television show, ''America's Funniest Home Videos,'' has made a serious move toward taking over prime-time leadership next fall based on the unexpected success of ''Twin Peaks.''

headline: Economic Scene;   Pressures Mount For a Budget Deal
abstract: LEAD: POWERFUL forces have been pushing the President and the Democratic leadership of Congress toward a deal to cut the widening budget deficit, even if that involves an increase in taxes. The deficit could soar to well over $200 billion in the fiscal year 1991 as a result of lower revenues, higher interest payments and a bigger bill for bailing out savings and loan institutions than the

headline: In Emigre Crush, Tent Towns Sprout for Israelis
abstract: LEAD: Little tent towns began springing up across the nation this week.

headline: Prices Paid To Farmers Up 2% in May
abstract: LEAD: Prices farmers get for raw products increased 2 percent in May from April, raising the overall commodity index 3.4 percent above a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Adobe Systems Inc., Palo Alto, Calif., a software company, said it had acquired BluePoint Technologies, a New Hampshire-based maker of computer chips, for undisclosed terms.

headline: Singer Back in South Africa
abstract: LEAD: The singer Miriam Makeba, who won international acclaim during her 31 years in exile from her native South Africa, received an emotional homecoming today.

headline: P.&G. Profits Rise by 30%
abstract: LEAD: The Procter & Gamble Company, one of the world's leading makers of consumer products, said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings rose more than 30 percent, to $404 million, or $1.14 a share, compared with a profit of $310 million, or 92 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year ago.

headline: Wall Street In Search of Itself on the Yampa
abstract: LEAD: The band of Wall Streeters and other executives had already scaled 100 feet of the side of a mountain, when Al Brown yelled the news. The group had to name the next two climbs, he said, adding that they would be difficult.

headline: French Suspects Held in Basque Terror
abstract: LEAD: A routine identity check on a highway near Seville has led to the arrest of a band of French terrorist suspects who reportedly carried out at least 33 killings over the last 12 years on behalf of the Spanish Basque separatist group E.T.A.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Victory Seen for Nationalists in Yugoslav Republic
abstract: LEAD: A conservative nationalist party appears to have swept to victory in the opening round of the first free multiparty elections to be held in the Yugoslav republic of Croatia in more than 50 years.

headline: In Changing South Africa, 5 Deaths Reveal Unrest
abstract: LEAD: The killing of two whites at a gold mine at Welkom, about 140 miles southwest of here, and the slaying of three blacks in an adjoining township have exposed broader racial tensions between blacks and whites in South Africa. Those tensions are increasingly coming to the surface as a result of the political liberalization under way in the country.

headline: House of Lords Bars War-Crimes Trials in Britain
abstract: LEAD: In a rare challenge to the House of Commons, the House of Lords today overwhelmingly rejected a Government bill that would have permitted the prosecution of suspected Nazi war criminals now living in Britain for offenses committed in the Baltics, Byelorussia and the Ukraine 50 years ago.

headline: Beijing Journal;   Marxism Died and Left a Big Hole in Their Lives
abstract: LEAD: A secular age of faith appears to have collapsed in China, turning into a time of despair and doubt in which many people have no heroes and nothing to believe in.

headline: Amgen Has Profit in Period
abstract: LEAD: Spurred by sales of its anemia drug, Amgen Inc. today reported substantial sales and earnings. Sold under the name Epogen, erythropoeitin is Amgen's first product approved for sale by the Food and Drug Administration.

headline: Colombian Rebels Release U.S. Miner
abstract: LEAD: Colombian guerrillas today freed Scott Heimdal, the American gold miner who was kidnapped two months ago, an spokesman for the Ecuadorean Government said.

headline: Ernst & Young Selects Health-Care Consultant
abstract: LEAD: Joseph W. Duva, who gained attention for his work to cut the corporate cost of health care at the Allied-Signal Corporation, is widening his arena, as a benefits consultant for Ernst & Young.

headline: G.M.A.C. Offering $250 Million Notes
abstract: LEAD: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation, a unit of the General Motors Corporation, is offering $250 million in notes due 2000 through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   MOSCOW SAYS CUTS IN ENERGY SUPPLIES TO LITHUANIA BEGIN
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet authorities told Lithuanian officials today that they would halt crude oil supplies to Lithuania's only refinery and curb the flow of natural gas. This set off calls in Lithuania's Parliament for scaling back independence measures that had provoked the Kremlin's economic move.

headline: P.&G. Agrees to Purchase Part of American Cyanamid
abstract: LEAD: The American Cyanamid Company said yesterday that it had agreed to sell part of its consumer-products business, including Old Spice after shave, to the Procter & Gamble Company.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Old Political Rifts Surface in Poland Now That the Communists Are Out
abstract: LEAD: As the Solidarity movement fractures, the political debate in Poland is beginning to reflect a broad spectrum of interests and antagonisms dividing this nation of 39 million people.

headline: How a Conductor Brought Harmony To East Germany's Peaceful Revolt
abstract: LEAD: To New Yorkers he is the future music director of the New York Philharmonic, but to the people of East Germany, especially those of Leipzig, Kurt Masur is a hero of the revolution that overthrew Communist rule and the man who might have been President.

headline: Orders to Factories Rose 3.8% in March
abstract: LEAD: Orders to factories for manufactured goods rose in March for the second straight month, the Government said today in a report that analysts interpreted as another sign that the industrial sector is recovering from months of weakness.

headline: Looking Ahead
abstract: LEAD:    MONDAY: The United Nations General Assembly convenes a special session on promoting economic growth in developing nations. Martin R. Shugrue is scheduled to discuss his plans as special trustee of Eastern Airlines.       TUESDAY: Automobile sales for April 11 to 20.    Durable goods orders for March.

headline: An Empire at Risk - Trump's Atlantic City;   Debt Forcing Trump to Play for Higher Stakes
abstract: LEAD: For Donald J. Trump, the 43-year-old entrepreneur who built his business empire during the 1980's with borrowed money, the stakes are highest, and the game hardest, along the sandy Boardwalk of Atlantic City.

headline: Liberian Rebels Scorn Talks And Vow Assault on Capital
abstract: LEAD: Liberian rebels said today that they had lost patience with peace talks and vowed to oust President Samuel K. Doe with an assault on Monrovia.

headline: Foreign Passports Tell of a Desperate Hong Kong
abstract: LEAD: The term ''pregnancy leave'' is taking on a new meaning here, as shown by a successful Hong Kong Chinese banker who is negotiating an unusual sweetener before he takes a new job. He wants his employer to pay to send his pregnant wife to Canada to give birth, insuring that their child will be born a

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Ted Chin: Candid and Respected
abstract: LEAD: POKING fun at an old stereotype, Ted Chin, a rare Chinese-American advertising executive, likes to refer to himself as inscrutable. His friends laugh when he says it, for Mr. Chin is one of the most candid individuals in advertising. In an industry where criticism is usually given privately, Mr. Chin goes public.

abstract: LEAD: Following is a list of guests at President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's breakfast at the Soviet Embassy today:       Soviet Participants       Ambassador Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh       Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze       Yuri D. Maslyukov, chairman of the state planning agency       Yevgeny M.

headline: G.M.A.C. Notes Have 8.85% Yield
abstract: LEAD: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation offered $300 million worth of notes through an underwriting syndicate led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The 8 7/8 percent notes, which have a final maturity date of June 1, 2010, are noncallable for life. The securities, however, carry puts that can be exercised in 1995, 2000, and 2005.

headline: Debate on Phone System: Is U.S. Falling Behind?
abstract: LEAD: In Congressional hearings and a closed-door conference of top Federal and state regulators this week, a bitter debate has flared over whether the nation's telephone system is being modernized quickly enough.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   3 Admit to Vandalism At a French Cemetery
abstract: LEAD: The authorities said today that three neo-Nazi skinheads had admitted to desecrating a Roman Catholic cemetery near Rennes in western France last Wednesday night.

headline: Foreigners Criticize Venture Bill
abstract: LEAD: A bill intended to enhance the competitiveness of United States business has provoked such strong opposition from foreign investors that they have taken the unusual step of asking the Speaker of the House to take the measure off the House calendar.

headline: New Publisher for McCall's
abstract: LEAD: Michael Golden was named publisher of McCall's magazine yesterday by William T. Kerr, president of The New York Times Magazine Group, which owns the publication. Mr. Golden had been general manager of Child magazine, also a member of the group, since January 1988.

abstract: LEAD:          Companies

headline: Baker Seeks to Avoid Breaking Off P.L.O. Talks
abstract: LEAD: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d indicated today that the Bush Administration was trying to do all it could to avoid breaking off the United States-P.L.O. dialogue because that would mean an end to the current peace process.

headline: Talking Deals;   No End in Sight In Norton Battle
abstract: LEAD: THE bruising weeks-old fight for the Norton Company by BTR, a British conglomerate, is far from over. And the fight could grow nastier as Norton, a maker of abrasives based in Worcester, Mass., continues to throw obstacles in its opponent's path, and BTR sinks its teeth in and hangs on.

headline: Britain Says I.R.A. Appears to Be Stepping Up Its Attacks Outside Ulster
abstract: LEAD: British Government officials and analysts from both sides of the Irish Sea say the Irish Republican Army appears to be stepping up its attacks on British soldiers outside Northern Ireland.

headline: Real Estate;   A Face Lift In Midtown Manhattan
abstract: LEAD: IN the vernacular of office building renovation, a face lift is usually a cosmetic updating of a tired-looking property through methods ranging from basic cleaning and repairs to elaborate resurfacings.

headline: Can Harcourt Brace Survive Its Debt?
abstract: LEAD: There's a big question facing the publishing house of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. these days: What price victory? Publishing legend William I. Jovanovich built one of America's biggest book empires over a span of nearly four decades and then, three years ago, fended off a raider's attack by borrowing nearly $3 billion.

headline: Mexico Plans To Privatize Bank System
abstract: LEAD: President Carlos Salinas de Gortari sent the Mexican Congress a constitutional amendment today that would reprivatize the country's banking system, which has been in state hands since 1982, and allow private interests to set up new financial institutions.

headline: Cease-Fire Begins in Nicaragua As the Contras Agree to Disarm
abstract: LEAD: Leaders of the Sandinista Government, the government-elect and the contra rebel army signed agreements today for an immediate cease-fire in Nicaragua's eight-year civil war and the complete disarming of the rebel army by June 10.

headline: P.L.O. Completes Buildup in Lebanon
abstract: LEAD: Eight years after Israel's armed forces drove the Palestine Liberation Organization guerrillas out of Lebanon, the organization has completed the rebuilding of its military forces in the country. P.L.O. hard-liners are urging Yasir Arafat to abandon hopes for a negotiated settlement of the Israeli-Palestinian dispute and use the forces against Israel.

headline: Pic N' Save Truce With Dissidents
abstract: LEAD: The Pic 'N' Save Corporation reached a truce with Girard Partners L.P., a dissident shareholder group trying to gain control of its board. The parties said Pic 'N' Save's annual meeting would be postponed until Aug. 15 and neither would solicit proxies or consents before July 15. The pact allows Pic 'N' Save, based in Dominguez, Calif., and its investment bankers to concentrate on finding bidders for the company, which could include Girard.

headline: British Inflation Up
abstract: LEAD: British inflation rose at a steep 9.7 percent annual rate in May, the Government said Friday. The Central Statistical Office said the rise reflected increases in housing costs, higher tax rates on alcoholic beverages and tobacco and increased charges for natural gas and electricity. The inflation rate that excludes the cost of home loans and the poll tax, a new levy to finance local government services, rose to an annual 7 percent in May, from 6.5 percent in April.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   European Leaders Back Kohl's Plea to Aid Soviets
abstract: LEAD: Leaders of the European Community, under pressure from Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany to help speed German unification, agreed today on steps that he requested to reassure the Soviet Union.

headline: The Executive Life;  The Serious Business of Executive Amusements
abstract: LEAD: Take a look around the first-class cabin on your next international airline flight. Whole rows of traveling executives can be found hunched for hours over what looks like a slightly bulky walkie-talkie with a tiny video screen. At first glance, it might appear that these businessmen and women, their gaze intent, their fingers punching away furiously at the buttons on their miniature keyboards, are working on some exciting business plan or project that must be completed before they land.

headline: Tokyo Stock Tumult Cuts Earnings of Banks
abstract: LEAD: Japan's major banks announced their earnings today for the just-ended fiscal year, and, as had been expected, most reported lower profits and margins because of the tumultuous changes affecting the financial markets here.

headline: Dallas Bank Chairman Quits
abstract: LEAD: Charles Pistor has resigned as chairman of a small Dallas bank, a post he took after leaving the huge First Republicbank Corporation shortly before it failed.

headline: Peruvian Bars Drug Accord Unless U.S. Helps on Crops
abstract: LEAD: President Alan Garcia has declared that he will not sign an agreement with the United States to combat the cocaine trade if the accord does not include economic compensation for losses from growing coca leaf.

headline: Panel on Bombing Seeks Revamping of F.A.A.
abstract: LEAD: The Presidential commission that investigated the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 has concluded that the Federal Aviation Administration is not properly organized to prevent or respond to such attacks and that it should revamp its anti-terrorist activities, Federal officials say.

headline: Bush Son Faced Ban In January
abstract: LEAD: In January Federal regulators considered action against Neil Bush, the President's son, that would have banned him from ever again serving as an official of a savings and loan institution or a bank, according to a document released today by the House Banking Committee.

headline: AIDS Virus and Its Stigma Plaguing Women in Zambia
abstract: LEAD: Rhoda Banda, a thin 20-year-old woman with an occasional broad smile and lively laugh, is one of only two people in her village who made it to secondary school.

headline: Family First, Mrs. Bush Tells Friend and Foe at Wellesley 44
abstract: LEAD: Barbara Bush today gently confronted seniors at Wellesley College who had protested her choice as their commencement speaker, telling them that husbands and children are ultimately more important than careers.

headline: Addendum
abstract: LEAD: * TVSM Inc., the publisher of The Cable Guide, has merged with Cable Publications Inc., the division of the Crosby Vandenburgh Group that publishes TV Entertainment magazine. The company will retain the TVSM name and will continue to publish both of the monthly television listings guides.

headline: Mosbacher on World Trade
abstract: LEAD: Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher chided American companies for taking a short-term view of profits and for being slow in taking advantage of new Eastern European markets.

headline: Ad for Nike Wins Again
abstract: LEAD: Wieden & Kennedy continued its sweep of the leading advertising awards last night, winning the best-of-show prize for print at the National Addy Awards in St. Louis, presented by the American Advertising Federation.

headline: Harris Bankcorp Will Lay Off 320
abstract: LEAD: Harris Bankcorp, Illinois's third-largest bank, said it would discharge 320 employees and take a $16 million pretax charge in the second quarter. The job reductions, cutting 8 percent of the bank's work force, ''took place at all levels of the organization and at all departments,'' a Harris spokeswoman said.

headline: Procter Sees Higher Profit
abstract: LEAD: The Procter & Gamble Company expects to enjoy strong sales and income growth in the fiscal year ending June 30, Edwin Artzt, company chairman, said today at a rare meeting with industry analysts.

headline: Gorbachev Plans to Meet South Korean, U.S. Says
abstract: LEAD: In a major step toward improving relations with South Korea, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has agreed to meet with President Roh Tae Woo of South Korea during his visit to the United States, Administration officials said today.

headline: U.S. Removes Ban On Hughes Bids
abstract: LEAD: The Hughes Aircraft Company, a unit of the General Motors Corporation, said the United States Air Force had lifted a new business suspension against the Hughes Missile Systems Group. The Air Force action allows the unit to bid for Government contracts.

headline: Savings Units Trim 'Junk' Holdings
abstract: LEAD: During the final quarter of 1989, savings and loan associations sold ''junk bonds'' with a face value of $2.8 billion, according to a recently completed study by K. H. Thomas Associates, a bank and savings industry consulting firm in Miami.

headline: BSN Is Selling U.S. Biscuit Units
abstract: LEAD: The French food manufacturer BSN S.A. put its United States biscuit subsidiaries on the block as part of its plan to focus on high-growth markets in Eastern Europe and Asia. The company said its Mother's and Salerno subsidiaries, with combined annual revenue of about $200 million, hold only 5.7 percent of the United States biscuit market.

headline: Money Fund Assets Up
abstract: LEAD: The assets of the nation's 503 money market mutual funds increased by $94.70 million, to $381.41 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 159 institutional funds increased by $141.40 million, to $92.80 billion. The assets of the 242 general-purpose funds were down by $750.10 million, to $129.48 billion.

headline: Warner Joins Walt Disney In Banning Ads at Its Films
abstract: LEAD: Warner Brothers has followed the lead of the Walt Disney Company in banning commercials from movie screens where its pictures are shown.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Top Hungarian Parties Agree to Elect Dissident Writer to Presidency
abstract: LEAD: As a freely elected Parliament convened here for the first time in four decades, Hungary's leading political parties agreed today that Arpad Goncz, a writer jailed for six years after the 1956 uprising, would be elected President of the nation.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Statesman Elected in Greece
abstract: LEAD: Parliament elected Constantine Karamanlis as President today, making the 83-year-old conservative elder statesman the head of state for the next five years. Mr. Karamanlis mustered the support of 153 of the 300 deputies in Parliament - 2 more than the required minimum of 151. His New Democracy Party, now led by Constantine Mitsotakis, won a thin working majority in Parliament in elections last month.

headline: Newspaper Advertising Continues To Weaken
abstract: LEAD: With advertising soft and profits down at many dailies, the annual convention of the nation's newspaper publishers, which starts here on Monday, is not expected to be a particularly happy affair.

headline: Newspaper Family Group Acts to Block Dissident
abstract: LEAD: The majority owners of Freedom Newspapers Inc. have solidified their defenses against a dissident family member by turning over control of the two-thirds of the company's stock they own to a voting committee and agreeing to sell shares only to each other for five years, The Orange County Register, Freedom's flagship newspaper in Santa Ana,

headline: Law Allows Banks to Sell Insurance
abstract: LEAD: Efforts by large banks to expand into the insurance business were rewarded yesterday as Delaware enacted laws allowing banks in the state to sell insurance nationwide.

headline: Talking Business; with Yamaguchi of N.T.T.;   Where U.S. Can Compete in Japan
abstract: LEAD: The Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Company, which provides almost all local and long-distance telephone service in Japan, has drawn international attention for its new willingness to import foreign equipment after years of resistance and for its opposition to an American-style separation of local and long-distance service.

headline: Despite Progress on Arms, Bush Expects Some Disputes
abstract: LEAD: Satisfied with the progress made in Moscow on arms control issues, President Bush said today that he still has a ''wide array'' of disputes to take up with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev when they meet in Washington next week.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Europe United?
abstract: LEAD: With France and West Germany leading the way, the European Community is about to set off down the road toward political union, but its 12 member nations are still far from agreement over how much sovereignty they are willing to surrender.      The very concept of

headline: Aquino Backers Form Political Organization
abstract: LEAD: President Corazon C. Aquino announced the formation of a political organization today to mobilize support for her administration.

headline: 16 East European Journalists Observe at U.S. Magazines
abstract: LEAD: For the next 10 weeks, 16 Eastern European journalists will spend their days at leading magazine companies in New York to study how Americans edit, publish, promote, distribute and attract advertisers to their magazines.

headline: Chrysler in Talks On a New Plant
abstract: LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation is negotiating with the Mitsubishi International Corporation for a stamping plant to be built next to Chrysler's assembly factory in Bramalea, Ontario, the company said. The assembly factory is likely to make Chrysler's next generation of midsize cars, the LH and LX.

headline: 4 Options Exchanges Agree On a New Trading System
abstract: LEAD: Four of the nation's five exchanges that trade stock options have agreed upon a new computer system for options trading, and officials of the Securities and Exchange Commission said it could be in place by the end of the year.

headline: Alcoa in Contract On Recycled Cans
abstract: LEAD: Browning-Ferris Industries announced an agreement to sell more than one billion used aluminum cans yearly to the Alcoa Recycling Company. Browning-Ferris, based in Houston, is one of the world's largest waste handling companies. It collects cans through organized recycling efforts in 170 programs nationwide.
