headline: U.S. Report Describes Weak Soviet Economy
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet economy is in such bad shape that a ''single major event,'' like a long strike or new ethnic unrest, could cause economic chaos, Congress was told yesterday.

headline: Evolution in Europe: East Berlin Journal;   A First U.S. Visit, and Maybe a Last
abstract: LEAD: For Lothar de Maiziere, the idea that he is about to be the first East German leader to visit the United States is not really that extraordinary.

headline: Islamic Party in Algeria Defeats Ruling Group in Local Elections
abstract: LEAD: The Islamic Salvation Front, which advocates turning Algeria into an Islamic republic, scored a stunning success in this country's first free election since it gained independence from France 28 years ago.

headline: Treasuries Off in Quiet Trading
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities dipped slightly in lifeless trading yesterday, as credit market participants marked time before a slew of economic reports are released.

headline: Washington Post's Net Off
abstract: LEAD: The Washington Post Company today reported a 6 percent decline in first-quarter earnings, attributing the weaker results to lower advertising sales at three important divisions.

headline: Pope Challenges Rich Nations to Start Sharing
abstract: LEAD: Pope John Paul II warned today that Communism's collapse did not mean capitalism had triumphed, and he challenged industrialized countries and big business to stop ''hoarding'' and start distributing wealth fairly.

headline: CORRECTIONS
abstract: LEAD: An article in the special Careers section last Sunday about jobs in the environmental safety industry misidentified a New York recruiter who specializes in the area. He is William Alford.

headline: A.T.&T. Debt Is Upgraded
abstract: LEAD: The rating on about $9.2 billion of American Telephone and Telegraph Company debt was upgraded yesterday by Moody's Investors Service Inc.

headline: Michener's Random Deal
abstract: LEAD: A month after he threatened to abandon Random House, the novelist James Michener has decided to stay with his longtime publisher after all.

headline: East Europe Deals For Control Data
abstract: LEAD: The Control Data Corporation said it had received a $9 million letter of intent from Poland to buy a computerized energy management system. The system, expected to be financed by the World Bank, may not require an export license because of an easing of export restrictions agreed to by the United States and its allies in Paris last week, said Dieter Porzel, vice president of Control Data's central

headline: Evolution in Europe: In Unity, Perhaps Strength;   3 Baltic Chiefs Agree to Coordinate Their Policies
abstract: LEAD: The presidents of the three Baltic republics met today and agreed to coordinate foreign and domestic policies in a united effort to gain their independence from Moscow.

headline: Southland Reports Loss Of $1.01 Billion in Period
abstract: LEAD: The Southland Corporation, the owner of 7-Eleven convenience stores, said today that it had lost $1.01 billion in the fourth quarter of last year and that it might seek bankruptcy if it could not restructure its debt.

headline: Martin Seeks National Recognition
abstract: LEAD: HAVING weathered the departure of its founder, the hostile takeover of its parent company's parent company and an apparent renaissance in New York advertising, all in the last two years, the Martin Agency, one of the hot regional ad agencies of the 1980's, is asking, ''What next?''

headline: Cyprus Journal;   What Next for the U.N. on This 'Fairy Tale' Isle?
abstract: LEAD: From a blue wooden hut overlooking the Pyla plateau in southern Cyprus, Maj. Franz Walch of the Austrian Army surveys the rippling wheat fields with satisfaction.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   For West's Christian Democrats, the East Offers a Chance and a Challenge
abstract: LEAD: With many former East bloc countries uncertain where the path away from Communism will lead them, Western Europe's Christian Democratic parties are trying to woo them toward a form of capitalism that emphasizes Christian social values.

headline: Bolivian Chief to Ask Bush for More Aid on Drugs
abstract: LEAD: President Jaime Paz Zamora plans to appeal to President Bush in Washington this week for a major increase in financial aid to help Bolivia get out of the cocaine business.

headline: Shifts at Chrysler
abstract: LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation named Lawrence W. Baker general manager for its Jeep/Eagle division, responsible for marketing, advertising and merchandising. He switches jobs with Martin R. Levine, who becomes general manager for the Dodge car and truck division. Chrysler also appointed Ralph A. Sarotte director of multi-brand marketing programs, responsible for media budgeting and corporate advertising.

headline: Ads for Chrysler Say Buyers Prefer Its Cars Over Honda's
abstract: LEAD: Suffering from a steep decline in its share of the United States vehicle market, the Chrysler Corporation is intensifying a two-month-old media blitz with new advertising based on a surprising finding that new-car buyers prefer Chrysler cars over those of the highly rated Honda Motor Company.

headline: Color Imaging, Step by Step
abstract: LEAD: At $700 for each new color photograph, last-minute additions of new products in The Hobie Catalog, published by the Hobie Cat Company of Oceanside, Calif., seemed out of the question - at least until Hobie Cat discovered ''color photo imaging.''

headline: Bache Officer Is Leaving In Shake-Up
abstract: LEAD: Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. announced a shake-up of its management yesterday, which included the departure of one of the firm's top executives.

headline: U.S. Says It Won't Return Mexican Doctor Linked to Drug Killing
abstract: LEAD: The Justice Department said today that it could not ''foresee any circumstances'' under which the Government would free a Mexican doctor whose arrest in the death of an American drug agent brought a Mexican threat to curtail drug-control operations with the United States.

headline: Cholera Outbreaks Highlight Zambia's Plight
abstract: LEAD: In the open-air market in Luangwa Township, where Winwell Sikombe sells overripe tomatoes arranged on the ground in small pyramids and dollops of cooking oil from two bottles, health officers in rubber boots and plastic aprons came to explain how to prevent cholera.

headline: Workers Disrupt Pan Am Meeting
abstract: LEAD: More than 150 union employees, angry over continuing losses at the Pan Am Corporation and the lack of a contract, jeered at the airline company's annual meeting and threatened to strike. Pan Am's 6,500 union reservation agents, cargo agents and clerical workers have worked without a contract for two years.

headline: The Economics of Popular Discontent
abstract: LEAD: There is a subtle, subversive political force at work in China - economic discontent.

headline: G.E. Names a Lawyer To Environment Post
abstract: LEAD: A former Justice Department lawyer who specializes in the enforcement of environmental laws was named yesterday to the top environmental position at the General Electric Company.

headline: Business Digest
abstract: LEAD:    The Economy

headline: Romania Is Reported in Nuclear Deal With India
abstract: LEAD: In the latest disclosure by the new authorities in Eastern Europe about the activities of past Communist Governments there, Romania has revealed that the Ceausescu Government had improperly diverted a supply of Norwegian heavy water to India, according to Norwegian officials.

headline: NEC Application For Sale to China
abstract: LEAD: The NEC Corporation said it would apply to Cocom for permission to export a work station to China as part of a contract to develop software there. The Paris-based Coordinating Committee for Multilateral Export Controls oversees exports of high technology from the West and Japan to Communist nations.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Cleveland Electric Illuminating Co., Cleveland, a wholly owned subsidiary of Centerior Energy Corp., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a shelf offering of $100 million in first mortgage bonds.       Common Stock

headline: Europe-Japan Talks Held
abstract: LEAD: The European Community and Japan held high-level talks today for the first time in three and a half years to try to clear the air between the two trading giants, European Community officials and diplomats said.

headline: Arabs Applaud Gorbachev Remark
abstract: LEAD: Palestinian and other Arab officials, increasingly worried by Washington's signals to the Middle East, today welcomed suggestions by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union that Soviet Jewish emigration might be limited to prevent further Jewish settlement of the occupied territories.

headline: Bally Revamping
abstract: LEAD: The Bally Manufacturing Corporation said it was considering several restructuring moves to raise shareholder value. As a first step, Bally offered an exchange of common stock for its 13 5/8 percent subordinated debentures due on Jan. 2, 2001. Shares in Bally, which makes game machines and operates casinos, fell $1.50 today, to $10.625, on the New York Stock Exchange, where its 12.4 percent drop was the day's worst.

headline: Israel Charging Officer In Antigua Camp Case
abstract: LEAD: A senior Defense Ministry official said today that a police complaint would be filed charging a reserve colonel with holding unauthorized talks on the establishment of a military training camp in Antigua, the Caribbean island.

headline: Patents;   Upjohn Denies Charge Of Fraud on Minoxidil
abstract: LEAD: An attorney representing doctors who are being sued for infringing a patent on minoxidil, the hair-growing compound, asserted this week that the Upjohn Company obtained its key patent through fraud.

headline: Real Estate;  A Big Project In Rundown Linden Area
abstract: LEAD: FOR more than half a century a group of rundown warehouses has lined a 70-acre tract in the southeastern section of Linden, an old industrial city within a 20-minute drive of Manhattan. Now Hartz Mountain Industries of Secaucus plans to transform the site fronting the combined Routes 1 and 9, surrounded by oil refineries and manufacturing plants, into a new neighborhood with up to 1.1 million square feet of retail, commercial and light industrial space.

headline: REBEL FREED FROM MANILA JAIL
abstract: LEAD: Masked rebel soldiers stormed the Manila city jail today and freed Lt. Col. Billy Bibit, who is charged with helping to lead last December's failed coup, the police said. The Young Officers' Union, a shadowy group linked to the failed coup against President Corazon Aquino, took responsibility for the jailbreak.

headline: SOUTHWEST TO GET ECONOMIC BENEFITS IN SAVINGS BAILOUT
abstract: LEAD: The Federal cleanup of the savings and loan disaster will result in a significant transfer of wealth from the Northeast and Middle West to Texas and other states in the Southwest, many economists and politicians have concluded.

headline: The Executive Life;  How to Retire And Stay Alive, Too
abstract: LEAD: It was a day that Henry Kates, chief executive of the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company, would never forget. Sitting in a conference room at a Phoenix hotel with some 300 other Mutual Benefit insurance employees, Mr. Kates listened as a 69-year-old company field manager gave his retirement presentation.

headline: EUROPE HASTENING INTEGRATION PACE
abstract: LEAD: Leaders of the European Community agreed today to set the 12-nation organization on a path toward what they call political union, but they left it to coming negotiations to determine just how much sovereignty each country will have to surrender.

headline: Canary Wharf Gets Bank
abstract: LEAD: Olympia & York Canary Wharf Ltd. announced yesterday that Manufacturers Hanover Bank would relocate its British operations to Canary Wharf, a 71-acre office development in the West End of London.

headline: Duke Power Prices Bonds
abstract: LEAD: The Duke Power Company yesterday priced $150 million in first and refunding mortgage bonds through competitive bidding won by an underwriting group led by Kidder, Peabody & Company.

headline: Rousing a Sleeping Industrial Giant
abstract: LEAD: Not long after he became president of Mitsubishi Heavy Industries last year, Kentaro Aikawa took a tour of the company's sprawling aerospace works here. Mr. Aikawa spent most of his career as a shipbuilder and turbine engineer for the company in Nagasaki, so he was something of a stranger to the rows of F-15 fighters, Boeing 767 fuselages and Japanese rockets under construction.

headline: Treasuries Rally on Tax Vow
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities moved higher and interest rates fell in nervous trading yesterday, as dealers juggled a promise from President Bush and the onset of a flood of new Treasury issues.

headline: Foreign Landowners
abstract: LEAD: Foreigners continue to own just under 1 percent of the nation's agricultural land, a level that has varied little over the years, the Agriculture Department said today. The department's Economic Research Service made its 1989 end of the year review of reports under a 1978 law requiring foreigners to register American agricultural land holdings.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   40 REPORTED DEAD IN SOVIET CLASHES
abstract: LEAD: The Kremlin reported today that at least 40 people had been killed in three days of growing ethnic rioting and Soviet troop countermeasures in the Central Asian republic of Kirghizia.

headline: Honecker May Escape Trial
abstract: LEAD: The East German authorities have decided not to prosecute Erich Honecker, the ousted Communist leader, citing his failing health, the Interior Minister, Peter-Michael Diestel, said in an interview published today.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, APRIL 7, 1990
abstract: LEAD:          The Economy

headline: Soviets Reject a Call For Criminal Action On 2 Ex-Prosecutors
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Parliament rejected a call for criminal proceedings against two corruption investigators today, a day after 10,000 demonstrators rallied outside the Kremlin in support of the two men.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Soviets Are Said to Pull Nuclear Arms From Some Restive
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Government, concerned that ethnic unrest in some regions could imperil control of its nuclear arsenal, has begun moving scores of battlefield nuclear weapons out of troubled areas and into the more politically stable Russian republic, American officials said today.

headline: Nicaragua's Hard Road to a New Day
abstract: LEAD: Jan 10, 1978: Pedro Joaquin Chamorro, a newspaper publisher who is an outspoken opponent of the dictator Anastasio Somoza Debayle, is killed in downtown Managua, and widespread anti-Government protests ensue.

headline: Bush Delays Action on Lithuania, Not Wanting to Harm Gorbachev
abstract: LEAD: After conferring with allies and Congressional leaders, President Bush today delayed carrying out a threat to take action against Moscow for tightening its chokehold on Lithuania, fearing sanctions might undermine President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and worsen the Baltic crisis.

headline: Fund Yields Are Mixed
abstract: LEAD: Yields on money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed for the week ended yesterday.

headline: Agency Says It Met a Bailout Goal
abstract: LEAD: Working against a self-imposed deadline of June 30, the Resolution Trust Corporation, established to manage the savings and loan bailout, said it had all but cleared its first major hurdle by completing the sale of 140 insolvent savings institutions over the past three months to banks and other private investors.

headline: Dukakis Seeks to Bar State From Investing in Tobacco
abstract: LEAD: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis has decided to seek a ban on the investment of public funds in tobacco companies, a move that would make Massachusetts the first state to divest itself of tobacco stocks.

headline: At Last, Small Stocks May Be Ready to Party
abstract: LEAD: As Wall Street kept its cool and Tokyo's market fought one rumor-driven panic after another, the United States last week added a few percentage points to its thin lead in the worldwide game of stock-market supremacy.

headline: South Africa to Admit All Races As Patients in Its Public Hospitals
abstract: LEAD: In a significant retreat from apartheid, the Government announced today that it was opening South Africa's segregated public hospitals to all races.

headline: Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week
abstract: LEAD: Treasury financings this week are confined to today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills.

headline: Futures Trader Fined
abstract: LEAD: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange said a futures trader had agreed to a $50,000 fine and a six-month suspension of floor privileges to settle charges of a significant trading offense. The exchange said in a statement on Tuesday that the trader, Lloyd D. Gabbert, had directed the proceeds last October of certain trades of stock index futures into two accounts, improperly creating a loss in one and a profit in the other.

headline: BBDO Gets A President In New York
abstract: LEAD: AFTER nearly two years without a top executive to supervise account management, BBDO New York yesterday named Thomas H. Carey, a 23-year veteran of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, as its new president and chief operating officer.

headline: Kaifu Praises Trade Deal But Sees Some Difficulties
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu pleaded today for popular support of the changes his Government agreed to in trade talks with the United States, saying that they would eventually benefit Japanese consumers. But he acknowledged that the economic shifts would be ''painful'' and that he faced a potentially tough political battle to put the measures into effect.

headline: 115 Killed in Quake in China
abstract: LEAD: An earthquake rocked China's western region of Qinghai late Thursday, killing 115 people and flattening more than 1,000 homes, officials said today. Officials from Qinghai's seismological bureau said by telephone from the provincial capital, Xining, that the quake, measuring 6.9 on the Richter scale, also damaged a labor camp and that more than 200 convicts had escaped in the confusion.

headline: Brady Backs Bill to Shift Stock Futures to S.E.C.
abstract: LEAD: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady today threw the full weight of the Bush Administration behind legislation that would transfer jurisdiction over stock-index futures to the Securities and Exchange Commission from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

headline: U.S. Regains Export Lead
abstract: LEAD: The United States regained its position last year as the world's leading exporter, passing West Germany, the International Monetary Fund said on Sunday.

headline: Palestinian Revolt's Violence Declines
abstract: LEAD: It is 1 P.M. and Manger Square is swarming with tourists in search of souvenirs. But with the calm nonchalance born of routine, one by one all the Palestinian merchants show the customers out, then close and padlock their doors.

headline: World Trade Talks Advance Despite Farm-Price Dispute
abstract: LEAD: A meeting of the industrial democracies' finance ministers ended today with officials saying they had made some progress in global trade talks despite sharp differences between the United States and the European Community over agricultural trade.

headline: MANDELA'S GROUP CALLS OFF TALKS
abstract: LEAD: President F. W. de Klerk's plans for negotiations with South Africa's black majority suffered a setback today when the African National Congress announced that it was suspending plans to attend talks with the Government scheduled for April 11.

headline: Chip Maker Signs Pact With Soviets
abstract: LEAD: The Cypress Semiconductor Corporation said it planned to make computer chips and other electronic devices for the Soviet Union in an unusual licensing agreement that will give the company Soviet chip-making technologies. Cypress signed a letter of intent with the International Center for Informatics and Electronics of

headline: Strike Ends At Hyundai
abstract: LEAD: Production lines at South Korea's largest car maker, the Hyundai Motor Company, started up again today after a one-week strike.

headline: Pixar Plans Sale Of Computer Unit
abstract: LEAD: Pixar will sell its Image Computer unit to Vicom Systems Inc. Pixar said it was selling the hardware operation to concentrate on its Renderman software, which is used to produce pictures on desktop computers.

headline: 2 Are Saved and 20 Missing In Plane Crash Off Panama
abstract: LEAD: A twin-engine plane carrying 22 people crashed today shortly after takeoff from the Panamanian island of Contadora when birds were sucked into an engine, according to the airline, Aeroperlas. Twenty people were missing and two rescued, it said.

headline: Japan Criticized on Trade Progress
abstract: LEAD: The Senate Finance Committee's ranking specialists in trade policy expressed concern today that Japan was not living up to promises to open its economy and warned that Congress ''may have no choice'' but to respond with retaliatory legislation.

headline: Bulgaria Reports Discovery Of Mass Grave From 1940's
abstract: LEAD: A mass grave in which 40 people were buried has been found in southwestern Bulgaria, and the authorities believe that it dates from the Soviet invasion in World War II, the official news agency B.T.A. said today.

headline: China to Sell Companies
abstract: LEAD: China plans to sell four small state-owned companies in the Shenzhen special economic zone near Hong Kong to foreign or domestic interests, The People's Daily said today. The newspaper said all of the concerns were poorly managed and losing money.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Addendum
abstract: LEAD: * Poppe Tyson, a business-to-business advertising and public relations agency that is a subsidiary of Bozell, has opened an office in Los Angeles.

headline: Salomon Shows Profit; Morgan Stanley Net Up
abstract: LEAD: First-quarter earnings reported yesterday by two of Wall Street's biggest firms - Salomon Inc. and Morgan Stanley Group Inc. - were buoyed by strong trading profits. Investment banking revenues at both companies remained weak, reflecting the continued slowdown in corporate mergers and takeovers.

headline: Patents;   A New Way To Evaluate Race Horses
abstract: LEAD: When horse-racing professionals evaluate a thoroughbred before purchase, they scrutinize its pedigree, its health and its physical characteristics, like the length of its legs and the breadth of its chest.

headline: Chip Group Is Left With A Solid Base
abstract: LEAD: Industry and Government officials said today that Robert N. Noyce had attracted enough financial resources and managerial and scientific talent to Sematech that the consortium could succeed without him in command.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   600 Balkan Emigrants Call A Berlin Rail Station Home
abstract: LEAD: So far there is no name for them like the boat people of Indochina, but 600 Romanian citizens who have made their way in recent weeks to the Lichtenberg Station here might be called ''train people.''

headline: Czechoslovakia: Constitutional Scholars' Lab
abstract: LEAD: ''I rescheduled three classes to come to this, and I haven't ever rescheduled a class for a Supreme Court case,'' said Laurence H. Tribe, the Harvard Law School professor. But a constitutional convention is hard to resist.

headline: Alexandra Journal;   Afternoon Stroll Down Apartheid's Sad Streets
abstract: LEAD: On a sunny afternoon recently, Francis Faller took his 8-year-old daughter, Lara, on her first journey into an unfamiliar but friendly world.

headline: Wall Street Is Celebrating Despite Tax Talk
abstract: LEAD: Nobody ever went broke underestimating the fiscal irresponsibility of American politicians.

headline: Ogilvy Promotes Eight
abstract: LEAD: Ogilvy & Mather announced the appointment of eight senior vice presidents: Don Blashford, account director; Marcia Christ, associate creative director; Julie Friedlander, director of national broadcast negotiations; Rosalinde Rago, director of advertising research; Richard Russo, associate creative director; Daisy Sinclair, head of casting; Harold Sogard, account director, and Karl Westman, music producer.

headline: Ceausescu Wept as He Faced Firing Squad, Footage Shows
abstract: LEAD: Nicolae and Elena Ceausescu begged for mercy as soldiers prepared the Romanian dictator and his wife for the firing squad, according to footage of the execution broadcast here today.

headline: Patents;   Blow Dryer for Horses
abstract: LEAD: A Swiss company received a patent this week on a blow dryer for horses. The machine was designed to dry the animals before they catch cold from either their own sweat or from being washed. The machine consists of a large, heated blower that can be raised or lowered along a vertical track inside a large, vented, tent-like structure.

headline: Oil Prices Off Sharply as Supplies Rise
abstract: LEAD: Oil prices continued to tumble yesterday as mounting surpluses of petroleum caused increased waves of selling here and overseas. The May contract for crude oil settled at an eight-month low of $17.68 a barrel, down 76 cents, on the New York Mercantile Exchange, the largest energy market.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Bairnco Corp., New York, a holding company, said David C. Bevan Jr. had resigned as senior vice president for finance and administration, treasurer and secretary. J. Robert Wilkinson was named vice president for finance and treasurer, and Barry M. Steinhart was named vice president for administration and secretary.

headline: Radio Ship Docks in Taiwan Before Broadcasts to China
abstract: LEAD: Taiwanese set off firecrackers today to welcome the radio ship, the Goddess of Democracy, to northern Keelung, where she will refuel before heading for the high seas to broadcast pro-democracy messages to China.

headline: ITT Officer, Moving Up, Seen as Next President
abstract: LEAD: The ITT Corporation yesterday named Dale R. Comey, an executive at its insurance unit, as an executive vice president of the corporation, and a company official said that he had been identified as ITT's next president.

headline: Suitor of Norton Hints at Higher Bid
abstract: LEAD: BTR P.L.C., a British maker of industrial products, indicated it might be willing to sweeten its $1.64 billion hostile bid for the Norton Company if the plastics and ceramics company based in Worcester, Mass., could demonstrate it was worth a higher price. The London-based conglomerate said in United States Government filings that it had asked for confidential information and was prepared to meet with Norton, which so far has resisted the $75-a-share cash bid.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: LEAD:    General Assembly

headline: Japan's NKK Buys More of National Steel
abstract: LEAD: National Intergroup Inc., which owns 50 percent of the National Steel Corporation, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell all but 10 percent of the steel company to the NKK Corporation of Japan.

headline: LOOKING AHEAD
abstract: LEAD:    MONDAY: Memorial Day, Banks, government offices, stock exchange ans many businesses are closed.    Fox announces its fall television schedule.       TUESDAY: CBS announces its fall television schedule.    Investment Company Institute reports mutual fund investment figures for April one day this week.

headline: Conagra In Deal for Beatrice
abstract: LEAD: In a surprise announcement, Conagra Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Beatrice Company for $1.34 billion in a combination that would create the nation's second-largest food company.

headline: U.S. AND JAPAN SET ACCORD TO RECTIFY TRADE IMBALANCES
abstract: LEAD: After a year of wide-ranging critiques of each other's economies, the United States and Japan reached an unusual agreement today intended to trim America's spending excesses and to transform the Japanese economy, making it easier for foreigners to do business here.

headline: Jerrico Is Selling Restaurant Chains
abstract: LEAD: Jerrico Inc. agreed to sell two restaurant chains, Jerry's and Fazoli's, for undisclosed amounts so that it could concentrate on its Long John Silver's Seafood Shoppes. Jerry's has 46 restaurants, mainly in Kentucky and Indiana, and Fazoli's has five restaurants in Kentucky.

headline: ARCO Net Drops 22.3%
abstract: LEAD: ARCO said today that its first-quarter earnings fell 22.3 percent from last year's first quarter, when the company had a gain of $634 million from the initial public offering of the Lyondell Petrochemical Company.

headline: New Delta Service
abstract: LEAD: Delta Air Lines Inc. said it would begin hourly service between Los Angeles and San Francisco on June 1, offering a special one-way fare of $99 and double frequent-flier bonus miles. Delta said it would also offer a special $199 one-way fare for travel between Los Angeles and New York, with double frequent-flier bonus miles from June 1 to July 31.

headline: Upheaval in the East: Moscow Journal;   U.S. Passport Takes Gulag Survivor Halfway Through the Looking Glass
abstract: LEAD: Wary as only a gulag survivor can be, Morris Hershman stands alone and theoretically triumphant amid the throngs of Soviet citizens who wait outside the American Embassy these troubled days, taunted by the hope of emigration.

headline: Sale by Occidental
abstract: LEAD: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said its domestic oil and gas subsidiary had completed the sale of its Appalachian oil and gas properties to Ashland Exploration Inc. in a deal worth about $107 million. Ashland Exploration is a subsidiary of Ashland Oil Inc.

headline: Food Lion
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Evolution in Europe;   SOLE OIL REFINERY IN LITHUANIA SHUT BY SOVIET EMBARGO
abstract: LEAD: Lithuania's only oil refinery shut down tonight, its reserves exhausted by a five-day fuel embargo imposed by the Kremlin in the hope of weakening the republic's spirit of independence.

headline: Strike Ended in Nicaragua; Chamorro Gives Big Raises
abstract: LEAD: Government negotiators and striking union leaders announced agreement late tonight on a package of salary increases, job guarantees and other measures to end a weeklong strike by Sandinista-led civil servants that had brought the country's newly elected Government to a virtual standstill.

headline: I.B.M. Set To Re-enter PC Market
abstract: LEAD: Trying again in an area where it suffered its most embarrassing defeat, the International Business Machines Corporation plans to introduce a new home computer line next week.

headline: Lithuania Considers Delaying Full Independence
abstract: LEAD: As the Kremlin tightened its economic squeeze on Lithuania today, the President of the rebellious republic said his government would consider a moratorium on full independence as part of a deal with Moscow.

headline: MORE MEA CULPAS FOR THE ANNUAL REPORT
abstract: LEAD: For several years, many of the companies that consider themselves in the vanguard of financial reporting, like Boeing and Chrysler, have been reserving a little-noticed section in their annual reports for something called the ''management report.'' In it, members of top management acknowledge their responsibility for presentation of the numbers in the financial statements, affirm their commitment to maintaining adequate internal controls and sometimes even sign their names for emphasis.

headline: The P.L.O.: From Birth Amid Mideast Strife to Suspended U.S. Talks
abstract: LEAD: 1964 The Palestine Liberation Organi-zation is formed.

headline: Court Battle Over Rights To Bloomingdale's Store
abstract: LEAD: A bankruptcy court battle has broken out over the rights to the Bloomingdale's flagship store in Manhattan, with the Bloomingdale family, which no longer owns any part of the store but does own the land under it, seeking to evict the store by May 17.

headline: Blocked Funds Put U.S. Role In Seville World Fair in Doubt
abstract: LEAD: As work advances on the new auditoriums, pavilions and stadiums for the Seville World's Fair, Expo '92, Spanish and American officials are concerned that construction may never begin on one of the main attractions: the United States pavilion.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Animated Ads Used by VH-1
abstract: LEAD: In its last advertising campaign, the VH-1 cable music network presented a radiant, stylized view of the life style of young urban professionals that was reminiscent of the television show ''thirtysomething.''

headline: U S West Plans Stock Offering
abstract: LEAD: U S West Inc. has filed plans to make the first additional stock offering in its six-year history in an effort to raise about $525 million for several projects. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday, U S West disclosed plans to offer 14 million new shares of common stock.

headline: Rolling Stone's Publisher To Start a Men's Magazine
abstract: LEAD: Yet another general-interest men's magazine is on the drawing board. Straight Arrow Publishers Inc., the publisher of Rolling Stone, announced yesterday that it would introduce the new men's magazine in the fall of 1991.

headline: New England Bank
abstract: LEAD: The Bank of New England Corporation said today that it would sell $665 million in assets of a subsidiary, New England Commercial Finance Corporation, to the National Bank of Canada for an undisclosed price. The move is part of an asset sales program at the bank, which reported $1.11 billion in losses in 1989, mostly because of bad real estate loans.

headline: J. B. Lippincott Is Sold For Over $250 Million
abstract: LEAD: Harper Collins, the publishing subsidiary of Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, announced yesterday that it had sold its J. B. Lippincott unit to a leading Dutch scientific and technical publisher for more than $250 million as part of an effort to reduce its debt.

headline: S.E.C. Chief Criticizes Bill to Thwart Takeovers
abstract: LEAD: The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission today strongly criticized an anti-takeover law pending before the Pennsylvania Legislature, saying it would disenfranchise shareholders and leave incompetent managers ''free to run a company into the ground.''

headline: Lomas to Sell Leasing Unit
abstract: LEAD: The Lomas Financial Corporation, the financial conglomerate that is under bankruptcy protection, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Ellco Leasing Corporation unit to the General Electric Capital Corporation for $161 million in cash and $30.6 million in preferred stock. The G.E. subsidiary will also assume $1 billion of

headline: Treasury Is Selling Only Bills This Week
abstract: LEAD: Treasury financings this week are confined to the bill market, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Warsaw's Path For Kremlin
abstract: LEAD: In calling for a referendum on economic plans, the Soviet Union appears to be following an approach to reform that was first tried in Poland, beginning in 1987. Here is the way the Polish experience unfolded.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Bonn, After Arrests, Checks For Honecker Link to Terrorists
abstract: LEAD: After the arrest of 10 West German terrorist suspects in East Germany, a West German prosecutor has opened an investigation to determine whether Erich Honecker and other officials of the fallen East German Communist Government can be charged with obstruction of justice.

headline: Pleas by Insurance Officials
abstract: LEAD: Five of the six family members controlling the Champion Insurance Company have pleaded guilty to mail fraud charges in a plea bargain with the Federal Government.

headline: Treasury Is Selling Only Bills This Week
abstract: LEAD: Treasury financings this week are confined to bills, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and an auction of one-year bills on Thursday. On Wednesday, the Resolution Funding Corporation will announce the size of its April 10 sale of 40-year bonds to finance the bailout of the savings industry.

headline: Your Own Account;  Playing Retirement Roulette
abstract: LEAD: Thomas M. Iezzi is only 48, but already he is planning his retirement. ''I've worked hard all my life,'' said Mr. Iezzi, the chief financial officer for a wholesale beer distributor in Houston. ''If, at age 58, I have adequate resources, I might say the heck with it all.'' His major concern, though, is how he will provide health insurance for his retirement years.

headline: France's Main Parties Move to Counteract Le Pen
abstract: LEAD: With France's Socialist Government pledging a new fight against social inequality and two conservative parties burying their differences to form an electoral alliance of their own, the far-rightist National Front suddenly appears to be setting this country's political agenda.

headline: Yield Settles at About 6.40% On New York City Notes
abstract: LEAD: A $900 million sale by New York City of revenue-anticipation notes due June 29 of this year was priced yesterday through competitive bidding. Securities traders said the sale went well and the bidding was aggressive.

headline: Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * Nestle to the J. Walter Thompson Co. for confectionery sales in Europe, with a budget of $15 million.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   YELTSIN IS AHEAD IN RUSSIAN VOTING
abstract: LEAD: Boris N. Yeltsin, a rival and fierce critic of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, took the lead early this morning in the contest for the presidency of the Russian republic - a job that would give him an important power base.

headline: Arab Militants Release 3 After Qaddafi Intervenes
abstract: LEAD: A Frenchwoman, her Belgian companion and their daughter were released in Beirut today, more than two years after being taken hostage by a Libyan-supported militant group as they cruised the Mediterranean on a pleasure boat.

headline: Ammirati Buyback
abstract: LEAD: Ammirati & Puris said yesterday that it had completed its buyback from the Omnicom Group, which acquired the agency last year when it bought Ammirati's former parent, the Boase Massimi Pollitt Partnership. Ammirati had sold itself to Boase Massimi Pollitt in 1987.

headline: Leningrad Journal;   Party, Facing Clings to Its Properties
abstract: LEAD: The Tauride Palace was built in the 18th century for Prince Potemkin as a gift from Catherine the Great, but in living memory it has belonged to a more contemporary royalty - the Communist Party.

headline: Canadians Sign Pact, But the Doubts Linger
abstract: LEAD: Canada's provincial leaders dispersed to their capitals after signing a pact with Prime Minister Brian Mulroney that was intended to keep Quebec within the confederation, but doubts remain as to whether all 10 provinces will go along.

headline: Lag in Official Burmese Vote Tally Worries Some Diplomats
abstract: LEAD: As results continued to trickle in today from the first multiparty elections in 30 years in Myanmar, formerly Burma, Western diplomats said the main opposition party had already won at least 66 percent of the seats in a new National Assembly.

headline: Federated Is Said to Be In Tax Case
abstract: LEAD: The Internal Revenue Service is said to be considering a tax claim of more than $1 billion against Federated Stores Inc. The basis for the claim is said to be that the Campeau Corporation misallocated the ''good will'' of Federated when it acquired the retail chain in 1988.

headline: 5 Central Americans Call for Disbanding Of the Contras Soon
abstract: LEAD: Five Central American Presidents called today for the full demobilization of the contra army by April 25 and urged that United States aid for resettling the rebels be offered only to those who give up their weapons.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   USA Today Promotion
abstract: LEAD: USA Today's new advertising campaign, created by the New York office of Babbit & Reiman Advertising, toys with the newspaper's reputation. ''The paper people love to tear apart,'' says the ad's headline. The copy, however, explains that it refers not to any criticism of USA Today's editorial content, but simply to the claim that people often clip and save the paper's articles.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Abitibi-Price Inc., Toronto, a lumber maker, will build a $56 million de-inking plant at the Alabama River Newsprint Co. mill in Claiborne, Ala. The project involves its joint-venture partner, Parsons & Whittemore Inc., a wood products company.

headline: Currency;   The Swiss Franc Moves Up
abstract: LEAD: This was the week of the Swiss franc as it moved higher against the dollar, the West German mark and the yen. A week ago, it took 1.4900 francs to buy a dollar. By last Friday, it took only 1.4530. The franc has been helped by the country's relatively high interest rates and by comments at week's end by the head of Switzerland's central bank supporting a strong currency and a sustained fight against inflation.

headline: India Asserts That Pakistan Is Preparing for Border War
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister V. P. Singh said today that Pakistan had moved radar units and armored regiments close to the Indian border and was readying its airfields.

headline: Groups Taking Aid Donations

headline: Maxtor Accepted In Miniscribe Bid
abstract: LEAD: The Maxtor Corporation, a maker of computer disk drives based in San Jose, Calif., said its bid to acquire substantially all of the assets of the bankrupt Miniscribe Corporation, a disk maker in Longmont, Colo., had been accepted by the United States Bankruptcy Court in Denver. Under the bid, Maxtor will pay $21.5 million in cash and $20 million in stock, and Miniscribe's Hong Kong and Singapore operations will release $4.5 million in cash and acounts receivable to the court.

headline: A Surprise Spacewalk: Repairs for Soviet Ship
abstract: LEAD: Soviet astronauts aboard the Mir space station are planning an unscheduled spacewalk to repair their damaged transport ship and insure a safe return to Earth, published reports and American experts say.

headline: S.E.C. Division Head Leaving
abstract: LEAD: Kathryn B. McGrath, the director of the Securities and Exchange Commission's investment management division, announced today that she will resign next month to become a partner in the Washington office of Morgan Lewis & Bockius, a New York-based law firm.

headline: Symantec to Acquire Peter Norton
abstract: LEAD: The Symantec Corporation, a software company in Cupertino, Calif., said today that it had agreed to acquire Peter Norton Computing Inc. of Santa Monica, Calif. for Symantec common stock valued at about $70 million.

headline: Authors Warn on Gallimard
abstract: LEAD: The heirs of three of France's best-known 20th-century authors and 55 other writers threatened today to switch publishers if a corporate raider gained control of Editions Gallimard, France's largest independent publisher.

headline: Unicef Reports Donor Fatigue
abstract: LEAD: The head of the United Nations Childrens Fund accused the world's richer countries of '' aid fatigue'' today as he appealed for more help for the victims of two of Africa's longest running and bloodiest civil wars-- the decade-old conflicts in Sudan and Mozambique.

headline: GlenFed Picks New Chairman
abstract: LEAD: Completing a long-planned succession, GlenFed Inc., parent company of Glendale Federal Bank, the nation's fifth-largest savings and loan association, said today that its chairman, Raymond D. headline: Summit in Washington;   Warsaw Alliance Schedules Summit Meeting in Moscow
abstract: LEAD: The Warsaw Pact will hold a summit meeting in Moscow next Thursday, the East German Foreign Ministry said today.

headline: Libya Behind Speedboat Raid, Israel Asserts
abstract: LEAD: Israeli officials today offered details of what they said was the extensive role played by the Libyan military in the planning and execution of an unsuccessful seaborne attack on Tel Aviv by heavily armed Palestinian guerrillas.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Nintendo's Review
abstract: LEAD: Nintendo of America has narrowed the review for its $15 million advertising account to the Leo Burnett Company and the San Francisco office of Foote, Cone & Belding, advertising executives said Friday. The incumbent is McCann-Erickson.

headline: A Czech Cousin Haunts Budweiser
abstract: LEAD: Anheuser-Busch, the brewer of Budweiser beer, is negotiating with the Czech producer of the 16th-century original of the same name to settle longstanding trademark differences. If they reach an agreement, European beer drinkers may soon confront the question: Which Bud's for you?

headline: U.S.-Canada Pact Review
abstract: LEAD: The 18-month-old United States-Canada free trade agreement is working well, although some problems remain, United States officials told Congress today.

headline: Tunisian Leader Begins Visit to Washington
abstract: LEAD: The President of Tunisia will begin a three-day visit to Washington on Monday with two pivotal issues on his agenda: the immigration of Soviet Jews to Israel, and the Western outcry about Iraq's manufacture and deployment of long-range missiles, chemical weapons and other advanced military technology.

headline: Japanese Warrants Surge, But Many Investors Lose
abstract: LEAD: Japan is justly famous for its many natural hot springs, which seem to bubble from nearly every cleft rock in this mountainous land. But never has there been a more bountiful gusher than the financial wellspring known as the Japanese market for stock warrants.

headline: Ad Bureau Chief to Take A Post With Scripps
abstract: LEAD: Craig C. Standen, the president and chief executive of the Newspaper Advertising Bureau, announced yesterday that he would leave the bureau in August to join the E. W. Scripps Company. He will become vice president for marketing and advertising of the company's newspaper and publishing division.

headline: Lawyer for Thrift Office
abstract: LEAD: The new director of the Office of Thrift Supervision has appointed a lawyer with little direct experience in the savings and loan industry as the agency's top attorney. headline: Summit in Washington;   Raisa Gorbachev's Thaw in Relations
abstract: LEAD: Raisa Maksimovna Gorbachev, the prickly, self-assertive co-star of previous summit sideshows, threw out her old script today and emerged as a graceful and gracious guest.

abstract: LEAD: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation, one of Pennsylvania's largest companies, said today that its board had voted to exempt it from coverage under the state's new anti-takeover law.

headline: Ortega Warns of Snag on Contras
abstract: LEAD: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra left open the possibility today that the inauguration of President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro could be postponed if the contra rebels were not disarmed by that date.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Shift at The National
abstract: LEAD: The National, a daily sports newspaper started in January, has reorganized its marketing department into an advertising sales development department. The job of marketing director, which had been held by Emmett Green, was eliminated. Peter A. Spina, the paper's advertising sales director, said his department needed the marketing team to provide it with research and promotional work.

headline: The Media Business;   Grey Advertising's Parts Add Up to Big Sums
abstract: LEAD: For years, the word on Madison Avenue was that Grey Advertising was a little like its name: a dull agency that created nondescript advertising. But these days, Grey is anything but drab.

headline: Frenchman Head of New Aid Bank
abstract: LEAD: The 42 member nations that are creating a bank to provide financial aid to Eastern Europe have elected the chief personal adviser of President Francois Mitterrand of France to head the bank and have selected London as its headquarters.

headline: Slow Death for Drexel in Japan
abstract: LEAD: The improbably sudden collapse of the Drexel Burnham Lambert Group shocked Wall Street in February, as did the United States Government's willingness to stand aside as the firm crumbled to financial rubble. But one of those caught most off guard was Masahiko Yamamoto, manager of Drexel's Tokyo branch.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Albanian Leader Says the Country Will Be Democratized but Will Retain Socialism
abstract: LEAD: In his first encounter with foreign journalists, President Ramiz Alia said on Saturday that his policy of democratizing this isolated Communist country could not be stopped.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Old Agency Reaches for A New Image
abstract: LEAD: THESE days the buzzword at Ayer is ''stretch.'' Today, exactly a year after he became chief executive of Ayer, Jerry J. Siano will introduce a campaign to forge a strong identity for the country's oldest advertising agency.

headline: Last British Prisoners Give Up in Manchester
abstract: LEAD: The last five prisoners abandoned the roof of Strangeways Prison today, ending a 25-day siege, the longest in British history.

headline: New Direction Expected In Geographic Shake-Up
abstract: LEAD: The abrupt replacement of the editor of National Geographic magazine, brought on by editorial and managerial disputes within the scientific society, appears likely to alter the magazine's course as it explores its own identity.

headline: Mongolia's Communists Mapping Changes to Keep Grip on Power
abstract: LEAD: Hoping to keep its 70-year grip on power in the face of a growing pro-democracy movement, the Communist Party opened a hastily convened congress today with a call for widespread change.

headline: Interest Rates Rise; Trading Is Light
abstract: LEAD: Interest rates climbed yesterday as prices of Treasury securities fell after the Federal Reserve unexpectedly signaled again that it was not about to loosen credit.

headline: Waves of Emigration Are Washing Over Europe

headline: Canada Trade Surplus
abstract: LEAD: Canada's trade surplus soared in March, powered largely by a strong United States economy that consumed more Canadian goods than in February, the Government said today. The surplus swelled to $471 million (Canadian), or $402 million (United States), from a revised February surplus of $53 million (Canadian), or $45 million (United States).

headline: Sides Differ on Reports Of Progress in TV Talks
abstract: LEAD: The broadcast networks and a coalition representing Hollywood producers disagreed today on whether they had made progress in their longstanding negotiations over financial control of television programs.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;  Options Clearing Chief Backs S.E.C. Jurisdiction
abstract: LEAD: It would be easier to portray the continuing regulatory battle over stock index futures as a struggle between two cities, New York and Chicago, were it not for people like Wayne P. Luthringshausen, the chairman of the Options Clearing Corporation.

headline: British Layoffs Foreseen
abstract: LEAD: Thousands of jobs will be cut as British factories struggle to stay competitive in the face of rising costs, the Confederation of British Industry predicted today in its latest survey of industrial companies. Profits are being squeezed by rising labor costs and high interest rates, and domestic demand has been falling, the confederation said.

headline: Dow Down 53.71 to End At 2,882.18

abstract: LEAD: Gold is supposed to be a safe haven in times of turmoil. But those who fled to it last winter as Communist regimes dissolved in Eastern Europe have suffered since. Last week, gold traded as low as $341 per ounce in London, a four-year low.

abstract: LEAD: Boeing 737 jets are being produced at a rate of 17 a month, the Boeing Commercial Airplane Group said. The company, increased production for the small jet from 14 a month earlier this year.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD: * Daniel H. Dolgins has been appointed director of strategy and planning at Baron & Zaretsky Advertising.

abstract: LEAD: Ignoring terrorist threats by cocaine traffickers, millions of Colombians voted for president today and elected Cesar Gaviria Trujillo, the candidate who advocated the toughest line on the traffickers.

headline: Gasoline Prices Decline

The average price for a gallon of gasoline, including all taxes, was 117.68 cents on June 22, down 0.42 cents from June 8, the Lundberg Survey said on Sunday.

headline: Dow Surprises Some by Rising 12.16 Points
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices rose yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average gaining 12.16 points, to 2,668.92.

abstract: LEAD: IN an effort to raise its profile to the level of other advertising trade groups, the International Advertising Association announced a management reorganization on Friday that will bring the group its first full-time professional leadership.

headline: Chinese Aide May Seek U.S. Refuge
abstract: LEAD: A senior Chinese official who disagreed with the military crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators last spring has quietly arrived in the United States, apparently seeking refuge, American officials said yesterday.

The bid is subject to the arrangement of financing and other conditions. One of the conditions is the completion of the previously announced sale of Kinark's hotel properties for at least $12 million.

VPI made the claims in a lawsuit seeking unspecified damages filed in United States District Court in New York.

abstract: LEAD: The Solidarity leader Lech Walesa today ended a strike by Gdansk shipyard workers, telling them that anarchy would damage Poland's image abroad.

headline: DE KLERK ENDORSES SHARING OF POWER
abstract: LEAD: President F. W. de Klerk said today that his Government would not agree to majority rule but was prepared to work out a formula for whites to share power with blacks in South Africa.

abstract: LEAD: Leaders of the political party representing Romania's ethnic Hungarian minority in this country's newly elected national Parliament have decided overwhelmingly to stay out of a coalition with the ruling National Salvation Front.

abstract: LEAD: Gen. Michel Aoun, who says he is the leader of Lebanon's only legitimate government, has reportedly offered to step aside if asked to do so by the head of his Maronite Catholic Church, newspapers here have reported.

abstract: LEAD: A physicist and a former Federal official have invented a device that uses powerful bursts of microwave energy to disable electronic eavesdropping devices planted in walls, floors or ceilings.

abstract: LEAD: Gen. Samuel K. Doe of Liberia called on the entire population today to take up arms and join the fight against rebels who are trying to overthrow his Government.

headline: Unocal's Net Down 11.5%
abstract: LEAD: The Unocal Corporation said today that its first-quarter earnings fell 11.5 percent, to $77 million, or 33 cents a share, from $87 million, or 37 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year ago.

abstract: LEAD: European science is growing stronger and more influential as increasing numbers of top researchers from different countries collaborate on papers with one another, according to the authors of a study to be made public today.

abstract: LEAD: The Xerox Corporation will introduce a line of electronic copiers later this year that will set the pace for the company in the next decade, officials said at the annual shareholders meeting. abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Government said today that it planned to hold a countrywide referendum this year on a new package of economic changes, giving Soviet citizens their first direct say on a matter of national policy.

abstract: LEAD: President Bush indicated today that he would withhold normal trade status from the Soviet Union as long as the Lithuanian question remained unresolved. At the same time he confirmed that he was renewing such economic benefits for China despite Beijing's hard-line policies.

abstract: LEAD: Shrinking top management after a failed merger attempt, the Equimark Corporation said yesterday that Claire W. Gargalli had resigned as chairman and chief executive of Equibank, its main subsidiary.
