headline: Iraqi Takes Harsh Line at Meeting
abstract: LEAD: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq set a bellicose and anti-American tone for the Arab summit meeting here today, despite efforts by Egypt and Saudi Arabia to mute inflammatory oratory.

headline: Pondering Transition At Backer
abstract: LEAD: DEAN SCAROS was asked about a recent article in Advertising Age about the future of agencies whose influential leaders face retirement. ''That's one of the reasons I wanted to speak with you,'' said Mr. Scaros, the president of Backer Spielvogel Bates Inc.

headline: Excerpts From Mandela and de Klerk Remarks as Talks Open
abstract: LEAD: Following are excerpts from statements today by President F. W. de Klerk and Nelson Mandela, deputy president of the African National Congress, at the start of talks on political change in South Africa. The official translation was used for the parts of Mr. de Klerk's remarks uttered in Afrikaans.

headline: Treasuries Rise in Busy Trading
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities rose in active trading yesterday, as retail accounts purchased securities after fairly large price declines in recent days.

headline: Shift at Ayer Unit
abstract: LEAD: In a bid to shore up its underachieving Los Angeles office, Ayer has named Donna F. Tuttle, a former United States Deputy Secretary of Commerce, as chairwoman and chief executive of the office. The office -which Thomas F. Maxey, Ayer's vice chairman, said ''is smaller than we want it to be'' - will be renamed Ayer Tuttle, and it will add Ms.

headline: Bush Sees 'Significant Change' in Baltic Standoff
abstract: LEAD: The United States today hailed Moscow's reported decision to ease its economic sanctions against Lithuania, and President Bush called President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's talks with Baltic leaders a ''significant change'' that could help end the Baltic crisis.

headline: What if They Ran Indy And Japan Came, Too?
abstract: LEAD: None of the 33 cars in the Indianapolis 500 on Sunday will have a Japanese engine, but future races may be very different. The event, as much a noisy reunion for car-crazy Americans as a test of speed and endurance, is attracting new attention from Japanese auto makers eager to increase their appeal in the United States and

headline: Amid Praise, a Shaky Household
abstract: LEAD: Is Household International Inc. headed for a big fall?

headline: Chairman of Philips Is Said To Be Stepping Down Early
abstract: LEAD: Philips N.V., the Dutch electronics giant, is expected to announce on Monday that its chairman, Cornelis J. van der Klugt, is stepping down more than a year earlier than planned because of pressures resulting from the company's surprisingly poor earnings for the first quarter.

headline: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
abstract: LEAD:            Net      Percent       Income      Change                $      Net Income   Percent        Jan.-Mar.   Change        1990   From '89        Coastal Corp.   $ 75,600,000    +25.2        Copperweld Corp.   4,500,000    -41.6        Ford Motor Co.   506,200,000    -69.1        General Motors Corp.   710,000,000    -54.2        Great Northern Nekoosa   (71,300,000)    -       Harper Group Inc.

headline: Autonomy's Cry Revived in Quebec
abstract: LEAD: Sitting placidly on a bench along an empty parade route, Jean-Maurice Guenette wore a slogan T-shirt that has not been seen on the streets of Quebec in 10 years. In blue letters, it said ''Oui,'' an echo of the motto of the Quebec separatists whose dreams of independence were narrowly dashed in a 1980 referendum.

headline: Trump Criticized on Late Payments
abstract: LEAD: Less than a week after Forbes magazine marked him down a notch from a billionaire to a mere half-billionaire, Donald J. Trump is under fire from a handful of contractors who say he has been slow to pay money he owes them, possibly because of a cash squeeze.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Soviet Stage: Is 2 a Crowd?
abstract: LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev may not yet face a full-fledged political opposition in this deeply troubled land, but he now certainly has a personal nemesis to haunt his days of power.

headline: Logic Devices In Litigation
abstract: LEAD: The Cypress Semiconductor Corporation said today that it had amended its countersuit against Advanced Micro Devices Inc. about programmable logic devices.

headline: Several Dead as Police and the Nepalese Do Battle
abstract: LEAD: Several people were reportedly killed here today when angry crowds, frustrated by what they regarded as the slow pace of change, attacked several men in police uniform while officers rained blows on a Cabinet minister's car and shot at rioters.

headline: Ortega, a Lame Duck, Begins His Diplomatic Farewell
abstract: LEAD: In his last regional conference of heads of state before leaving office this month, President Daniel Ortega Saavdra of Nicaragua began talks with four other Central American Presidents here today in what his aides say will be a final push for the quick disbanding of the contra army.

headline: New Twists in the Legend of Mao's Onetime Heir
abstract: LEAD: For 20 years now, whatever it was that happened to Lin Biao, former Chinese Defense Minister and the heir apparent to Mao Zedong, has been among the great unresolved mysteries of the Communist world, one that remains shrouded in uncertainty even in these days of remarkable revelations.

headline: Brazil and Argentina Seeking Aid
abstract: LEAD: Despite a backlog of more than $11 billion in interest owed to commercial bankers, Brazil and Argentina will be negotiating for new official aid when the International Monetary Fund and World Bank meet in Washington next week.

headline: Bank Yields Mixed in Week
abstract: LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions were mixed for the week ended yesterday. Except for a few banks that change yields on certain deposits, to fall in line with competitive offers, there has not been a sustained movement in months, analysts said.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:    THE ECONOMY       The U.S. agency that insures private pension plans was handed a crucial victory by the Supreme Court, which gave it the power to make an employer take back responsibility for its pension obligations. The ruling will provide needed relief for the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, with liabilities outweighing assets by a $1 billion deficit, and will aid virtually all retirees.

headline: The Bank of Tokyo Responds
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Pact in Pittsburgh With Rail Unions
abstract: LEAD: An investment group trying to buy assets of the Pittsburgh & Lake Erie Railroad Company said today that it had reached tentative labor agreements with the railroad's unions. The Railroad Development Corporation said the agreements cover 80 percent of the union-represented work force. The railroad announced on Feb.

headline: Big Board Plans Night Operation, Using Computers But Not Traders
abstract: LEAD: For the first time in its nearly 200-year history, the New York Stock Exchange will begin trading after its normal hours later this year and hopes to start trading during the night in 1991, exchange officials told brokerage firms yesterday.

headline: Wall Street;   When Zero-Coupon Bonds Point the Way
abstract: LEAD: Many traders think zero-coupon bonds, which sell far below their maturity value but pay no annual interest, are a good barometer for the broader ''junk bond'' market. If so, recent developments may signal a slight warming trend that could send junk bond prices higher.

headline: Tobacco Sales Off in California
abstract: LEAD: Cigarette sales have dropped 14 percent and state tobacco tax revenues have more than tripled since voters approved a tobacco tax increase in 1988, the American Lung Association said on Wednesday.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:          Companies

headline: Lilly Ends Output Of 60 Products
abstract: LEAD: Eli Lilly & Company has discontinued manufacturing 60 products and versions of products, according to a notification letter sent to drug wholesalers around the country. Representatives of several pharmaceutical wholesaling companies said that the products involved were either old or slow-selling and that the manufacturing halts would have little or no financial impact.

headline: Treasury Bonds Stage Advance
abstract: LEAD: Treasury bond prices posted their best gains in nearly a month yesterday, as dealers positioned themselves for the release this morning of April employment data.

headline: A Neo-Stalinist Yearns for Old Times
abstract: LEAD: An afternoon at home with Nina Andreyeva is an experience of cozy domesticity often interrupted by jarring moments of anachronism.

headline: Ethnic Protesters Attack Troops, Soviets Say
abstract: LEAD: Soviet television reported tonight that militants in the Soviet republic of Kirghizia had fired on troops and attacked trucks as tensions mounted further in the Central Asian region.

headline: Placer Dome to Sell Canada Oil Assets
abstract: LEAD: Placer Dome Inc., a leading North American gold producer, agreed to sell the Canadian oil and gas operations of its Placer CEGO Petroleum Holdings Ltd. subsidiary to the Opus Acquisition Corporation for about $305 million Canadian ($262 million in United States currency). Opus is jointly owned by Poco Petroleums Ltd.

headline: GE Credit Offers Notes Due in 2008
abstract: LEAD: The GE Credit Corporation, a unit of the General Electric Company, is offering $250 million in 8 5/8 percent notes due 2008 through Kidder, Peabody & Company as sole manager.

headline: After the Summit;   The Soviets and South Korea: At Odds Since Day 1
abstract: LEAD: By meeting yesterday, Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Roh Tae Woo underscored an anachronism of cold-war history.

headline: Talks Urged In Drug Suit
abstract: LEAD: A Chicago arbitration judge has ordered Amgen Inc. and its leading marketing partner, the Ortho Pharmaceutical Corporation, a unit of Johnson & Johnson, to negotiate quickly their dispute regarding the sale of genetically engineered erythropoietin, or EPO, a hormone used to treat anemia.

headline: Dominican Rivals in Tight Race
abstract: LEAD: President Joaquin Balaguer and his longtime rival, Juan Bosch, remained locked in a close race today, a day after national elections, as some politicians said the vote count was extremely slow.

headline: Conservatives Win in Croatia
abstract: LEAD: A conservative nationalist party has as expected taken a large parliamentary majority in the final round of the first free multiparty elections in the Yugoslav republic of Croatia in more than 50 years.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:    Debt

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: LEAD:    General Assembly       SPECIAL COMMITTEE ON PEACEKEEPING OPERATIONS - 3 P.M.       DISARMAMENT COMMISSION - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.       Economic and Social Council       SOCIAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Romanian Anti-Communists Keep Up Anti-Iliescu Protest
abstract: LEAD: Anti-Communist protesters stormed out of a meeting today with the Provisional President, Ion Iliescu, dashing Government hopes of a quick end to a 17-day demonstration demanding Mr. Iliescu's resignation.

headline: Navistar's Net Drops by 77.1%
abstract: LEAD: The Navistar International Corporation said on Thursday that its net income plunged 77.1 percent in its second quarter because of an industrywide decline in retail truck sales.

headline: Business and Health;   Cutbacks Sought In Retiree Benefits
abstract: LEAD: AS Eastern Airlines tries to trim health-care benefits promised over the years to thousands of retired workers, its moves are being watched closely by benefits executives, labor union officials and bankruptcy lawyers.

headline: LTV Profits Decline 42.3%
abstract: LEAD: The LTV Corporation today reported a 42.3 percent decrease in first-quarter earnings, blaming lower profits from its steel and military industries.

headline: More Nicaraguans in U.S. Going Back Home
abstract: LEAD: Confident that the inauguration on April 25 of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro will usher in an era of peace for Nicaragua, a growing number of Nicaraguan exiles are restarting their lives and businesses there.

headline: New G.M. Concept: Thinking Small
abstract: LEAD: The General Motors Corporation did not grow into the world's No. 1 auto maker by thinking small or bucking the economies of assembly-line manufacturing. But G.M. has been trying to do both at the factory that assembles the Buick Reatta coupe, and G.M. executives now seem pleased enough with the result to consider using the system for other models.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:    Debt

headline: KOHL, AT HARVARD, REAFFIRMS BORDER
abstract: LEAD: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany reiterated today that the border between Germany and Poland would remain ''inviolable'' after his country reunites with East Germany.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;  Like Father, Like Son
abstract: LEAD: Is advertising talent inherited or learned? An argument for the former comes from Dick Buckley of the Buckley/Swartz agency in Swampscott, Mass., whose son Bryan is co-chairman of the daring young agency Buckley/DeCerchio Inc. Dick Buckley's latest work is a pro bono ad and logo for the Democracy for China Fund.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Y.&R. Goal: Improved Creativity
abstract: LEAD: EXECUTIVES at Young & Rubicam suggest that the decision to reorganize the agency's giant New York office from three divisions into one was a case of winning the battle but losing the war.

headline: Fund Yields Rise Slightly
abstract: LEAD: Yields on tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were slightly higher in the week ended yesterday.

headline: Officials Say Deaths In Danish Ferry Fire Could Rise Past 176
abstract: LEAD: The bodies of victims of the North Sea ferry fire began arriving here today for identification as the Norwegian police said the death toll could rise to more than 176.

headline: Industrial Output Up by 0.7% in March
abstract: LEAD: The nation's industrial production rose by seven-tenths of 1 percent in March, the Federal Reserve reported today, in a second consecutive strong showing that led analysts to suggest that the manufacturing recession may have ended.

headline: Colombia Rebels Shun Arms and Win Votes
abstract: LEAD: A surprise winner in Colombia's elections on Sunday was a guerrilla group that only two months ago traded in its guns for the ballot box.

headline: House Bill Aids Price-Fix Suits
abstract: LEAD: The House challenged a threatened veto by President Bush and voted today to make it easier for discount stores and local prosecutors to sue manufacturers and full-price retailers for price fixing.

headline: In Managua, Fresh Hope
abstract: LEAD: President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro's three-week-old Cabinet was exasperated, ready to give up.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Archive Corp., Costa Mesa, Calif., a maker of tape drives for computer systems, completed the acquisition of Cipher Data Products Inc., San Diego, a maker of magnetic tape drives, for about $120 million.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   Study Proposes Deeper U.S. Troop Cuts in Europe
abstract: LEAD: The United States can make deeper troop cuts in Europe than those the Bush Administration has proposed without endangering its security, senior defense experts and influential lawmakers conclude in a new study.

headline: No Headline
abstract: LEAD: At no time since he burst upon the scene as a New York City developer and then as an Atlantic City casino operator has Donald J. Trump seemed in more financial trouble than in the last few weeks. The 43-year-old entrepreneur has been closeted with his bankers amid concerns that he lacks the cash to make timely payments on his huge business debt.

headline: Thermo Unit Sets Deal for Finnigan
abstract: LEAD: Thermo Instrument Systems Inc., maker of analytic instruments in Waltham, Mass., that is a unit of the Thermo Electron Corporation, reached an understanding to acquire the Finnigan Corpration, which makes spectrometers, for $20 a share, or $110 million to $120 million.

headline: LMVH Increasing Stake in Guinness
abstract: LEAD: LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton, the French liquor and luxury-products company, moved to increase its stake in Guinness P.L.C. to 24 percent, in line with the British liquor company's stake in LVMH. LVMH said the move was part of an agreement reached with Guinness in 1988 to hold equal stakes in each other.

headline: No Financial Mystique
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: New Phillips Fuel
abstract: LEAD: The Phillips Petroleum Company has joined a growing number of oil companies introducing a reformulated gasoline intended to be less harmful to the environment than existing grades. Phillips's reformulated fuel, blended to reduce certain hydrocarbon emissions, will be tested in St. Louis, one of more than 100 cities that fall below the Environmental Protection Agency's minimum standards for air quality, the company said.

headline: Computers to Help Drivers Find Their Way
abstract: LEAD: This summer the General Motors Corporation will begin a yearlong experiment on a 12-mile stretch of Los Angeles freeway to examine how 12 cars equipped with electronic navigation systems can elude congested highways by turning on to local streets shown on a computerized map. In Japan, the Honda Motor

headline: Japan Trade Surplus Up
abstract: LEAD: After 11 months of decline Japan's trade surplus climbed in March, but economists said it was because the month's imports were being compared with an unusually large amount of imports in March 1989.

headline: Market Place;   A Dangerous Beat Worries Investors
abstract: LEAD: IS the ''market mambo'' starting right on time, with the stock market ending a two-month advance as fears grow of bad earnings reports?

headline: Grumman in Talks On Japanese Deal
abstract: LEAD: The Grumman Corporation, the aerospace company in Bethpage, L.I., that also links supercomputers in large networks, said it had started talks with Japanese supercomputer makers to bring the Japanese machines to America. Political opposition had blocked nearly all sales in the United States of Japanese supercomputers, used mainly in large research projects to design weapons, aircraft and cars.

headline: U.S. Urged to Emphasize Economic Strength
abstract: LEAD: Promoting a new foreign policy that is not rooted in rivalry with the Soviets, the chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, David L. Boren, warned today that the United States risks losing its pre-eminence unless it adjusts to a world order based on economic, not military, might.

headline: President Named Chief Of Dime Savings Bank
abstract: LEAD: The Dime Savings Bank, one of the strongest of New York's large savings banks, yesterday named Richard D. Parsons, a 42-year-old lawyer, as its new chief executive, effective July 1. He will succeed Harry W. Albright Jr., 65, who has headed the bank for 15 years and will continue as chairman.

headline: Utility Names New Managers
abstract: LEAD: Northeast Utilities has appointed a team of senior managers to take over the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, the operator of the long-delayed Seabrook nuclear power plant.

headline: Ford in Australia
abstract: LEAD: The Ford Motor Company of Australia, the country's biggest car maker and a subsidiary of the Ford Motor Company of the United States, said it planned to spend $1.2 billion (Australian), or $916 million in United States currency, in the next five years to improve its products and factories. The announcement came as the company said earnings had slid to $124.1 million (Australian) in 1989 from $126 million in 1988, despite a 16 percent increase in new car sales.

headline: Japan Builds East Asia Links, Gaining Labor and Markets
abstract: LEAD: After having built its economic miracle on strong links with the industrialized West, Japan is now increasing its trade and investment in the buoyant economies of East Asia, creating a highly efficient manufacturing bloc in this vital region.

headline: Spots by Follis & Verdi To Fight Child Abuse
abstract: LEAD: The camera first looks down on the basketball player's sneakers, and then, amid chilling music, it pans seven feet up to his head. He bends toward the camera and says, ''If it makes you nervous to have someone my size in your face, now you know how your kid feels when you're in his.'' In one spot the player is Mark Eaton, the 7-foot-4 center of the Utah Jazz.

headline: Two Chinese Protesters Tell Of Detention on Anniversary
abstract: LEAD: Two Chinese dissidents who disappeared last month before a planned appeal to free political prisoners said today that they were held by the police to prevent unrest on the anniversary of last year's army crackdown.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Soviet Experts Say Their Economy Is Worse Than U.S. Has Estimated
abstract: LEAD: Several senior Soviet economists said here today that the United States had consistently overestimated the size of the Soviet economy and understated Soviet military spending.

headline: GE Credit Prices Notes Due 2007
abstract: LEAD: The GE Credit Corporation, a unit of the General Electric Company, yesterday priced $250 million in notes due 2007 through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company.

headline: Rescuers Dig for Survivors of Iran Quake
abstract: LEAD: Weary disaster teams dug for survivors with fading hope and buried uncounted bodies in mass graves in earthquake-stricken northwestern Iran yesterday. Foreign emergency aid poured in and official estimates of the toll of death and destruction continued to climb.

headline: East German Fuel Sales
abstract: LEAD: East Germany's state-owned Minol oil company almost tripled gasoline sales in the first four months of 1990, reflecting a rise in car ownership in East Germany. The head of Minol's retail division, Leonhard Kneler, told the state news agency last week that at least 100 new gasoline stations a year would be needed to meet demand from East German drivers and the greatly increased number of West German cars visiting the East.

headline: Wall Street;   Riding Out the End-Quarter Calm
abstract: LEAD: A sense of listlessness descended over Wall Street this past week as trading volumes sagged. The quiet dismayed brokers. And the low volumes made it harder for pundits to reach meaningful conclusions about gains and losses in various indexes. But a quick look at trading patterns over the past five quarters shows that the swoon is no cause for alarm.

headline: Variety of Treasury Bill Sales This Week
abstract: LEAD: Treasury financings in this holiday-shortened week include today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, followed on Wednesday by the Treasury's auctions of $6 billion each of cash management bills due on June 21 and Sept. 20. On Thursday, the Treasury will auction $10 billion of one-year bills.

headline: The Cookie Monster Makes Policy
abstract: LEAD: A not-so-funny thing happened to Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner on the way to the White House, where he was to deliver America's new national transportation policy. The policy got eaten up by a Cookie Monster named Richard Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget.

headline: Chase Manhattan's Earnings Plummet 67%
abstract: LEAD: The Chase Manhattan Corporation, the nation's second-largest banking company after Citicorp, announced a 67 percent drop in first-quarter profits yesterday, chiefly because of problems in its commercial real estate lending.

headline: The Reverse LBO Survives, but in a Downsized Model
abstract: LEAD: The tumult in the equities market and the wreckage of the 1980's ''junk bond'' market has brought many of the nation's financial wizards back down closer to earth. Their leveraged buyouts are no longer flying as high as they were - and selling them back to the public is much harder than it was.

headline: Triton in Deal With Conoco Unit
abstract: LEAD: The British oil group Triton Europe P.L.C. said it was selling its oil and gas assets in the British North Sea to Conoco (U.K.) Ltd., a unit of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, for $61 million. Triton said the assets include interests in the Alba oilfields and Kilda and Anglia gas fields, which have not received development approval.

headline: Revamping Is Set for Intergroup
abstract: LEAD: National Intergroup Inc., the Pittsburgh-based holding company once known as the National Steel Corporation, said yesterday that it planned to put its Ben Franklin merchandise stores up for sale. The company will also pay a special dividend or repurchase stock, move its headquarters to Dallas and change its name to the Foxmeyer Corporation, the name of the drug-distribution company it bought four years ago.

headline: Business and the Law;   S.E.C. Complains About Its Limits
abstract: LEAD: AFTER more than three years of investigation, Federal prosecutors uncovered enough evidence of wrongdoing to convince Michael R. Milken to plead guilty to violating securities laws. But none of that evidence from the largest investigation of crime on Wall Street will be turned over to the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Federal agency charged with policing the securities markets.

headline: Pro Bono
abstract: LEAD: * The Ad Council has chosen Wells, Rich, Greene to create a campaign to counter drunken driving.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   Western Historians Join Russians to Dissect Past
abstract: LEAD: With the official history of the last 70 years now discredited as a pack of Stalinist lies, the Soviet academic establishment this week took the unusual step of inviting about 50 leading Western Kremlinologists and historians to come and help them wrestle with the truth.

headline: Dip Continues For Starts In Housing
abstract: LEAD: Housing starts continued to fall in March from their January peak, the Commerce Department reported today, but many analysts said the decline had bottomed out.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Final Months of Berlin Wall
abstract: LEAD: East Germany has set a deadline of December for total demolition of the Berlin wall, which sealed citizens off from the West for 28 years. The state press agency quoted Maj. Gen. Dieter Teichmann, chief of the border troops, as saying that the concrete barrier would be gone by December. On Wednesday, East Germans began knocking out wall slabs all over the city to reopen blocked streets.

headline: White House Tutors Kremlin In How a Presidency Works
abstract: LEAD: On his visit to Camp David this month, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev dropped German unification and Soviet political reform for a moment to quiz President Bush about the logistics of being President. How does paper flow in his office? Who decides who gets into the Oval Office? How does his staff handle

headline: The Executive Life;  Weighing the Fast Track Against Family Values
abstract: LEAD: Susan Lawley seemed to have it all. As a vice president at Goldman, Sachs & Company, Mrs. Lawley earned $250,000 a year in 1988 supervising the administration of the firm's mortgage securities department. She and her husband, Robert, then a vice president at Bankers Trust Company, owned a four-bedroom house in New Jersey, drove to work in a Mercedes-Benz and a Lincoln Continental, tooled around the waters off their Long Island beach house in a sleek new motorboat and even wore matching Rolex watches.

headline: Fire on Train in India Kills 80 and Injures 65
abstract: LEAD: A leaking gas cylinder exploded in a moving commuter train today and set off a fire that left at least 80 people dead and 65 others injured, news reports and officials said.

headline: Loan Reported, Giving Trump Time to Raise Cash
abstract: LEAD: Donald J. Trump and the banks that have backed his empire with billions in loans reached a tentative agreement yesterday that would give Mr. Trump an additional $60 million in loans and temporarily suspend some interest payments on other debt, bank officials said.

headline: A Haze of Debt Clouds The Plaza Hotel's Gleam
abstract: LEAD: Donald J. Trump is fond of calling the Plaza Hotel, which he bought two years ago, ''the ultimate trophy in the world.'' But the famed Manhattan luxury hotel has proved to be a costly trophy.

headline: BUSH THANKS IRAN
abstract: LEAD: Kidnappers freed a second American hostage in Beirut on Monday after the intercession of Syria and Iran, turning him over to Syrian Army officers more than three and a half years after he was abducted.

headline: Treasuries Post 7th Straight Drop
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities inched lower again yesterday for the seventh straight session.

headline: Canada Pact Signed but Doubts Remain
abstract: LEAD: Canada's provincial leaders dispersed to their capitals today after signing a pact with Prime Minister Brian Mulroney that is intended to keep Quebec within the confederation. But serious doubts remain as to whether all 10 provinces will go along with a deal that would endow Quebec with a special constitutional status.

headline: $200 Million in Notes Offered By Private Export Funding
abstract: LEAD: The Private Export Funding Corporation, which is owned by a number of commercial banks involved in export financing, industrial companies exporting United States products and a few financial service companies, is offering $200 million in secured notes that are due 1996 through underwriters led by Citicorp Securities Markets

headline: 24-Hour Trading Plan Gets Mixed Reviews on Wall St.
abstract: LEAD: John J. Phelan Jr., the chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, yesterday officially disclosed a five-phase plan to establish 24-hour trading on the Big Board by the year 2000.

headline: A Savings Fiasco in Texas Ends at a Fire-Sale Price
abstract: LEAD: In the mid-1980's the Stonebridge Ranch, a 6,250-acre development planned as a sprawling community of million-dollar homes, scenic golf courses and 13 man-made lakes, symbolized the vigor of the North Texas economy and the optimism of the aggressive savings and loan that poured an estimated $330 million into buying and upgrading the property.

headline: Summit in Washington;   The Gorbachev's Trip: Today's Schedule
abstract: LEAD:    8:15 A.M. Barbara Bush and Raisa Gorbachev leave for Wellesley College in Massachusetts.       9:30 A.M. President Gorbachev meets with Congressional leadership at the Soviet Embassy.       11:00 A.M. President Gorbachev and President Bush begin third meeting in the Oval Office.       1:00 P.M. President Gorbachev leaves the White House for the Soviet Embassy for lunch and a semiprivate meeting with Vice President Dan Quayle.

headline: Economic Scene;   National Security: New Priorities
abstract: LEAD: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney this week submitted a proposal to Congress for cutting the armed forces by 20 to 25 percent over the next five years. But his plan would reduce military spending by only 10 percent, because savings from force reductions would be largely offset by rising outlays on antimissile defenses, procurement of new strategic nuclear weapons systems, purchases of new conventional weapons and more spending on research and development of new weapons.

headline: BUSINESS DIARY
abstract: LEAD:    COMPANIES       A New Game at Trump's Tables       Donald J. Trump had better hope he can bargain better than he can run a casino. He failed on Friday to pay about $40 million due on ''junk bonds'' and another $30 million on bank loans that financed his purchase of Trump's Castle Hotel and Casino in Atlantic City.

headline: Ex-K.G.B. Officer Asserts Spy Agency Is Unchanged
abstract: LEAD: A recently retired senior officer of the K.G.B. appeared today before a gathering of Communist Party insurgents to accuse the leadership of the state security police of a continuing campaign against Soviet nonconformists.

headline: Praise and Doubts on U.S. Sale Plan
abstract: LEAD: Private developers and real estate experts yesterday praised the Government's decision to cut the price of billions of dollars' worth of real estate being sold through the Resolution Trust Corporation, but they cautioned that the discounts might not increase the number of potential buyers.

headline: IN MOSCOW SHOPS, STOICISM APLENTY
abstract: LEAD: Moscow stores featured fresh supplies of stoicism today, with shoppers forced to brandish their domestic passports and face a ration list rapidly growing to include everything from light bulbs to socks.

headline: Detroit Acts on Rental-Car Problem
abstract: LEAD: After years of hearing dealers complain that rental companies were poaching on their business by selling nearly new cars, auto makers have offered a remedy that may ease the tension.

headline: Campeau Chains Expect Recovery
abstract: LEAD: Federated and Allied department stores projected no sales growth for the quarter beginning in May but said they were recovering under Federal Bankruptcy Court protection. ''We clearly are doing better in Chapter 11 than we expected,'' James M. Zimmerman, the president of Federated Department Stores Inc.

headline: Campbell Soup Consolidates
abstract: LEAD: The Campbell Soup Company said on Friday that it would consolidate its advertising agencies, and the big winners were BBDO and FCB/ Leber Katz Partners.

headline: U.S. Pilots in Peru Join Battle Against Forces of Coca Trade
abstract: LEAD: American civilian helicopter pilots who are part of the anti-drug effort at this Peruvian jungle base took part in a fierce two-hour firefight Saturday with guerrillas supporting coca growers, American officials said today.

headline: Britain Is Convinced Its Customs Halted Giant Gun for Iraq
abstract: LEAD: The British Government said today that it was convinced that Iraq was attempting to build a giant gun but that British customs officers set back the project by seizing eight steel tubes last week.

headline: Talking Business; with LeBaron of Batterymarch Financial;   All-Night Trading Called Beneficial
abstract: LEAD: The three leading American financial exchanges have announced plans for all-night trading of stocks and options, starting in 1992, as a way to keep the United States competitive as overseas equity markets grow and global trading increases.

headline: Police in Zambia Open Fire On Student Demonstrators
abstract: LEAD: Policemen opened fire today on hundreds of stone-throwing university students who were protesting a doubling of the price of corn meal, Zambia's staple.

headline: Chip Sales Projections
abstract: LEAD: Worldwide chip sales will remain flat in 1990 but will then experience annual growth of at least 10 percent until 1993, a trade group reported today.

headline: Towers in Manhattan;  A Residential High-Rise Goes Up on Midblock Lot
abstract: LEAD: Neighborhood groups on the Upper East Side of Manhattan have been battling since 1982 for zoning changes that would discourage the construction of tall residential towers in favor of buildings that are shorter and considered to be more in context with surrounding structures.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   NATO Splits on Removing Nuclear Artillery From West Germany
abstract: LEAD: West German and Dutch officials said today that NATO should move quickly to withdraw nuclear-tipped artillery shells from German soil. But the United States resisted any immediate decision, saying the question must be studied thoroughly.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Baker Says NATO Might Pursue Individual Pacts in Eastern Europe
abstract: LEAD: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d indicated today that NATO leaders might agree at their summit meeting next week to invite individual members of the Warsaw Pact to enter into nonaggression agreements with NATO to give the Eastern European countries a greater sense of belonging to the new Europe.

headline: Shamir Rebuffs Gorbachev on Emigres
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir appeared to rebuff President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today by saying Israel will not dictate to Jewish immigrants from the Soviet Union where they can live.

headline: Summit in Washington;   Muscovites Scoff at Talk of Summit
abstract: LEAD: Igor Repka had little time to ponder the world travels of Mikhail S. Gorbachev as he grabbed the collar of an interloper and thrust him back from the line at the money-changing bureau for this summer's throng of would-be Soviet travelers.

headline: Revco Set to Sell 221 Drugstores
abstract: LEAD: Revco D.S. Inc., the pharmacy chain struggling to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy, agreed to sell 221 of its retail drugstores to a Texas investor group for undisclosed terms. In January, privately held Revco said it planned to sell 712 of its drugstores in the Midwest and Southeast to focus on its other 1,100 more profitable stores in the

headline: India to Lift Nepal Embargo and Discuss Rift
abstract: LEAD: Fifteen months after imposing crippling trade restrictions on Nepal, India has agreed to lift its embargo on July 1 while beginning negotiations on new treaties between the neighbors.

headline: Tandem Net Rises 58.5%
abstract: LEAD: Tandem Computers Inc. reported today that its second-quarter revenues and earnings were considerably above the comparable period a year earlier but below its own earlier expectations.      Tandem had cautioned Wall

headline: Getting the Most Out of Byproducts
abstract: LEAD: General Mills Inc. took Benefit cereal off the market last December when it did not catch on with consumers, leaving the company with 50 tons of unwanted flakes.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   A Magazine Is Coming Along With the Menu
abstract: LEAD: A new venture owned by a specialty publishing concern and a company that owns restaurants is stapling menus inside a new general interest magazine called Knife & Fork. The magazine is being given to restaurant customers.

headline: I.B.M. Introduces New Model 25 PC
abstract: LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation said it had introduced a new Model 25 personal computer that offers more functions, faster processing, 50 percent more fixed disk drive capacity and higher resolution color graphics than existing machines.

headline: Negotiations Concluded Over U.S.-Soviet Trade
abstract: LEAD: American and Soviet negotiators have concluded the remaining details of a trade agreement under which enterprises of the two countries would establish deeper footholds in each other's markets.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;  Equicor Official Gets Top Health Network Job
abstract: LEAD: Ronald W. Moreland, an insurance and benefits executive who ran the $1 billion Western operations of Equicor, an employee benefits company, has been named president and chief executive of Managed Health Network Inc., a Los Angeles company that provides mental health and employee assistance programs.

headline: Why Wall Street Likes Scientific-Atlanta's Mr. Fixit
abstract: LEAD: The major reason Wall Street likes Scientific-Atlanta Inc. may be that it loves William E. Johnson, the former consultant who became the company's chief executive in 1987. Mr. Johnson, previously unknown outside the the major multinational companies that had sought his advice, is credited with executing Scientific

headline: Credit Suisse Parent to Buy Stake in Oldest Swiss Bank
abstract: LEAD: The parent of Credit Suisse, Switzerland's third-largest bank, will take a big stake in the nation's oldest bank, Bank Leu Ltd., the companies said today.

headline: Free Markets Can't Control Pollution
abstract: LEAD: Over the last 20 years, the managers of American industry have gradually become accustomed to the demands of environmental regulation.

headline: WHITE HOUSE SEEKS A 'NEW LEADERSHIP' AT SAVINGS AGENCY
abstract: LEAD: The outspoken head of the Federal savings and loan bailout came under White House pressure today, with the President's chief spokesman saying that ''we are interested in getting new leadership'' in the rescue effort.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:    THE ECONOMY       Japan should not again be cited for unfair trading practices, Carla A. Hills, the U.S. trade representative, told Congress, saying the U.S. and Japan had reached an agreement on wood products that could raise U.S exports to Japan by $1 billion a year. [Page A1.]      The House voted to set up a process that would allow the Government to close banks and savings and loans convicted of laundering drug money.

headline: The Mandela Visit;   Europe Keeps The Sanctions
abstract: LEAD: The European Community decided today not to lift sanctions against South Africa, despite pressure from Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain to relax them.

headline: Tech Notes;   Zapping Safety Into Toxic Waste
abstract: LEAD: Researchers at Battelle Memorial Institute's Pacific Northwest Laboratories have come up with what they call a ''promising'' approach to dealing with radioactive and toxic materials contaminating ground at the Hanford nuclear reservation in Washington state: they electrocute it. Last month, they drove four 30-foot-long graphite and molybdenum electrodes into the ground at the edges of a site, 40 feet in diameter, contaminated with cesium and strontium and hazardous chemicals.

headline: Libya Reports Oil Cut
abstract: LEAD: Libya said on Tuesday that it had cut oil output by 100,000 barrels a day, more than the amount requested under this month's OPEC accord. Delegates of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries wanted a reduction of 77,000 barrels a day by Libya in their agreement for total cuts of 1.445 million barrels daily to bring output down to around 22 million barrels.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * American Savings Bank, White Plains, said it had authorized Kropschot Financial Services, Philadelphia, a merger and acquisition advisory firm, to solicit offers for Amsave Credit Corp., its wholly owned unit that specializes in commercial and leasing finance.

headline: Strikes and Lack of Investors Threaten Polish Austerity Plan
abstract: LEAD: Poland's ambitious program to force-feed this country free-market capitalism has reached its most crucial juncture to date, with the Government simultaneously confronting serious labor unrest and skittishness among foreign investors.

headline: Resorts' Plan Approved
abstract: LEAD: A bankruptcy judge has approved a Resorts International Inc. statement outlining how the company plans to shed much of its $927 million in debt, the company said today. Federal Bankruptcy Judge Rosemary Gambardella requested minor language changes before approving the plan, said Christopher Whitney, the casino company's executive vice president.

headline: India-Nepal Accord on Ending Trade Dispute Is Near Collapse
abstract: LEAD: An agreement to end a yearlong trade dispute between India and Nepal is in danger of falling victim to the unsettled political situation in Katmandu and to India's preoccupation with a steadily worsening crisis in Kashmir.

headline: Midway Air's Gamble on Expansion
abstract: LEAD: Long esteemed on Wall Street as a scrappy little airline that thrived in a business dominated by Goliaths, Midway Airlines Inc. now finds itself in a brutal competitive struggle that has dealt the carrier heavy losses. The outcome, industry experts agree, will be decisive: Either Midway will become a larger and more profitable airline or a badly wounded also-ran.

headline: Airbus Curb in India
abstract: LEAD: Indian Airlines cannot lease out the A320 airbuses it grounded after a crash in February or sell other planes scheduled for delivery without the manufacturer's consent, an Airbus Industrie spokesman said last week. The spokesman, Robert Alizart, said that under a clause in any Airbus sale contract buyers could not reassign an aircraft still under warranty, like the 14 that have been grounded and the 4 on order, without Airbus's approval.

headline: ON G.E. AND EATING OUR SEED CORN
abstract: LEAD: An article May 13 (''Are We Eating Our Seed Corn?'') discussed the extent to which many large American corporations, and the General Electric Company in particular, are buying back their stock and thus spending less on research and development and missing opportunities to develop innovative products.

headline: Outcry Over Visits From South Africa
abstract: LEAD: Administration officials said today that they were considering ways to revise the schedule for the White House visits of President F. W. de Klerk of South Africa and Nelson Mandela because of protests that Mr. de Klerk's visit comes first.

headline: U.S. Tobacco Ads in Asia Faulted
abstract: LEAD: American cigarettes are advertised illegally in Asia, including ads on the covers of children's school notebooks, on kites and on chewing gum packages, witnesses told the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee today.

headline: Stocks Rise 3.93% in Tokyo
abstract: LEAD: The primary index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange surged nearly 4 percent this afternoon, helped by the yen's rebound against the dollar.

headline: Unrest Reported in Muslim Areas of China; Foreigners Are Barred
abstract: LEAD: Reports of unrest in Muslim areas of western China and of a ban on visits by foreigners to the area continued to circulate today, but the Foreign Ministry declined to comment.

headline: College Fund Goes Back To Its Roots
abstract: LEAD: WHEN executives at Young & Rubicam suggested to the United Negro College Fund 18 years ago that the organization focus its first public-service campaign around the line, ''A mind is a terrible thing to waste,'' the fund's leaders initially balked.

headline: 4-Year 'Workout' Trims Loan Loss
abstract: LEAD: The business of salvaging troubled properties is thriving as a result of the downturn in real estate values. But the savings and loan crisis has made many of these ''workout'' projects vastly more complicated than in the past.

headline: Pacificorp Raises Bid To Buy Pinnacle West
abstract: LEAD: Pacificorp, the utility giant based in Portland, Ore., today increased to $1.82 billion its offer for Arizona's largest utility, the Pinnacle West Capital Corporation.

headline: Tunis at Impasse on Political Change
abstract: LEAD: When word of Algeria's election results began to filter to its neighbor here, the people in the offices at 26 Gamal Abdel Nasser Street and 2 Madrid Avenue began drawing comparisons. While Algeria is pressing ahead with liberalization, they said, Tunisia has halted.

headline: East Bloc's Admirers in Africa Draw Line at Multiparty Politics
abstract: LEAD: African leaders who long admired Eastern Europe, accepted its aid and copied its political structures are vigorously resisting suggestions that multiparty democracy of the kind taking root in places like Poland and Hungary has any application at home.

headline: Cuba Upholds Prison Terms For Two Rights Campaigners
abstract: LEAD: Cuba's Supreme Court has upheld prison sentences against two human-rights campaigners jailed for discrediting the Cuban state by spreading false information, the Cuban press agency Prensa Latina said today.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: LEAD: * Avon Products Inc., New York, the cosmetics company, promoted Marcia Worthing to senior vice president for human resources.

headline: Japonica on Allegheny
abstract: LEAD: The private investment group Japonica Partners L.P. said today that it had bought enough of Allegheny International's debt to own more than 50 percent of the company once it emerges from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. The group has been trying to buy Allegheny through bankruptcy court proceedings and has lined up bank financing for a reorganization plan that includes a takeover.

headline: McCaw's Net Up in Quarter
abstract: LEAD: McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. reported yesterday that its earnings for the first quarter rose to $851.9 million, or $4.97 a share, compared with a loss of $97.7 million for the first quarter of 1989.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * American Brands Inc., Old Greenwich, Conn., said its shareholders defeated a proposal that would require the company to stop producing and marketing tobacco products by the year 2000.

headline: Cleric Is Buried
abstract: LEAD: The assassinated spiritual leader of Muslims in Srinagar was buried today in ceremonies attended by hundreds of thousands of Kashmiris. Separatist guerrillas, saying that the moderate Maulvi Mohammed Farooq was one of them in death, fired rounds from automatic weapons over his tomb, according to reports from the scene.

headline: No Decisions On Mark Yet, Kohl Says
abstract: LEAD: Moving to stifle the rising furor over proposals for monetary union, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany said today that no decisions had been made. He also appointed a leading official of West Germany's powerful central bank as his personal adviser on uniting the two nation's currencies.

headline: Stock Plan Announced By Playboy
abstract: LEAD: Playboy Enterprises Inc. announced a recapitalization plan today aimed at helping the company finance acquisitions and other activities without diluting the controlling stake of its founder, Hugh Hefner.

headline: Citicorp Deal Seen as Possible
abstract: LEAD: Citicorp is considering the purchase of United Savings Bank of Tysons Corner, Va., in a move that would sharply increase the size and reach of its consumer banking business in the Washington area, it was disclosed yesterday.

headline: Siebe Takeover Offer Accepted by Foxboro
abstract: LEAD: The Foxboro Company, a Massachusetts-based industrial controls company that has received inquiries from a number of suitors in recent weeks, agreed yesterday to be acquired by Siebe P.L.C., a British safety products and engineering company, for $52 a share, or $655 million.

headline: Israel Answers Soviets, Denies Plans for Settlers
abstract: LEAD: Israel reiterated tonight that it has no plans to settle Soviet Jewish immigrants in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

headline: INDIA IS ACCUSED IN CLERIC'S KILLING
abstract: LEAD: A senior official of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's Government accused India today of direct responsibility for the assassination in Indian-ruled Kashmir on Monday of the territory's most senior Muslim cleric, Maulvi Mohammed Farooq. His death was followed by those of at least several dozen mourners reportedly shot by Indian security forces as they followed Mr.

headline: Pension Fund Rating Shift
abstract: LEAD: The California Public Employees Retirement Systems, considered by some to be the nation's most influential pension fund, said today that it had started a system to evaluate corporate performance that will help it with investment decisions.

headline: The Guys in White Hats from Sony
abstract: LEAD: In 1989, the Materials Research Corporation, which I founded, was faced with a critical challenge: raise capital or probably fail. The capital we finally raised came from Japan. We are now a wholly owned subsidiary of Sony U.S.A.

headline: Icahn Seen As Loser in USX Vote
abstract: LEAD: Carl C. Icahn all but conceded today that he had failed to win support for his plan to split the USX Corporation. The votes cast at the annual meeting here will not be tabulated for at least a week, but the indications are that the New York financier has come up short in his costly campaign.

headline: RATES JUMP ON NEWS OF BUDGET GAP
abstract: LEAD: Interest rates climbed yesterday as prices of Treasury securities were battered by the report by the Government that it posted its largest monthly budget deficit on record in March.

headline: Li Peng Says Soviet Ideas of Change Do Not Apply to China
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Li Peng of China said today that reports of a rift with Moscow over the waning of Communism had been exaggerated, but he left little doubt that the two neighbors are on different political wavelengths.

headline: Banks Seen Closer to Trump Pact
abstract: LEAD: Bankers negotiating a $60 million loan package for Donald J. Trump moved closer to agreement yesterday after the contributions of some large New York banks were reduced, people involved in the talks said.

headline: 28 Sudan Officers Executed On Charges of Trying a Coup
abstract: LEAD: A military firing squad executed 28 officers, including three retired generals and a brigadier, after a summary court-martial on charges of trying to stage a coup, official news organizations reported.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * American Stock Exchange, New York, appointed Christopher Finn executive vice president, responsible for marketing, research, communications and government relations. Philip Steele was named senior vice president, responsible for strategic planning and special projects.

headline: World Bank Aid to Poles
abstract: LEAD: Poland and the World Bank initialed an agreement today for a $300 million loan to finance structural changes in Poland, the Deputy Finance Minister, Marek Dabrowski, said. He said that bank officials had approved Poland's long-term plans for economic development but that the first $100 million installment of the loan might be released only after the Government formally adopts the plans in August.

headline: Europe Sales Help Raise Compaq Net
abstract: LEAD: Buoyed by strong European sales that offset a slump in the domestic personal computer market, the Compaq Computer Corporation reported earnings today that exceeded Wall Street estimates. But Businessland Inc., a leading PC retailer, reported a loss, as expected.

headline: New President Named At Bank of New York
abstract: LEAD: As a junior officer at the Bank of New York's branch in the CBS Building in the mid-1970's, Alan R. Griffith had a ringside seat on the fast-growing communications industry and soon developed an expertise in lending to those companies.

headline: Explosion on Dead Sea Beach
abstract: LEAD: A bomb in a trash can exploded today on a Dead Sea beach, wounding four people, the police said. The explosion occurred at the Ein Gedi campground, a beach frequented by tourists and run by the Ein Gedi kibbutz. The area is south of the Israeli-occupied West Bank. No group took responsibility.

headline: Altera Buys Stake
abstract: LEAD: The Altera Corporation, a small but fast-growing semiconductor company, said it would buy a minority stake of a chip production factory in Texas from Cypress Semiconductor for $7.4 million. The agreement will give Altera its own production facility for a minimal investment. Cypress will get access to the next generation of Altera's technology.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Amdura Corp., Denver, said it would file for Federal bankruptcy protection after it was unable to get additional credit from its banks.

headline: Rightists Urge Whites to Oppose de Klerk
abstract: LEAD: The leader of the right-wing Conservative Party called on whites today to rally for ''all-encompassing action'' against President F. W. de Klerk's plans to dismantle apartheid.

headline: Business Books for New-Age Bosses
abstract: LEAD: I think of books as leading indicators. The ideas people grapple with today shape the future. But the books business readers are reading and the ideas writers are writing about tell me that traditional management ideas may no longer be relevant. The marketplace says traditional ideas about business and management don't excite much passion anymore.

headline: Lone Israeli Slays 7 Palestinians; 7 More Arabs Die as Riots Erupt
abstract: LEAD: An Israeli described as emotionally disturbed shot and killed seven Arab day laborers today, provoking widespread Palestinian riots in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip in which seven more Palestinians were killed and hundreds wounded or injured.

headline: Economic Scene;   Socialist Eggs, Market Omelet
abstract: LEAD: HUNGARY'S voters sent their Communist leaders to metaphoric Siberia this week, electing a nationalist coalition loosely cast in the image of the Christian Democratic parties of Western Europe. But the Communists' economic baggage, two decades of central planning followed by two decades of botched reforms, remains behind.

headline: Dominicans Vote: Balaguer vs. Bosch Again
abstract: LEAD: Large numbers of voters turned out today in an election that pitted two octogenarian rivals who have long dominated this country's politics against each other for what many expect will be the last time.

headline: Christian Factions Trade Fire In Battles in Beirut and Hills
abstract: LEAD: Rival Christian factions traded artillery shells and rockets today in Christian East Beirut and the Kesrouan hills northeast of here, and a five-story building in the militia-held quarter of Nabaa was set ablaze.

headline: Bank Lending Said to Slow; No Credit Squeeze Is Seen
abstract: LEAD: Three top Federal regulators said today that there had been a slowdown in bank lending but no credit squeeze. And they said that any slowdown should not be attributed to excessively harsh treatment of banks by examiners.

headline: NBC Shows Are Sought For Cable
abstract: LEAD: In a move with complicated political implications for the cable and broadcast television industries, Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest cable operator, has asked NBC to allow it to show the network's programs on cable channels in areas that do not have an NBC affiliate.

headline: Socialist Victory Seen In 2d Bulgarian Round
abstract: LEAD: Bulgarians went to the polls today in runoff elections that pitted the former Communist Party against opposition groups for control of Parliament.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   New Network Group Selects TBWA Agency
abstract: LEAD: The Network Television Association, which was formed in April by NBC, ABC and CBS to promote their medium, announced on Friday that it had selected TBWA Advertising to aid that effort.

headline: Economic Growth Seen
abstract: LEAD: The United States economy will skirt a recession through 1991 and set a postwar record for the longest period of business growth, the nation's top business economists predicted today.

headline: Careers;   Managing A Diverse Work Force
abstract: LEAD: SENSITIVITY training for managers has been around for years, but it has recently evolved into something more timely - training in the management of a diverse work force.

headline: Bhaktapur Journal;   The Katmandu Valley, Stage Set for Urban Ritual
abstract: LEAD: A West German architect calls it a valley of urban cultures so perfect that they are ''beyond expression.''

headline: Pristina Journal;   Albanians' New Way: Feuds Without Blood
abstract: LEAD: Libibe Dragacina extended his hand to Beslim Betushi, and when the handshake was concluded, a group of witnesses broke into happy applause.

headline: Data Bank/May 6, 1990
abstract: Index of Leading Indicators

headline: New Products Clog Food Stores
abstract: LEAD: New products are the lifeblood of the food business. But the large numbers being produced have begun to clog the industry's arteries, creating new strains between manufacturers and supermarket retailers.

headline: All About/Nintendo;  As the Craze Cools, A Youth-Based Industry Matures
abstract: LEAD: Companies that have enjoyed fast and easy growth designing and marketing home video games are now finding that, as in many of their games, survival gets trickier as play advances.

headline: Feuding Couple Settle Ownership of Esprit
abstract: LEAD: In a last-minute agreement that prevents the sale of the company to outsiders, the husband-and-wife founders of Esprit de Corp. said today that they would transfer ownership of the clothing company to an investor group headed by the wife.

headline: Ford Motor Credit Sells 10-Year Notes
abstract: LEAD: The Ford Motor Credit Corporation yesterday priced $200 million in 10-year notes through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

headline: Puerto Rico Issue Has 5.6% Yield
abstract: LEAD: A $250 million bond anticipation note issue from the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico was tentatively priced yesterday through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

abstract: LEAD: Moscovites are used to complaining about empty stores, but today their worst exaggerations became a reality as nervous weekend shoppers from within and without the city raided stores, leaving shelves bare.

headline: Stock of Motorola Off on Phone Plan
abstract: LEAD: The stock of Motorola Inc. dropped sharply after the company announced plans to build a $2.3 billion world cellular telephone network using satellites. Shares in Motorola fell $3.125 each in New York Stock Exchange trading, to close at $81. Tony G. Langham, an electronics industry analyst at County NatWest U.S.A., a New

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Amdura Corp., Denver, which is operating under Federal bankruptcy law protection, said it would solicit bids for its main hardware distribution business, thus putting all of its operating businesses up for sale.

headline: CHOICE IN MANAGUA FOR MILITARY CHIEF SETS OFF A FUROR
abstract: LEAD: On the eve of taking power, the political coalition of President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro has been thrown into crisis over a tentative agreement by Mrs. Chamorro to retain the Sandinista Defense Minister, Humberto Ortega Saavedra, as head of Nicaragua's army.

headline: Wells, Rich, Greene Deal Shows Strength of French
abstract: LEAD: The effort by French advertising companies to establish themselves as international marketers took a striking turn on Friday when Wells, Rich, Greene announced that it had sold a large minority interest to a French advertising conglomerate.

headline: Mentor Buying Sun Computers
abstract: LEAD: The Mentor Graphics Corporation said today that it will buy $300 million worth of Sun Microsystems Inc.'s Sparc computers over the next three years. Mentor, based in Beaverton, Ore., will resell the Sun computers bundled with its software, which is primarily used to design chips and printed circuit boards.
