headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Young & Rubicam
abstract: LEAD: Young & Rubicam appointed two more creative directors at its New York headquarters. They are Joey Cummings, formerly executive creative director at Bozell Chicago, and Michael Hampton, who was promoted from executive vice president and group creative director. Y.& R. also said Friday that it had acquired Arbeit & Company of New York, a data base marketing consulting firm.

headline: Olivetti Forms Cellular Venture
abstract: LEAD: Ing. C. Olivetti & Company, the Italian office machine and computer concern, announced it had formed a consortium to build a second cellular telephone system in Italy. Olivetti said the venture, called Omnitel-Sistemi Radiocellulari Italiani, would invest at least $1.2 billion if the Italian Ministry of Post and Telecommunications allows a rival to the cellular operations of S.I

headline: All About: Recreational Vehicles;  Will Motor Homes And Trailers Tempt A New Generation?
abstract: LEAD: A few miles south of Disneyland on Interstate 5, in Irvine, Calif., lies what some consider to be the real Magic Kingdom: Traveland U.S.A., billed as the world's largest sales lot for recreational vehicles.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   U.S.-SOVIET SUMMIT IS PLANNED MAY 30 WITH BUSH AS HOST
abstract: LEAD: President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union will hold a five-day meeting in the United States beginning on May 30, the White House and the Kremlin announced today.

headline: Baker's Ploy: A Middle East Timeout
abstract: LEAD: When Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d bluntly told the Israelis on Wednesday that they should telephone the White House when they are ready to get serious about peace, it sounded as if the Administration was actually preparing to take the unusual step of disengaging from Middle East diplomacy.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Nintendo's Account
abstract: LEAD: Nintendo of America, the video-game company, yesterday selected the San Francisco office of Foote, Cone & Belding as its advertising agency. The other finalist was the Leo Burnett Company; the incumbent was McCann-Erickson. Nintendo said the account would bill $35 million, although an executive at McCann said the company had never spent more than $15 million.

headline: South Korean Growth
abstract: LEAD: South Korea's economy grew strongly in the first three months of the year despite talk by Government officials of an economic crisis, the Bank of Korea reports. The central bank said gross national product in the three months expanded an inflation-adjusted 10.3 percent from a year earlier.

headline: Gallimard Case In Higher Court
abstract: LEAD: France's largest independent publisher, Editions Gallimard, faced an uncertain future today after a court failed to settle a damaging family dispute for control of the company.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD: * Irwin Gotlieb has been promoted to worldwide director of broadcast and programming at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, and Rino Scanzoni to director of national broadcast for the agency's United States division.

headline: Overstating Ink Toxicity?
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Panel Is Told of Backlog of Savings-Fraud Cases
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has a backlog of 234 referrals and complaints of large-scale fraud involving the nation's financial institutions, according to data released today at a Congressional hearing.

headline: Shareholders Seek New K Mart Rule
abstract: LEAD: Shareholders of the K Mart Corporation approved a proposal asking management to allow shareholders to vote before the company activates its ''poison pill'' anti-takeover defense. The request was approved 83.6 million shares to 64.1 million at the company's annual meeting on Tuesday.

headline: U.S. Indicts Iraqi In Plot to Kill 2
abstract: LEAD: A former driver for the Iraqi Mission to the United Nations in New York has been indicted on charges of plotting with an Iraqi agent to kill two opponents of the Iraqi Government who were in the United States, Federal prosecutors announced today.

headline: Campbell Cutting 364 From Staff
abstract: LEAD: The new chief executive of the Campbell Soup Company yesterday cut nearly 19 percent, or 364 jobs, from its headquarters staff in Camden, N.J.

headline: Uncovered Short Sales Set Another Record on Big Board
abstract: LEAD: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest increased by 16.6 million shares to a record level for the period ended June 15. The new total is about 2.5 percent above that for the month ended May 15, the previous record level.

headline: Marshall Field Deal By Dayton
abstract: LEAD: In a deal announced today, Marshall Field & Company of Chicago, one of the oldest and grandest names in American retailing, is to be sold for $1.04 billion to another venerable retailer, the Dayton Hudson Corporation of Minneapolis.

headline: Rescue of Gdansk Shipyard Stalls
abstract: LEAD: Ten months ago, it seemed that a capitalist fairy tale was unfolding at this city's famed shipyard, the birthplace of Poland's Solidarity trade union movement. But today, the hoped-for revival has become a case study of the difficulties of turning state-run companies in Eastern Europe into private enterprises.

headline: Milken Defends 'Junk Bonds' As He Enters His Guilty Plea
abstract: LEAD: Apologizing for his crimes but defending the ''junk bond'' market he created, Michael R. Milken pleaded guilty yesterday to six felony charges of securities fraud and conspiracy. The 43-year-old financier agreed to pay $600 million in fines and penalties.

headline: Name Change Set For Texas Air
abstract: LEAD: The Texas Air Corporation announced it would change its name to Continental Airlines Holdings Inc. The Houston-based concern, once the nation's largest airline company, owns Eastern Airlines, which is currently in bankruptcy proceedings, as well as Continental Airlines.

headline: U.S. Urged to End Opposition to Ozone Aid
abstract: LEAD: The head of the United Nations Environment Program strongly urged the United States today to reconsider its decision to oppose new financial aid to third-world countries to help them phase out chemicals that are destroying the earth's ozone layer.

headline: Warnaco Unit Gets Buyout Deal
abstract: LEAD: Warnaco Inc., one of the largest brand name apparel companies, announced yesterday that its management would buy out the company's Activewear division for $85 million.

headline: EAST BERLIN OPENS NAZI FILES TO U.S.
abstract: LEAD: The Justice Department has reached agreement with East Germany for access to that country's World War II archives, a move that investigators say could result in important new prosecutions of Nazi war criminals living in the United States.

headline: LIBERIAN WARFARE HAS ROOTS IN 1985
abstract: LEAD: When historians assess the rule of Gen. Samuel K. Doe, they may decide that the most serious crisis of his reign originated in 1985, at the height of his power, when his troops crushed a coup attempt.

headline: Soviet Family Weighs Whether to Go or Stay
abstract: LEAD: Olga Avilova, an art historian, wants to save her family from the Soviet Union's social, economic and environmental problems by emigrating to Israel. Her husband, Sergei Kuznetsov, a mathematician, says the country's educated professionals have an obligation to stay.

headline: Chrysler Urges Officials To Buy More of Its Stock
abstract: LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation has asked 100 senior executives to invest a greater share of their wealth in the company's future by purchasing Chrysler stock.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   2d Account Back at Waring
abstract: LEAD: ''Who says you can't go home again?'' a pleased Saul Waring, president of Waring & LaRosa, asked yesterday.

headline: Russian Nobles Gather To Don the Old Mantles
abstract: LEAD: The nobles of Russia gathered tonight in a small converted church off Red Square to collectively come out of the shadows of long-enforced oblivion.

headline: Business and the Law;   Critics Say Bill Threatens Privacy
abstract: LEAD: In their rush to toughen the nation's laws against money laundering, Congress and the Bush Administration may be stepping on the civil liberties of bank customers, the American Civil Liberties Union and some lobbying groups representing bankers assert.

headline: Sri Lanka Rebels Raid Vital Airfield in North
abstract: LEAD: Tamil rebels today fired mortars at a vital airfield in the Jaffna peninsula at the north of this island nation, minutes after a Government minister had left at the end of a round of peace talks, military officials said.

headline: Cambodian Guerrillas Report Offensive to Retake Territory
abstract: LEAD: Thousands of Cambodian guerrillas staged major attacks today in a bid to recapture territory seized by Government forces in recent weeks, senior guerrilla officials said.

headline: Newcastle Journal;   Sorry, but Andy Capp Doffs the Cap for No One
abstract: LEAD: Andy Capp without his cap?

headline: Two-Year Notes to Be Sold This Week
abstract: LEAD: Treasury financings this week include today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of new two-year notes on Wednesday.

headline: UGLY DEBATE ENDS AS PROVINCES SIGN ACCORD ON QUEBEC
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney and the premiers of Canada's 10 provinces signed a package of measures tonight to clear the way for a constitutional accord to keep Quebec a part of Canada.

headline: Careers;   Rethinking Business Education
abstract: LEAD: IT is no secret that one of today's overriding challenges is the need to make changes in graduate business schools. In fact, a recently published report, ''Leadership for a Changing World - The Future Role of Graduate Management Education,'' discusses some of the steps business school deans and business leaders consider necessary.

headline: Savings Fraud Suspects Listed
abstract: LEAD: Several savings and loan executives and associates suspected of fraud in the failures of their institutions have been singled out for possible Federal prosecution, a spokesman for the Office of Thrift Supervision said today.

headline: If Communism Is Waning, Asia Defies the Trend
abstract: LEAD: About the same time that Mikhail S. Gorbachev was ending his visit to the United States and voters in several Eastern European countries were heading into multiparty elections, the Communist Party of India was issuing a statement that began, ''The U.S. imperialists have intensified their aggression against Cuba.

headline: Miscellany
abstract: LEAD: * Cook's magazine and its parent company, Pennington Publishing, have shut down. Conde Nast Publications, a unit of Advance Publications, has bought the subscription list of Cook's and will send subscribers Gourmet magazine, starting with the September issue.

headline: Jusco Buys Rights For Chain in Japan
abstract: LEAD: The Jusco Company, a supermarket operator, agreed with Britain's Body Shop International P.L.C. to set up a chain of franchised shops selling Body Shop toiletry products in Japan. Jusco will set up a subsidiary to manage Body Shop franchises and plans to open its first outlet in Tokyo this fall, it said in a statement.

headline: No Sanctions On India Trade
abstract: LEAD: The Bush Administration said today, as expected, that it would not impose economic sanctions on India for trade barriers the United States deems offensive.

headline: Israel Accused of Firing at Hussein's Yacht
abstract: LEAD: An Israeli Navy boat fired at the yacht of King Hussein of Jordan as the King was standing on deck, an Israeli newspaper reported today. An Israeli military spokesman said the navy vessel did not fire at the King's yacht but in another direction, as part of a routine weapons check.

headline: Text of Letter and Resolution by Lithuanians
abstract: LEAD: Following, in the official translation from Lithuanian, are the texts of a letter from the Lithuanian Parliament to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, and of a parliamentary resolution on relations with the Moscow Government:       LETTER

headline: Norton's Net Down 36.4%
abstract: LEAD: The Norton Company, which spent many weeks fighting a hostile takeover bid, said today that its first-quarter profits fell 36.4 percent, mainly because of losses stemming from its operations in Brazil, which has been suffering from a recession.

headline: Manager Out at G.M. Plant
abstract: LEAD: Patricia Carrigan, who at one time was the only woman running a General Motors Corporation assembly plant, abruptly retired two weeks ago from a G.M. parts plant in Bay City, Mich., and news reports have swirled in recent days about misadministration of a benefit plan for workers at the plant.

headline: Currency;   Gaining Ground on the Mark
abstract: LEAD: The dollar rose against the West German mark again last week, topping 1.70 marks to the dollar briefly on Friday before slipping back to 1.6985. The dollar is now up more than 4 percent against the mark since the beginning of May. Some foreign exchange traders say that part of the mark's weakness stems from the belief that the West German Bundesbank is having more disagreements than usual over economic policy with the West German Government.

headline: Gabon Crowds, Angered by Death Of Dissident, Rampage in 2 Cities
abstract: LEAD: Anti-Government protesters rioted in Gabon's two biggest cities on Wednesday, burning public buildings and property belonging to President Omar Bongo and aides, witnesses said today.

headline: State Must Offer Remedy on Unlawful Taxes, Court Rules
abstract: LEAD: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that after a state tax has been found unconstitutional, the state must give ''meaningful relief'' to those whose taxes it has already collected.

headline: Afghan Fear: Does World Still Care?
abstract: LEAD: When a two-man team from Coca-Cola's Asian operation arrived at the company's abandoned plant near the Soviet Embassy here the other day, a crowd assembled. It continued to gather for days, even after word passed that it would be weeks, maybe months, before the plant could be re-commissioned.

headline: KEY RATES
abstract: LEAD:               Previous   Year     In percent   Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   10.00   10.00   11.50        DISCOUNT RATE   7.00   7.00   7.00        FEDERAL FUNDS   7.00   8.25   10.48        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   7.75   7.80   8.61        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   7.67   7.74   8.37        7-YR. TREAS. NOTES   8.62   8.64   8.64        30-YR.

headline: Del Monte Buyout
abstract: LEAD: The European processed foods division of the Merrill Lynch Company's Del Monte Corporation is being bought out by management for $375 million. The new company will be called Del Monte Foods International and will include the European Processed Food division's associated overseas companies. Merrill has owned the division only since Jan.

headline: Reporter's Notebook: Summit in Washington;   Smiles, Golf Carts and 2 Lethal Footballs
abstract: LEAD: The scene at Camp David this morning was tranquil and informal, if you did not count the 2 marines in fatigues frantically swabbing the landing pad, or the 14 marines in dress blues with rifles and Soviet and American flags, or the dozen sailors in dress whites standing at attention, or the swarm of security people, or the Soviet and American aides carrying the coded signaling devices for blowing up the world.

headline: U.N. Panel Backs 3 Translators Ousted at Beijing's Request
abstract: LEAD: In a ruling likely to have far-reaching consequences for Chinese and Soviet staff members here, a United Nations tribunal has said the organization had no right to dismiss three Chinese employees at the Beijing Government's request earlier this year.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Carrier Corp., Syracuse, a subsidiary of the United Technologies Corp. that makes air-conditioning, heating and refrigeration equipment, appointed Richard M. Whiston vice president and general counsel, replacing Richard F. Taylor Jr., who retired.

headline: Concern About Inventories Causes Energy Price Surge
abstract: LEAD: Energy futures prices surged yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid concerns that gasoline and crude oil inventories would be tight in the near term.

headline: Research Set on New Plane
abstract: LEAD: The Government today named a team of aerospace companies to do research and development work on a revolutionary aircraft intended to fly between New York and Tokyo in a few hours.

headline: Holding Concern Signs Merger Pacts
abstract: LEAD: The NUI Corporation signed agreements for Pennsylvania Enterprises Inc. and its Pennsylvania Gas and Water Company unit to merge into it. In addition, the United Water Resources Company will buy the water operations and related assets of Pennsylvania Enterprises for about $220 million.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Snapple Campaign
abstract: LEAD: ''The all-natural taste of Snapple beverages is so good,'' says its first ad campaign from Buckley/DeCerchio, ''it makes some people forget themselves.'' In one television commercial a family of five guzzles the drink as they motor across the desert singing ''Row, Row, Row Your Boat.'' But they have been drinking without thinking; a road sign notes that the next rest area - and by implication the next bathroom - is 115 miles away.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: LEAD: Listed below are the target dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.       MONDAY       Construction Spending    Feb.       Tuesday       Leading Indicators    Feb.       Wednesday       New-Car Sales    March       Thursday       None       Friday       Consumer Credit

headline: Trading Away the Trade Deficit
abstract: LEAD: Last month's announcement by the Commerce Department that the trade deficit narrowed to $113 billion for 1989 sparked a sense of euphoria. It is true that the deficit was 11 percent less than the $127 billion recorded in 1988, but even with this modest improvement, the current account deficit is still running in excess of $100 billion.

headline: Adobe Expects Lower Profits
abstract: LEAD: Adobe Systems Inc., which supplies software that controls laser printers, said its revenues and earnings in its second quarter would be sharply lower than anticipated, largely because of a decline in sales to Apple Computer Inc., its largest customer.

headline: Strategist Quietly Gains Power Amid CBS Shifts
abstract: LEAD: Only a few years after being brought into the exclusive circle entrusted with resuscitating CBS, Jay L. Kriegel, a lawyer and one-time political aide with no background and little interest in television, has quietly emerged as the key strategist of the network's effort to pull itself out of the broadcasting basement.

headline: Lockheed Posts Gain of 11.3%
abstract: LEAD: The Lockheed Corporation said today that first-quarter earnings increased 11.3 percent, to $69 million, or $1.09 a share, from $62 million, or $1.04 a share, in the 1989 period. Sales rose 7.7 percent, to $2.25 billion from $2.09 billion.

headline: Penny Stock Quote System
abstract: LEAD: A new electronic system that gives brokers the prices of low-priced stocks has been a success, with use nearly doubling in the first week, the industry trade group that began the service said today.

headline: ABU NIDAL'S RIVALS SEEM TO BE GAINING
abstract: LEAD: The Palestinian terrorist Abu Nidal appears to be losing ground in a struggle for control of his group to rivals who say they will follow the less militant guidelines of Yasir Arafat's Palestine Liberation Organization.

headline: Market Place;  Growing Pains At Pic 'N' Save
abstract: LEAD: THE Pic 'N' Save Corporation, a leading retailer in the close-out merchandise field, is fighting for its future. An investment group led by David H. Batchelder, a former strategist to T. Boone Pickens, is seeking control of Pic 'N' Save's board with the intent of forcing the company's sale.

headline: Arabs Split in Reaction to Bush's Move on P.L.O.
abstract: LEAD: The United States decision to suspend contacts with the Palestine Liberation Organization produced forecasts today of increased violence from many Palestinian and Arab commentators, but some Arab nations sought to dampen the furor with more muted expressions.

headline: Greyhound Plans To Rebuild Fleet
abstract: LEAD: Searching for ways to save money and attract new financing, Greyhound Lines Inc. said it would rebuild its fleet of 3,949 buses instead of buying new models. Greyhound's president, Frank Schmieder, estimated the strike-bound bus line would save $318.5 million, compared with the cost of replacing the buses in two and a half years.

headline: Evolution in Europe: Bucharest Journal;   Feuds and Fisticuffs, but No Once and Future King
abstract: LEAD: By barring the exiled King of Romania from returning over the Easter holidays, the Romanian Government had hoped to avoid conflicts in a period of explosive political volatility.

headline: Nippon Telephone Split Delayed
abstract: LEAD: This year's steep drop in prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange may have saved the world's largest company, the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, from being broken up.

headline: Time Unit and 7 Days in Deal
abstract: LEAD: Entertainment Weekly, the magazine begun in February by the Time Inc. Magazine Company, has purchased the name and subscription list of 7 Days, which ceased publication on April 16.

headline: U.S. Delays On Iraqi Bid
abstract: LEAD: The Bush Administration has delayed a decision on Iraq's request for an additional $500 million in loan guarantees from the Commodity Credit Corporation until the conclusion of an Agriculture Department investigation into possible irregularities, including kickbacks, involving Iraq's purchase of American agricultural commodities.

headline: Chamorro, Naming Cabinet, Bypasses Her Coalition Allies
abstract: LEAD: After a burst of last-minute discord and reshuffling, President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro took full control of the Government today with a 13-member Cabinet of businessmen and technocrats with few links to traditional Nicaraguan politics.

headline: Patents;   Protecting Spacecraft From Debris in Orbit
abstract: LEAD: Engineers at the General Research Corporation, a scientific consulting firm in Vienna, Va., obtained a patent this week for what amounts to a garbage collector in space. Its purpose: to protect spacecraft from collisions with orbiting debris.

headline: New York City Chooses Firms for Bond Offering
abstract: LEAD: Ending a fierce competition on Wall Street, New York City has named the five securities firms that will serve as senior managers for its general-obligation bond offerings over the next two years.

headline: New Interactive TV Threatens the Bliss Of Couch Potatoes
abstract: LEAD: New television services that capitalize on computer technology are beginning to allow viewers to become more involved in what they watch, either by controlling what is seen on the screen or by becoming armchair participants in game shows or sporting events.

headline: Della Femina's Andy Victory
abstract: LEAD: The Boston office of Della Femina, McNamee WCRS suffered a sharp blow in March when it lost the Parker Brothers account to Grey Advertising, but the agency's showing at last night's Andy Awards at the Waldorf-Astoria should restore much of its pride.

headline: Tech Notes;   Cramming More on the Hard Disk
abstract: LEAD: Until now, putting extra data on a disk was accomplished by software programs that were cumbersome and sometimes lost the information they were supposed to store. Now a start-up company, Infochip Systems Inc., in Santa Clara, Calif., has developed a computer chip for high-speed data compression that can be used with personal computers and work stations.

headline: Iran-European Community Talks Stall
abstract: LEAD: Iran made its pitch to improve relations with the European Community today, but both sides made clear after three hours of talks here that there had been no breakthroughs on the issues of hostages and Iran's call for the death of the British author Salman Rushdie.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   RISING FOOD PRICES STIR PANIC BUYING IN SOVIET MARKETS
abstract: LEAD: Government plans to raise prices sharply set off panic buying and opposition in the country today, causing the Moscow authorities to order restrictions on food shopping in the city and prompting the Ukrainian Prime Minister to vow resistance.

headline: Algerian Front Formed in '54 to Fight French
abstract: LEAD: A radical group of indigenous Algerian nationalists, calling itself the National Liberation Front, was formed in 1954 and began an armed revolt against French rule of its homeland, which was one of France's chief colonies.

headline: G.M. Chairman Gets 'No' Vote
abstract: LEAD: The California Public Employees Retirement System, a large holder of the stock of the General Motors Corporation, said today that it had voted against the re-election of the departing G.M. chairman, Roger B. Smith, to the board.

headline: All the Arms Talks: Where They Stand as the Summit Nears
abstract: LEAD: Despite some small signs of progress recently, negotiations on the first reduction in long-range nuclear arms are moving slowly and are complicating preparations for what President Bush has called his ''arms control summit,'' Administration officials say.

headline: Hotly Contested Press Proposal Fades in U.N.
abstract: LEAD: One of the most debated ideas that the United Nations has ever put forward - its call for a ''new world information and communications order,'' which would sanction government control of news organizations - is slowly fading away.

headline: Higher Incomes, U.N. Finds, Do Not Assure a Better Life
abstract: LEAD: Challenging traditional ways by which the world has measured the growth of nations, a new report issued by the United Nations Development Program concludes that there is no automatic link between a country's per capita income and the well-being and progress of its people.

headline: Insulting Gorbachev: A Crime?
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Parliament moved to adopt criminal penalties, including prison terms, for public remarks insulting President Mikhail S. Gorbachev or his policies. Page 10.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   The Poles Vote for Local Offices: 52,000 Races Are Contested
abstract: LEAD: Poles voted today for community councils nationwide and were expected to push forward democratic changes by ousting holdover Communists from their last bastions of power.

headline: Xerox Sets A Write-Off
abstract: LEAD: The Xerox Corporation said today that it would take a pretax write-off of nearly $400 million in the first quarter because of its investment in VMS Realty Partners.

headline: Rates Decline At Citicorp Sale
abstract: LEAD: Interest rates declined yesterday at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper.

headline: Latvia Moves to Find Amity With Moscow
abstract: LEAD: The Latvian President sought last night to strike a conciliatory stance toward Moscow, saying in a television broadcast that his republic would not suspend the Soviet Constitution.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Gorbachev Supporter Voted Russian Premier
abstract: LEAD: A national bureaucrat was elected Prime Minister of the Russian republic today, defeating an ally of the republic's President, Boris N. Yeltsin, the official press agency Tass reported.

headline: Muslim Leader of Kashmir Slain; 30 Die as Police Fire on Mourners
abstract: LEAD: A hereditary Islamic leader, the most senior and influential opponent of Indian rule in Kashmir, was assassinated in his home in the state's capital today. When 100,000 angry mourners followed his body through the streets of the city, security forces opened fire, killing at least 30 people and wounding some 200, according to hospital doctors.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:    MARKETS       A panel created to restore investor confidence after last October's stock plunge recommended that the Government require most financial markets to close for as much as a full day at times of great volatility. But the panel recommended only minor curbs on computerized program trading.

headline: Foote, Cone Seeks a Link With Japan
abstract: LEAD: DURING the Korean War, Norman W. Brown spent two years in Japan cracking codes as an Air Force intelligence officer. Now, Mr. Brown, the chairman and chief executive of Foote, Cone & Belding Communications, is using his knowledge of East Asia to find a partner in the booming Japanese advertising market.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: LEAD: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of June 17:       MONDAY       Bunker Hill Income Secs    HomeFed Corp    PHH Corp    Rykoff Sexton       TUESDAY       Bankers Tr NY    Brunswick Corp    CPC Intl Inc    Harsco Corp    Hexcel Corp    House Fabrics Inc    Upjohn Co       WEDNESDAY

headline: Measure Aids Swap Market
abstract: LEAD: Banks and other companies active in the trillion-dollar market for interest rate and currency swaps benefited on Monday when President Bush signed legislation amending bankruptcy laws. The measure requires bankruptcy courts to recognize the validity of certain agreements used in the swap market.

headline: Peoria Unites to Aid One of Town's Own, Hostage in a Jungle
abstract: LEAD: After Scott Heimdal, an American who was working at a mining company in Northern Ecuador, was abducted in that country April 28 and taken to Colombia by Colombian guerrillas, his captors demanded $1.2 million ransom.

headline: Mutual Funds;   Questions for the Eleventh Hour
abstract: LEAD: Tomorrow is the deadline for filing 1989 taxes, and many last-minute filers are spending the weekend putting the final touches on their returns. In fact, so many people drag their feet that April 15 traditionally is the biggest day of the year for investors' telephone calls at the New York-based Oppenheimer Management

headline: Grand Met Delays Listing A.D.R.'s
abstract: LEAD: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. has postponed until February its plan to list the company's American depository receipts on the New York Stock Exchange, David P. Nash, the company's top financial officer, told securities analysts in a meeting this week in New York. The company had originally planned the listing for sometime this fall.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Allegheny International Inc., Pittsburgh, a maker of electrical appliances, said most of its creditors and a majority of its stockholders had voted in favor of its Chapter 11 reorganization plan, but it fell short of the two-thirds majority needed in two classes of creditors.

headline: Nigeria Reports It Foiled a Coup By Army Rebels
abstract: LEAD: Nigeria announced today that troops loyal to the military Government of Gen. Ibrahim Babangida had thwarted an attempted coup, forcing rebel officers to surrender after 11 hours of fighting.

headline: Market Place;   London Is Trying To Keep Its Lead
abstract: LEAD: THESE are nervous times for the London International Stock Exchange. The exchange's computerized trading system is one of the most advanced in the world. But officials there are deeply worried about competition from other markets in Europe and about investors' ability to bypass the exchange and trade among themselves -and their tendency to do so because of the exchange's cumbersome and costly settlement operation.

headline: U.S. Sets Wool Subsidy
abstract: LEAD: Producers of wool and mohair will receive about $100 million in Government subsidies because 1989 market prices fell below the Federal support level, the Agriculture Department has reported. The payments, which are to begin immediately, will be split equally between wool and mohair producers.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:    Debt

headline: Separatist Coalition Takes Lead In Voting in a Yugoslav Republic
abstract: LEAD: In the first free multiparty elections in Yugoslavia since World War II, a center-right opposition coalition appears certain of a majority in the main chamber of the Slovenian Parliament.

headline: Quebec and Canada: Loveless Match
abstract: LEAD: ''Scotch and water,'' said Claude Beland, uttering the words with a shudder usually reserved for cod liver oil. ''Here, we drink wine.''

headline: Renault Dividend
abstract: LEAD: The French state-owned car maker Renault said it would pay its shareholders - the French Government and its own employees - their first dividend since 1980. The payout will be 750 million francs, or $133.4 million. Of this, 742 million francs, or $131.9 million, will be for the state. Renault's status as a state agency was altered last week by legislation that allows it to enter into a partnership with Volvo A.B.

headline: How Distinct Is Quebec? French, and That's That
abstract: LEAD: The stop signs here all say ''arret.'' French Canadians have their own national holidays, their own music videos, their own literature. They drink wine at lunch and still smoke with abandon in cafes, offices and public elevators.

headline: STRIKES TESTING CHAMORRO'S RULE
abstract: LEAD: Striking civil servants loyal to the opposition Sandinista Front ignored a Government ultimatum ordering them to return to work by 9 A.M. today, confronting the new and impoverished Government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro with its first serious political crisis.

headline: Napo Journal;   In Thailand's Driest Corner, Poverty With Grace
abstract: LEAD: In the little village of Napo in the poorest part of Thailand - the drought-prone Esarn, or northeast - the benefits and strains of the country's extraordinary development are easily seen.

headline: Two Enter Guilty Pleas In Tax-Fraud Scheme
abstract: LEAD: Two businessmen have pleaded guilty to engaging in a tax-fraud scheme that involved more than $4 billion in rigged and bogus transactions in Treasury bills and other Government securities, the United States Attorney in Manhattan announced yesterday.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Creativity Takes Twist At Berenter
abstract: LEAD: THE advertising of Berenter, Greenhouse & Webster is inventive. Take its forthcoming work for Baileys Original Irish Cream Liqueur. It was invented in the agency's test kitchen.
